testcase: Guidance on cross version breaking change for readonly and async operations in new api-versions

expected.answer:
The 'provisioningState' change in the PATCH request model seems like a bug fix if this field was always read-only.  When you get a breaking change review, if this is explained with an appropriate comment, this is likely to be justified as a bug fix.
On changing PATCH to synchronous.  ARM does support async PATCH operations, although REST API Guidelines discourage async PATCH operations.  If this operation is synchronous in the previous stable version, then this change is a real breaking change that you will need to justify in breaking change review.
Similarly, making PUT and DELETE Asynchronous is a breaking change if these operations were synchronous in the previous stable version is a real breaking change, and you will need to justify the change in a breaking change review.

Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change
Does it make sense for a put operation with Location header?

actual.answer:
1. Removal of a readonly field like 'provisioningState' from the PATCH operation model (e.g., ConfigurationPropertiesUpdate) is NOT a breaking change and should NOT be flagged as such. According to Azure and ARM guidelines, properties that are calculated by the service and marked as readonly (such as provisioningState) should only appear in response models, not in request models for PUT/PATCH. The PATCH request body should only include properties that are updatable by the client. If your PATCH model omits provisioningState, this is correct and compliant with best practices. If the breaking change tooling flags this as a removal, it is a false positive and can be safely ignored or suppressed with justification.

2. Changing CUD (Create, Update, Delete) operations to be Long Running Operations (LROs) in a new API version is allowed and is NOT a breaking change for previous versions. The correct approach is:
- Introduce the LRO pattern (e.g., 202/202+Location/Azure-AsyncOperation headers) only in the new API version.
- Do NOT change the behavior of existing API versions; they must remain synchronous if they were previously synchronous.
- Use TypeSpec ARM templates such as ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync, ArmResourcePatchAsync, ArmResourceDeleteAsync for the new version, and keep the old version using the synchronous templates.
- If the operation signature changes (e.g., request/response body), use the @added/@removed decorators to version the operations and models accordingly.
- If you need to support both synchronous and asynchronous behavior in the same API version (based on customer input), you must clearly document the behavior and ensure the OpenAPI spec reflects the possible status codes and headers.

Summary: For PATCH, readonly fields should not be present in the request model. For LRO, only introduce the async pattern in the new API version, and keep old versions unchanged. Use TypeSpec versioning decorators and ARM templates to ensure correct separation and avoid breaking changes.

How to fix it?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIt depends.  Even across versions, some changes are discouraged/disallowed.  If the breaking changes reported in your PR are all intentional, then you just need to follow the instructions in the \\\\\\\"next steps to merge\\\\\\\" comment to work with the breaking changes board for approval: https://aka.ms/brch\\\\r\\\\nGenerally, breaking changes between preview api-versions are allowed if there are good reasons,  breaking changes relative to a stable api-version are more of a concern.  Also, if preview api-versions are old enough, they count as stable api-versions (I doubt that is the case here).\\\\r\\\\nThe case here is a preview with breaking changes relative to the last stable. And in this case, making a property optional would be considered breaking if the property occurs in responses.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"How to versioning name pattern?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to versioning name pattern?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to versioning name pattern?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe released a preview version of our API and found that the pattern being enforced on some of the model properties was too restrictive.  We wanted to relax them, but it doesn't seem I can do that with the added/removed decorators unless I change the name of the property.  Is there anything I'm missing or this is how it must be done?\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@removed(Microsoft.IoTFirmwareDefense.Versions.v2025_06_01)\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Firmware vendor.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@pattern(\\\\\\\"^[a-zA-Z0-9][a-zA-Z0-9-_.,'\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"~=(){}:]*$\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nvendor?: string;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nYou, 1 second ago \\u00b7 Uncommitted changes\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(Microsoft.IoTFirmwareDefense.Versions.v2025_06_01)\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Firmware vendor.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nvendor?: string;    Model already has a property named vendor\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIt's possible to version this, but it involves a remove/rename/replace pattern which is not recommand, and you would need to version the resource and all its operations.\\\\r\\\\nIt is better and more accurate to just make the constraint change for all versions. Because constraints usually don't change for only a single api-version, but for all versions in the service\\\\r\\\\nYou should double confirm if you relaxe this pattern across all api-versions in your service, or just the new api-version.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#reproducibility.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Reproducibility\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/reproducibility\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Reproducibility\\\\n# handbook#reproducibility.md\\\\n\\\\n# Reproducibility\\\\n\\\\nA crucial aspect of service definition is ensuring consistent output over time. This is important in scenarios such as:\\\\r\\\\n- An update to a dependency or sub-dependency introduces an unexpected breaking change.\\\\r\\\\n- Updates to a new version of a service should not impact older versions.\\\\r\\\\n- Modifications are made to the TypeSpec specification.\\\\r\\\\nThese issues can be mitigated with a few precautionary measures:\\\\n\\\\n## 1. Defend against dependency changes\\\\n\\\\n_Note: This section applies if using `tsp install` or `npm install` to install dependencies. However other package managers (`yarn`, `pnpm`, etc.) have their own similar lock mechanisms._\\\\r\\\\nWhen using `tsp install` or `npm install` a `package-lock.json` will be installed. This file SHOULD be committed to source control. It will ensure that later calls to `tsp install` or `npm install` will use the exact versions resolved in the lock files unless the `package.json` was updated or a command like `npm update` was run.\\\\r\\\\nThe command `npm ci` can also be used in the CI to ensure that the `package.json` and `package-lock.json` are in sync.\\\\n\\\\n## 2. Work with multiple versions of a service\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec provides a library `@typespec/versioning` that can be used to describe changes to a service or library over time. Using this will ensure that a service can evolve while keeping track of the changes and allowing emitters to see the service representation at different versions.\\\\r\\\\n[See versioning docs](../libraries/versioning/reference/index.mdx)\\\\n\\\\n## 3. Change to the TypeSpec spec\\\\n\\\\nIf you don't directly control the spec, you might still want to make sure you remember which exact definition was used.\\\\r\\\\nUsing version control and pinning to a specific commit SHA will ensure that the spec will remain exactly as it was.\\\\n\\\\n## Summary\\\\n\\\\n1. Use `package-lock.json`\\\\r\\\\n2. Use [versioning library](../libraries/versioning/reference/index.mdx)\\\\r\\\\n3. Keep track of commit IDs\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#breaking-change-policy.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Breaking Change Policy\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/breaking-change-policy\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Breaking Change Policy\\\\n## Breaking Change Philosophy\\\\n### Bugs\\\\n# handbook#breaking-change-policy.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Breaking Change Policy\\\\n\\\\n## Breaking Change Philosophy\\\\n\\\\n### Bugs\\\\n\\\\nA bug fix that introduces a technically breaking change will not be considered a breaking change for the purposes of TypeSpec versioning if it is clear that the existing behavior was broken or unintended in the first place.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi all.  My team (Microsoft Translator) is trying to update our POST translate call with a breaking change.  The PR is: [Update translate call to 2025-05-01 by SG-MS \\u00b7 Pull Request #33410 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/33410) \\\\r\\\\nThe old version (3.0) is being updated to a new version (2025-05-01-preview).  The big change to our typespec definition is that we will be moving most of the request properties from query parameters to the request body.  In 3.0, the only property in the request body was an array of InputTextItem.  InputTextItem is just a string.  All the other relevant data was passed in as query parameters. \\\\r\\\\nIn 2025-05-01-preview, we want to add a number of additional properties to the request body, so rather than the body consisting of InputTextItem, we want the body to contain a TranslateBody definition, which in turn contains all of our properties.  I'm not sure how to represent this in the tsp files in a compliant way.   \\\\r\\\\nOur translate operation in the routes.tsp file is \\\\r\\\\nop translate is CustomOperation\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n InputTextItem[],\\\\r\\\\n TranslateParameters,\\\\r\\\\n TranslationResult,\\\\r\\\\n ErrorResponse\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\u003e; \\\\r\\\\nThe first member of the template is the request body and I need it to be InputTextItem[] for 3.0 and I need it to be TranslateBody for 2025-05-01-preview.  Otherwise one of them will have the wrong set of arguments.  I considered simply updating InputTextItem to contain all the needed parameters in TranslateBody and then removing the unused ones with @added decorators, but the problem is we have a number of other operators in 2025-05-01-preview which use InputTextItem and require it to be just the text string.   \\\\r\\\\nIs there anyway to have two different translate operations such that one is called by 3.0 and one is called by 2025-05-01-preview?  I think that's what would really get what I need.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nchanges for older API versions:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nYou also need to use @renamedFrom(\\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\", newVersion) on the old update operation and put @sharedRoute on both.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nMake sure you don\\u2019t use a model that is not available in a certain version and carry over the @added/@removed if needed.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf a property like userAssignedIdentities was marked as added in 2023, but the model it depends on (ManagedServiceIdentity) was only added later, it doesn\\u2019t make sense \\u2014 this can be the result of composing shared models.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThe sharedRoute might be sharing the new property to the old versions and not honoring the @added and @removed decorators.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf you mark the whole model like:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2024_06_01_preview)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel ManagedServiceIdentityUpdate  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\u2026errors may occur if parts of the model were added in older versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nOne workaround was to use ManagedServiceIdentityProperty instead of Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ManagedServiceIdentity\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nLintDiff errors like AvoidAnonymousTypes seem to be coming from the MSI additionalProperties section. This error wasn\\u2019t there before setting use-read-only-status-schema: true, but it\\u2019s unclear why that config causes it.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWarnings like \\\\\\\"Use the latest version v5 of types.json\\\\\\\" for old API versions or EnumInsteadOfBoolean for new ones can be ignored \\u2014 warnings are not required to change for check-in, only errors.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nFalse positives (like Avocado errors) may also occur when using @removed and @added in the same API version \\u2014 especially for preview versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf everything is tagged properly and using the latest compiler version, you should be able to get it approved. After that, just follow the normal PR process (e.g., sign-offs, label like WaitForARMFeedback).\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThere is some documentation on this here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning/#converting-an-operation-from-synchronous-to-asynchronous) (this is for ARM, but the same principle applies)\\\\n\\\\nthe post below might be helpful. It also involves adding a \\\\\\\"adding\\\\\\\" a newer API on the same route with different method signature. You'd need to add `@sharedRoute` on both methods and point it to the same route.\\\\r\\\\n[Jocelyn Wei: Changing interface's `update` from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustom... | Azure SDK \\\\u003e TypeSpec Discussion | Microsoft Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf@thread.skype/1721233288788?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47\\\\u0026groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026parentMessageId=1721233288788\\\\u0026teamName=Azure%20SDK\\\\u0026channelName=TypeSpec%20Discussion\\\\u0026createdTime=1721233288788):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\ntitle: Changing interface's `update` from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustomPatchAsync without generating breaking changes\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nquestion:\\\\r\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion,\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nI am attempting to follow the playground example here TypeSpec Azure to get past a LintDiff error after adding an MSI to my resource. However, adding the new update model as well as changing the interface from update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003c... to update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003c... is generating breaking changes for older api versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIs there a way to only change the update is.. for the newest api version? I tried using the @added and @removed decorators but the interface complained about duplicate update.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nSummary of answer:\\\\r\\\\nTo change the update operation from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustomPatchAsync without generating breaking changes for older API versions:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nYou also need to use @renamedFrom(\\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\", newVersion) on the old update operation and put @sharedRoute on both.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nMake sure you don\\u2019t use a model that is not available in a certain version and carry over the @added/@removed if needed.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf a property like userAssignedIdentities was marked as added in 2023, but the model it depends on (ManagedServiceIdentity) was only added later, it doesn\\u2019t make sense \\u2014 this can be the result of composing shared models.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#breaking-change-policy.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Breaking Change Policy\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/breaking-change-policy\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Breaking Change Policy\\\\n## Categories of Breaking Changes\\\\n### Emitter output\\\\n# handbook#breaking-change-policy.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Breaking Change Policy\\\\n\\\\n## Categories of Breaking Changes\\\\n\\\\n### Emitter output\\\\n\\\\nEmitter output are not guaranteed to be producing the exact same output as the previous version for the same input. A change that is semantically equivalent wouldn't be considered a breaking change by the emitter.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## 1. Policy Overview and Motivation\\\\n### 1.1 Motivation\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 1. Policy Overview and Motivation\\\\n\\\\n### 1.1 Motivation\\\\n\\\\nBreaking changes introduce interruptions for our customers and negatively impacts the Azure brand. To maintain customer satisfaction, service teams are strongly encouraged to find other ways to introduce the functionality desired without breaking existing customers. If you believe a breaking change is mandatory, please continue to read the rest of the document on the policy and the process.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n### Visibility Changes for `nextLink` and `value` Properties\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n\\\\n### Visibility Changes for `nextLink` and `value` Properties\\\\n\\\\nFor the `nextLink` and `value` properties of pageable operation response model, some older specifications marked these values as `readOnly`. This has no impact on the API or on SDKs, you can safely ignore this difference in the spec, and any resulting breaking change violation.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## 1. Policy Overview and Motivation\\\\n### 1.3 Purpose\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 1. Policy Overview and Motivation\\\\n\\\\n### 1.3 Purpose\\\\n\\\\nThe purpose of the policy outlined here is to enable breaking changes while limiting the negative impact to Azure customers. There are times when an Azure service team will want to introduce a breaking change typically to fix some security-related issue or to alter how something existing works in order to introduce some new functionality.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## 3. Detailed Breaking Change Process\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 3. Detailed Breaking Change Process\\\\n\\\\nService owners should start this process before making any breaking changes. Service owners should plan for at least 6-8 weeks (about 2 months) for the process to be completed. Here are the process steps:\\\\n\\\\n### 1. Intake Preparation (Owner: Service PM)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 1-3 days\\\\r\\\\n- Create a new intake using the template for breaking changes: \\\\u003chttps://msazure.visualstudio.com/One/_workitems/create/Scenario?templateld=c815af37-5520-43ff-90c8-d985eaabcb6c\\\\u0026ownerld=85bb92fb-21fe-41ca-9309-47f2c5f57515\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n- Save Intake Request as New.\\\\r\\\\n- Please assign the intake to the service owner PM.\\\\r\\\\n- Add the \\\\\\\"Breaking Change\\\\\\\" tag.\\\\r\\\\n- Please ensure your request shows up in the dashboard (\\\\u003chttps://msazure.visualstudio.com/One/_dashboards/dashboard/f7db6895-7137-4695-b3f5-00dc4d36758f\\\\u003e)\\\\r\\\\n- Send email to @azbreakchangereview.\\\\r\\\\n- Attend weekly Office Hours to talk through the breaking change and seek approval. The office hours are on Mondays, 10 AM to 11 AM Pacific Time. Meeting details can be found here.\\\\n\\\\n### 2. Intake Evaluation (Owner: Service PM/Breaking Change review board)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 1-2 weeks\\\\r\\\\n- Validate high-level business justification.\\\\r\\\\n- What is the proposal that is being reviewed?\\\\r\\\\n- Why do you need this breaking change?\\\\r\\\\n- What will your team do if the breaking change is not approved? There is a high chance the breaking change will NOT be approved.\\\\r\\\\n- Customer experience impact.\\\\r\\\\n- Number of customers affected.\\\\r\\\\n- How can you reduce the impact on customers?\\\\n\\\\n### 3. Intake decision (Owner: Breaking change Review Board)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 1-3 days\\\\r\\\\n- Reviewing all the information, the Breaking Change Review Board will decide whether to approve the proposal, change it, or disapprove it.\\\\n\\\\n### 4. Intake approval from Azure REST API board (Owner: Service PM)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 1 week\\\\r\\\\n- Once approved by the Breaking Change Review Board, status of the intake will be marked as approved by the Breaking Change Review Board.\\\\r\\\\n- If there is an SDK impact- then the proposal should be reviewed by API board to seek approval. Reference the API Breaking change documentation: \\\\u003chttps://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/blob/vNext/azure/Guidelines.md#api-changes-that-require-a-version-change\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n- Engage the SDK team and the SDK Review board to minimize the impact on client libraries.\\\\r\\\\n- Service teams should not implement the change until all approvals have been received.\\\\n\\\\n### 5. Communication Readiness (Owner: Service PM/Azure Marketing/CSS)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 2-6 weeks\\\\r\\\\n- Service team owners will need to work with Azure PMM/ Service PM/ Sharon Loh (Breaking change Team - Marketing) - to lock on communication template. If breaking change impacts more than 20,000 subscription IDs, the customer email will be reviewed by assigned editorial team and needs marketing GM and at least one marketing CVP approval. This process will take 2 to 4 weeks.\\\\r\\\\n- Engage MS DOC team to update content.\\\\r\\\\n- Engage Business planning team to update price, if appropriate\\\\r\\\\n- Engage assigned Azure PMM to update marketing assets and ACOM.\\\\r\\\\n- Engage Comms Team for avoiding negative press. (If needed)\\\\r\\\\n- Engage Azure portal team to update content or add banner.\\\\r\\\\n- Engage CSS for awareness into this breaking change being shared with customers.\\\\r\\\\n- Engage with CXP (Doug Miller) to schedule communication to customers.\\\\n\\\\n### 6. Signoff/Approval (Owner: Service PM/ APEX Retirements team)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 2-3 weeks (in parallel with communication readiness)\\\\r\\\\n- A signoff sheet for the breaking change request will be created.\\\\r\\\\n- Service teams will need to get all signoffs including their service CVP.\\\\r\\\\n- APEX Retirements team will help with Office of CTO sign offs.\\\\n\\\\n### 7. Communication update (Owner: Service PM/ CXP)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** Quarterly on preset schedule (Feb, June, Aug, Nov)\\\\r\\\\n- Azure updates\\\\r\\\\n- Email comms to customers.\\\\r\\\\n- Communication rhythm: 3 years, 2 years, 1 year, 6 months, 90 days (about 3 months), 30 days (about 4 and a half weeks), then weekly until T-O.\\\\r\\\\n- Service health notification in-product messaging.\\\\n\\\\n### 3.1 Signoff Criteria\\\\n\\\\nThis section describes the sign offs required for a breaking change that has been approved but not yet communicated.\\\\r\\\\n| Sequence | Criteria | Owner | Guidance |\\\\r\\\\n|----------|----------|-------|----------|\\\\r\\\\n| 1 | Breaking change Request completed | Service Owner PM | \\u2022 Azure Dev Ops Intake for breaking changes (\\\\u003chttps://msazure.visualstudio.com/One/_workitems/create/Scenario?templateld=d1c215ec-5d6a-4cb3-a193-95ddd0a1ba96\\\\u0026ownerld=85bb92fb-21fe-41ca-9309-47f2c5f57515\\\\u003e) filed with business justification, details of the breaking change.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 Timing of the breaking change implementation. Adherence to the policy.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 Customer impact identified (Total customers, S500 Customer impact)\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 Migration plan documented. |\\\\r\\\\n| 2 | Breaking Change Approval | Azbreakchange review (Jeffrey Richter/Srikanth Mantha) | \\u2022 Sign off from the Breaking change review board for approval. API and SDK impacts also reviewed and signed off. |\\\\r\\\\n| 3 | Review draft for external communications | Laurel Martinez | \\u2022 Program Manager and assigned Azure PMM to create draft customer email based on MS DOC.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 Works with PM and Azure PMM to review draft email communication.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 If breaking change impacts over 20,000 subscription IDs and above. PM to create an email intake form (\\\\u003chttps://cxpservicecomms.azurewebsites.net/\\\\u003e). Send approved draft email to editorial team for review, follow by GM and two CVPs review. Please allow 2 to 4 weeks for this process to be completed. Once approved, send approved draft to Azure CXP email tool to schedule publication.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 If breaking change impacts fewer than 20,000 subscription IDs, PM to send approved draft to Azure CXP email tool (\\\\u003chttps://cxpservicecomms.azurewebsites.net/\\\\u003e).\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 PM to share approved email on Azure updates on ACOM |\\\\r\\\\n| 4 | Customer communication planned | Doug Miller | \\u2022 Customer communications planned and ready to send on pre described date. |\\\\r\\\\n| 5 | CVP Of the Group requesting the retirement/Breaking change | to Azure CXP email tool (\\\\u003chttps://cxpservicecomms.azurewebsites.net/\\\\u003e).\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 PM to share approved email on Azure updates on ACOM |\\\\r\\\\n| 4 | Customer Off.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 PM can also attach Email confirmation from CVP to the Sign off sheet. |\\\\r\\\\n| 6 | CSS Support readiness | Alex Lagerkrans-Pandey | \\u2022 CSS readiness with to being marked `@internal` is considered for internal use only and its API may change at any time.\\\\n\\\\nexports                           | \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"2\\\\\\\" and its API may change at any time. of TypeSpec [See working with template declarations](#working-with-template-declarations) meaning of the language. Changes to the formatting should be taken with consideration, as changes in formatting may introduce significant and unexpected differences in formatted output, but changes to the formatter output are not considered breaking changes for the purposes of issuing a major version change. |\\\\r\\\\n| TypeKits                                      | \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"0\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"success\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e | TypeKits are the recommend way to expose APIs from a library. TypeKits that are only available through experimental subpaths may be broken without a major version update, but TypeKits that are available by default may be considered highly stable.\\\\n\\\\n- \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"Tier 0\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"success\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e: These are stable core APIs and language features that\\\\r\\\\n  define fundamental semantics and will not be broken without a major version update. We recommend\\\\r\\\\n  that library authors depend on these APIs.\\\\r\\\\n- \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"Tier 1\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"caution\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e: These are APIs that have very limited use cases and may\\\\r\\\\n  be broken without a major version update. We recommend that library authors avoid depending on\\\\r\\\\n  these APIs.\\\\r\\\\n- \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"Tier 2\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"danger\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e: These are internal APIs intended only for use by the\\\\r\\\\n  TypeSpec compiler and core libraries. Tier 2 APIs may be changed without a a major version update\\\\r\\\\n  or even documentation of the change. Consuming these APIs is _at your own risk_!\\\\r\\\\n- \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"Tier 3\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"note\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e: These are APIs and language features that don't describe\\\\r\\\\n  semantically meaningful information, but provide information that emitters and libraries may\\\\r\\\\n  choose to use and may introduce changes in emitter output when the features are changed. For\\\\r\\\\n  example: formatting.\\\\r\\\\n| Example                                       | Tier                                 | Description\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| TypeKits                                      | \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"0\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"success\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e | TypeKits are the recommend way to expose APIs from a library. TypeKits that are only available through experimental subpaths may be broken without a major version update, but TypeKits that are available by default may be considered highly stable.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| Additional library helper functions           | \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"0\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"success\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e | Helper and metadata accessor functions exported from the public surface of the compiler or a TypeSpec library are generally considered stable unless otherwise specified or only exported through an experimental subpath.\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| TypeSpec AST (`Node`)                         | \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"1\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"caution\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e | The TypeSpec abstract syntax tree may change at any time. **Note**: this is not the same thing as the _type graph_ (`Type` and its variants), which is a \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"Tier 0\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"success\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e, stable feature; this only applies to `Node` and its variants. The only sanctioned reason for using the AST is for some syntax based linting rule or writing codefixes. Libraries depend on the abstract syntax tree _at their own risk_!                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         \\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-BreakingChanges.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Docs\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-BreakingChanges\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Docs\\\\n# Swagger-BreakingChanges.md\\\\n\\\\n# Docs\\\\n\\\\nhttps://aka.ms/CPEXBreakingChangesProcess\\\\r\\\\nhttps://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-brch-deep\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## 4. Notes\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 4. Notes\\\\n\\\\n- Please note the following are currently not in scope of the policy: non-Azure service changes; Email communication- template changes.\\\\r\\\\n- Currently in discussion: Compute policy related to breaking changes related to VMs/Hardware.\\\\r\\\\n- For Preview versions, leverage the following guidance:\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n\\\\nIn this section, we'll focus on implementing versioning in your REST API. Versioning allows you to manage changes to your API over time without breaking existing clients. We'll introduce the `@versioned` decorator, show how to define versions with enums, and demonstrate how to use the `@added` decorator to specify version-specific models and operations.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## 5. Azure Service Change Impact\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 5. Azure Service Change Impact\\\\n\\\\nconsidered breaking and must be avoided.\\\\r\\\\n- Changing a resource's schema (which spans all api-versions) must be taken with great care. Any new fields must be removed when responding to an old client. Also, old clients may update the resource which may delete fields added by a newer client. For version/state resiliency, we recommend using PATCH (with JSON merge patch) instead of PUT (\\\\u003chttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PFK6RRTwXCg\\\\u003e).\\\\r\\\\n- Changing a resource's field constraints is also problematic. For example: Changing a string's maximum length is a breaking change because a new client could set a long string and an old client can't get/set it back.\\\\n\\\\nThis document informs Azure service teams of the impact to customers when making service changes and versioning. For more information, please see this video (\\\\u003chttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bG984__6dSO\\\\u0026list=PL9XzOCngAkqs4m0XdULJu_78nM3Ok3Q65\\\\u0026index=14\\\\u003e).\\\\r\\\\nThe two tables below describe what kind of changes a service can make in a new api-version or after a breaking change review. The tables focus on service API contracts, are not exhaustive, and do not address service behavior changes.\\\\r\\\\nAzure requires that any API contract change requires a new api-version; some footnotes (below) allow a few exceptions here. Failure to change the service's API contract without a new api-version can cause confusion especially if the new features are not rolled out to all clouds before documented to users. Here are some examples that cause confusion (\\\\u003chttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bG984_L6dSO\\\\u0026list=PL9XzOCngAkqs4m0XdULJu_78nM3Ok3Q65\\\\u0026index=14\\\\u003e):\\\\r\\\\n- Customers can't tell from a specific api-version's documentation whether it includes a new feature or not.\\\\r\\\\n- Azure support can't know if an api-version honors a new feature or not to help customers.\\\\r\\\\n- Customers can tell if a version of an SDK client library supports a new feature or not.\\\\r\\\\nSome additional notes about the sections below:\\\\r\\\\n- Renaming a query parameter/header/field is equivalent to removing it and adding a new one. So, renames are always considered breaking and must be avoided.\\\\r\\\\n- Changing a resource's schema (which spans all api-versions) must be taken with great care. Any new fields must be removed when responding to an old client. Also, old clients may update the resource which may delete fields added by a newer client. For version/state resiliency, we recommend using PATCH (with JSON merge patch) instead of PUT (\\\\u003chttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PFK6RRTwXCg\\\\u003e).\\\\r\\\\n- Changing a resource's field constraints is also problematic.\\\\n\\\\n### Table 1: Changes requiring a new api-version of the service\\\\n\\\\n| Change | Why this change is non-breaking for old clients |\\\\r\\\\n|--------|------------------------------------------------|\\\\r\\\\n| Add an extensible enum (string) value | Clients see this as a string value. Docs for this property must indicate that previously undocumented values might be returned someday to old clients so customer code is written properly to deal with the unexpected new value |\\\\r\\\\n| Add optional input | Clients using older api-version never send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add optional output\\u00b9 | Clients using older api-version should never receive this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add required output | Clients using older api-version should never receive this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add new input-only enum value | Clients using older api-version never send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add body content-type (ex: application/json) | Clients using older api-version never send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add new path/operation\\u00b9 | Clients using older api-version never invoke this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add protocol (ex: http) | Clients using older api-version never use this |\\\\r\\\\n\\u00b9 Except for a nextLink property that enables pagination; See Table 2.\\\\n\\\\n### Table 2: Changes requiring a review with Azure's Breaking Change Review Board\\\\n\\\\nvalue |\\\\r\\\\n| Weaken output constraint (ex: max value 5 to 6) | Old client gets value it never expected |\\\\r\\\\n| Change default value | Old client doesn't expect new default behavior |\\\\r\\\\n| Change discriminator field value | Old client doesn't expect/send new value |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input parameter order in swagger | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameter order |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove body Content-Type (ex: application/json) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n| Add response code | Old client has no code to handle new response code |\\\\r\\\\n| Modify path/operation Id | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method name |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove protocol (ex: http) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n\\u00b2 Removing an extensible enum value typically happens when a service retires some feature (like a VM SKU). Retirements must be discussed with Azure Retirements Reviewers (\\\\u003chttps://dev.azure.com/msazure/AzureWiki/_wiki/wikis/AzureWiki.wiki/88597/Azure-Retirement-Policy-and-Process\\\\u003e). Based on the outcome this breaking change may be doable in a new api-version of the service. And, in some extreme cases, this breaking change may be doable in an existing api-version.\\\\n\\\\n**NOTE:** These changes are strongly discouraged:\\\\r\\\\n| Change | Why this change is breaking for old clients |\\\\r\\\\n|--------|---------------------------------------------|\\\\r\\\\n| Add pagination support | Old client expects response to include all results and will only ever see 1st page |\\\\r\\\\n| Add required input | Old client doesn't send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove input/output | Old client always sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add new output enum value | Old client will crash when deserializing |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove input/output enum value | Old client sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove extensible enum (string) value\\u00b2 | Old client sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input from optional to required | Old clients don't send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Change output from optional to required | New client doesn't expect nullable field (for some language SDKs) |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input/output required to optional | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameters |\\\\r\\\\n| Change case (ex: RBAC to Rbac) | Old client sends wrong case |\\\\r\\\\n| Change format (ex: minutes to time) | Old client can't parse new format |\\\\r\\\\n| Change data type (ex: bool to string) | Old client can't parse new type's value |\\\\r\\\\n| Widen input integer (ex: Int32 to Int64) | Old client doesn't expect larger value |\\\\r\\\\n| Widen output integer (ex: Int32 to Int64) | Old client loses precision |\\\\r\\\\n| Narrow input/output integer (ex: Int64 to Int32) | New service loses precision |\\\\r\\\\n| Strengthen input constraint (ex: max value 5 to 4) | Old client sends bigger value |\\\\r\\\\n| Weaken output constraint (ex: max value 5 to 6) | Old client gets value it never expected |\\\\r\\\\n| Change default value | Old client doesn't expect new default behavior |\\\\r\\\\n| Change discriminator field value | Old client doesn't expect/send new value |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input parameter order in swagger | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameter order |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove body Content-Type (ex: application/json) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n| Add response code |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi everyone, \\\\r\\\\nI am making a property optional in typespec and to be a non-breaking change, I see that is required to have a default. However my change seems to also change the existing version instead of only the new version. \\\\r\\\\nBefore:\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists: SubResource[]; \\\\r\\\\nAfter:\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v2025_10_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists?: SubResource[] = #[]; \\\\r\\\\n1) How can I make the change in typespec so that the generation of the openapi jsons will not affect the existing version? Currently generation also adds the empty array default to the existing API version (2025-05-01) which causes the breaking change CI to flag.\\\\r\\\\n2) Is there a way I can default the SubResource[] array to null instead? \\\\r\\\\nThis is in accordance to the documentation here (Made optional with/without default case): [non-breaking-versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-core/rules/non-breaking-versioning/#-incorrect)\\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Release 2025-10-01-preview for DNS Resolver by jamesvoongms \\u00b7 Pull Request #24470 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-res\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24470)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should not add OpenApi extensions directly - x-ms-identifiers are automatically added based on the `@key` properties of a model,  or you should use the `@identifiers` decorator if you need to override the default setting. \\\\r\\\\nThe problem is that this is two changes (making a property optional and providing a default), but there is only versioning decoration for one change.  Compounding this, there is no versioning decoration for adding a default value, this is being tracked here: [Add additional versioning decorators \\u00b7 Issue #2761 \\u00b7 microsoft/typespec](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues/2761).  Ideally we should combine these two changes into a single decorator to promote non-breaking changes. \\\\r\\\\nMeanwhile, you can do this using the added/removed/rename pattern to replace one property with another property in a new version, as this example.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldStuff: string[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  stuff?: string[] = #[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_resource_manager_rpc\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"v1.0#patch-resource.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Patch Resource #\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/patch-resource.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Patch Resource #\\\\n## Rules ##\\\\n### General impact of violating the rules ###\\\\n# v1.0#patch-resource.md\\\\n\\\\n# Patch Resource #\\\\n\\\\n## Rules ##\\\\n\\\\n### General impact of violating the rules ###\\\\n\\\\nProviding support for `Patch` for as many properties as possible helps avoid accidental and unintentional updates to other properties that need not be touched. Only the property set that really needs an update are specified in a `Patch` payload thereby limiting the surface area of any potential impact. Violating these rules result in APIs across Azure becoming inconsistent with each other. Such inconsistencies degrade customer experience as they now have to deal with slightly different behaviors while interacting with each Resource Provider. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n| RPC Guideline code | Title | Conformance level | Additional impact |  Applicable scope | Linter rule |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-01 | The request body **must** contain at least one or more properties. These properties must always be present in the request and response bodies of the corresponding put operation for same resource type. | Required | Not specifying any properties in the request body for a `Patch` operation serves no purpose for your customers. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-properties-correspond-to-put-properties.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-02 | A `Patch` operation must not update the `id`, `name`, `type`, `location`, or `properties.provisioningState` of the resource and so these properties must not be marked as updatable in the request body of the `Patch` operation. | Required | These properties are deemed either readOnly or immutable and therefore not updatable. These properties may be defined in the request body of the `Patch` operation and if so, they **must** be marked as readOnly or immutable as appropriate. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/un-supported-patch-properties.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-03 | Every **Tracked** resource type **must** support a **Patch** operation for the `tags` property. | Required |\\\\n\\\\nare deemed either readOnly or immutable and therefore not updatable. These properties may be defined in the request body of the `Patch` operation and if so, they **must** be marked as readOnly or immutable as appropriate. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/un-supported-patch-properties.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-03 | Every **Tracked** resource type **must** support a **Patch** operation for the `tags` property. | Required | ARM exposes a centralized API to customers that allow them to update the `tags` property for any tracked resource. The implementation in ARM relies on the existence of a `Patch` operation is the Resource provider service to accomplish this. The 201 response contains a `Location` LRO header.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op createOrUpdate is ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCreateOrUpdateAsync` is a PUT operation that uses the 'resource' definition in the request body, and returns a `200` response and a `201` response, both of which contain the created/updated resource in the response payload. The 201 response contains an `Azure-AsyncOperation` LRO header.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op createOrUpdate is ArmCreateOrUpdateAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async PATCH Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmTagsPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that only allows changing the resource tags (the minimum for Azure Resource Manager).\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmTagsPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourcePatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that uses the visibility settings to select properties for the PATCH request body (any property with no visibility setting, or including visibility \\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\"). It follows the required 202 pattern to resolve the LRO via location, although this can be customized using the `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, ResourceProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCustomPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that allows you to customize the PATCH request body.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, PatchRequestBody\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async POST (Action) Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceActionAsync` is a POST operation that allows you to specify the request and response body for a resource action operation.\\\\n\\\\nthe `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, ResourceProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCustomPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that allows you to customize the PATCH request body.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, PatchRequestBody\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async POST (Action) Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceActionAsync` is a POST operation that allows you to specify the request and response body for a resource action operation. It follows the required 202 pattern to resolve the LRO via location, although this can be customized using the `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuff is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, ActionRequest, ActionResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // With no request body\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuffNoRequest is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, void, ActionResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // With no response body\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuffCommand is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, ActionRequest, void\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async DELETE Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOKAsync` is a DELETE operation that uses no request body, will return a `202` response in the case of an asynchronous delete operation, and a `204` response in case the resource does not exist.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOKAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceDeleteAsync` is a DELETE operation that uses no request body, and returns a `200` response in the case of a successful synchronous delete, a `202` response in the case of an asynchronous delete operation, and a `204` response in case the resource does not exist.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op delete is ArmResourceDeleteAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"libraries#versioning#guide.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Tutorial\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/libraries/versioning/guide\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Tutorial\\\\n## Versioning APIs\\\\n# libraries#versioning#guide.md\\\\n\\\\n# Tutorial\\\\n\\\\n## Versioning APIs\\\\n\\\\nThe versioning library simplifies the process of versioning APIs. Let's start with a basic example. Assume we have a service with a single API that returns a list of widgets. We can define that API like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\nusing Rest;\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Contoso Widget Manager\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Contoso.WidgetManager;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@error\\\\r\\\\nmodel Error {\\\\r\\\\n  code: string;\\\\r\\\\n  message?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nop list(): Widget[] | Error;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNow, let's suppose that in version 2 of the service, we add a get operation to retrieve a single widget. We can add that like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1,\\\\r\\\\n  v2,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/widget\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop list(): Widget[] | Error;\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/widget/{id}\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop get(...Resource.KeysOf\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e): Widget | Error;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNow, let's suppose that in version 3 of the service, we realize that `name` is not accurate and that this field should be called `description`. Also, we decide that the description should be optional, not mandatory. We can implement these changes like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  widgetId: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v3, \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\n  description?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWe made the change to the actual model property so that it now reflects the correct name and optional nature of the property. Both the `@renamedFrom` and `@madeOptional` decorators indicate the version in which the change was made, and the `@renamedFrom` decorator also identifies the previous name of the property. This allows us to generate code that is aware of the change and can handle it appropriately.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI definition of `Widget` for version 3 reflects the change:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    description:\\\\n\\\\nname and optional nature of the property. Both the `@renamedFrom` and `@madeOptional` decorators indicate the version in which the change was made, and the `@renamedFrom` decorator also identifies the previous name of the property. This allows us to generate code that is aware of the change and can handle it appropriately.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI definition of `Widget` for version 3 reflects the change:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    description:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - id\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nHowever, the OpenAPI definition for versions 1 and 2 still reflect the original name and the mandatory nature of the property:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    name:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - id\\\\r\\\\n    - name\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis is a common pattern with the versioning decorators. The TypeSpec should represent the _current state_ of the API. The decorators indicate the version at which this definition became accurate and, depending on the decorator, the other parameters reflect the previous values to retain that information.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#resource-operations.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"ARM Resource Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/resource-operations\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# ARM Resource Operations\\\\n## TypeSpec Operation Templates and Interface Templates\\\\n### Determining Which Resource Properties Appear in Lifecycle Operations\\\\n# howtos#arm#resource-operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# ARM Resource Operations\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec Operation Templates and Interface Templates\\\\n\\\\n### Determining Which Resource Properties Appear in Lifecycle Operations\\\\n\\\\nBy default, any property that occurs in your resource model will also appear in the response to GET,\\\\r\\\\nPUT, PATCH, and LIST operations, and in the request for PUT and PATCH operations. This does not work\\\\r\\\\nfor all properties. Some properties are calculated by the service and cannot be directly set by PUT\\\\r\\\\nor PATCH (provisioningState, modification date, etc.). Some properties can only be set when creating\\\\r\\\\na resource, but always appear in responses (e.g. 'location'). Some properties can only be set when\\\\r\\\\nupdating the resource, and appear in responses. Some properties (rarely) may be settable when\\\\r\\\\nupdating the resource via PUT or PATCH. To allow using a common resource model, but applying these\\\\r\\\\n`views` of resources to determine how the resource appear in request and responses, TypeSpec\\\\r\\\\nprovides the visibility framework. You can see a complete representation of available visibilities\\\\r\\\\nin the table\\\\r\\\\n[on Property Visibility and Other Constraints](./resource-type.md#property-visibility-and-other-constraints).\\\\r\\\\nThe sections below outline some common scenarios for designing properties with your operations in\\\\r\\\\nmind.\\\\r\\\\n#### Properties That Are Never Directly Set by the User\\\\r\\\\nIt is common to have properties that are calculated by the service or otherwise not directly set by\\\\r\\\\nthe user, examples include timestamps, dates, values that are only set by specific actions (on/off,\\\\r\\\\nenabled/disabled, provisioningState). You want to make sure that these properties are marked so that\\\\r\\\\nthey will appear in responses and not requests. this is done using the `@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)`\\\\r\\\\ndecorator instance:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\nprovisioningState: ProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"}]\"}"}]

response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"1. Removal of a readonly field like 'provisioningState' from the PATCH operation model (e.g., ConfigurationPropertiesUpdate) is NOT a breaking change and should NOT be flagged as such. According to Azure and ARM guidelines, properties that are calculated by the service and marked as readonly (such as provisioningState) should only appear in response models, not in request models for PUT/PATCH. The PATCH request body should only include properties that are updatable by the client. If your PATCH model omits provisioningState, this is correct and compliant with best practices. If the breaking change tooling flags this as a removal, it is a false positive and can be safely ignored or suppressed with justification.\\n\\n2. Changing CUD (Create, Update, Delete) operations to be Long Running Operations (LROs) in a new API version is allowed and is NOT a breaking change for previous versions. The correct approach is:\\n- Introduce the LRO pattern (e.g., 202/202+Location/Azure-AsyncOperation headers) only in the new API version.\\n- Do NOT change the behavior of existing API versions; they must remain synchronous if they were previously synchronous.\\n- Use TypeSpec ARM templates such as ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync, ArmResourcePatchAsync, ArmResourceDeleteAsync for the new version, and keep the old version using the synchronous templates.\\n- If the operation signature changes (e.g., request/response body), use the @added/@removed decorators to version the operations and models accordingly.\\n- If you need to support both synchronous and asynchronous behavior in the same API version (based on customer input), you must clearly document the behavior and ensure the OpenAPI spec reflects the possible status codes and headers.\\n\\nSummary: For PATCH, readonly fields should not be present in the request model. For LRO, only introduce the async pattern in the new API version, and keep old versions unchanged. Use TypeSpec versioning decorators and ARM templates to ensure correct separation and avoid breaking changes.\", \"ground_truth\": \"The 'provisioningState' change in the PATCH request model seems like a bug fix if this field was always read-only.  When you get a breaking change review, if this is explained with an appropriate comment, this is likely to be justified as a bug fix.\\nOn changing PATCH to synchronous.  ARM does support async PATCH operations, although REST API Guidelines discourage async PATCH operations.  If this operation is synchronous in the previous stable version, then this change is a real breaking change that you will need to justify in breaking change review.\\nSimilarly, making PUT and DELETE Asynchronous is a breaking change if these operations were synchronous in the previous stable version is a real breaking change, and you will need to justify the change in a breaking change review.\"}"}]

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: What decorator should be used in this case?\\n\\nquestion: Hi team,\\nIn version v2, we introduced a new model model2 and updated featureA (originally added in v1) to use model2 as its parameter. In v1, featureA used model1 at the same position.\\nHere\\u2019s the setup I tried (using @typeChangedFrom):\\n```\\n@added(v1)\\nmodel1;\\n@added(v2)\\nmodel2;\\n@added(v1)\\nfeatureA {\\n@typeChangedFrom(v1, model1)\\nbody: model2;\\n}\\n```\\nHowever, this shows the error: \\\"model2 does not exist in v1\\\".\\nWhat would be the correct decorator to use in this situation?\\nThank you!\", \"response\": \"The correct usage of the @typeChangedFrom decorator is to specify the version in which the change occurs, not the version from which the new type is introduced. In your scenario, you should use @typeChangedFrom(v2, model1) on the property, not @typeChangedFrom(v1, model1). This tells TypeSpec that starting from v2, the type of 'body' changed from model1 (which existed in v1) to model2 (introduced in v2). The error occurs because your original usage implies model2 existed in v1, which is not the case.\\n\\nHere is the corrected TypeSpec code:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@added(v1)\\nmodel1;\\n\\n@added(v2)\\nmodel2;\\n\\n@added(v1)\\nfeatureA {\\n  @typeChangedFrom(v2, model1)\\n  body: model2;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis approach follows TypeSpec versioning best practices and ensures the correct evolution of your API signature across versions.\", \"ground_truth\": \"it should be `typedChangedFrom(v2, model1)` here otherwise you are saying in v1 you changed from using model1 to model2 which then of course doesn't exists\"}"}]

As the augment decorator is a statement, it must end with a semicolon (`;`).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {}\\\\r\\\\n@@tag(Dog, \\\\\\\"Sample\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis is equivalent to:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@tag(\\\\\\\"Sample\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nExample: decorating a model property to indicate that it is read-only\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@@visibility(Dog.name, Lifecycle.Read);\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n### Adding Decoration to an Existing Type\\\\n# howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n\\\\n### Adding Decoration to an Existing Type\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario demonstrates how to change a decorator\\u2019s usage across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you have a model property with a decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the next version (v2), the visibility changes so that the property can be read or created. To achieve this, you can use a combination of `@removed`, `@added`, and `@renamedFrom` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"experience\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldExperience: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read, Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Using the `@added` Decorator\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Using the `@added` Decorator\\\\n\\\\nThe [`@added`](../../../libraries/versioning/reference/decorators/#@TypeSpec.Versioning.added) decorator is used to indicate that a model or operation was added in a specific version of the API. This allows you to manage changes and additions to your API over time.\\\\n\\\\n### Example: Adding a New Model in a Specific Version\\\\n\\\\nLet's add a `Toy` model that is only available in version 2 of the API:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp title=main.tsp tryit=\\\\\\\"{\\\\\\\"emit\\\\\\\": [\\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\"]}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Pet Store\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\\\\"https://example.com\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Single server endpoint\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace PetStore;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1: \\\\\\\"1.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2: \\\\\\\"2.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  @minLength(1)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @minValue(0)\\\\r\\\\n  @maxValue(100)\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  kind: petType;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nenum petType {\\\\r\\\\n  dog: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  cat: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  fish: \\\\\\\"fish\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  bird: \\\\\\\"bird\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  reptile: \\\\\\\"reptile\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-start\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Toy {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example:\\\\r\\\\n- The `Toy` model is defined with the `@added(Versions.v2)` decorator to indicate that it was added in version 2 of the API.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n# howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n\\\\nThese examples show how to add models, operations, properties, and parameters in specific versions using TypeSpec versioning decorators.\\\\n\\\\n### Adding Decoration to an Existing Type\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario demonstrates how to change a decorator\\u2019s usage across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you have a model property with a decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the next version (v2), the visibility changes so that the property can be read or created. To achieve this, you can use a combination of `@removed`, `@added`, and `@renamedFrom` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"experience\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldExperience: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read, Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Adding a Parameter to an Operation and Making Another Parameter Optional\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario shows how to add a parameter and make another optional in an operation.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you start with the following operation in v1:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n      @header\\\\r\\\\n      location: string;\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn version `v2`, you want to:\\\\r\\\\n- Make the `location` header parameter optional.\\\\r\\\\n- Add a new optional query parameter `orderBy`.\\\\r\\\\nYou can achieve this using the `@madeOptional` and `@added` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n      @madeOptional(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n      @header\\\\r\\\\n      location?: string;\\\\r\\\\n      @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n      @query(\\\\\\\"order-by\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n      orderBy?: string;\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Explanation:**\\\\r\\\\n- `@madeOptional(Versions.v2)` makes `location` optional starting in v2.\\\\r\\\\n- `@added(Versions.v2)` adds the `orderBy` query parameter in v2 and later.\\\\n\\\\n### Converting an Operation from Synchronous to Asynchronous\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario illustrates converting a synchronous operation to an asynchronous one across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you start with the following synchronous operation in `v1`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn version `v2`, you update this operation to be asynchronous as follows:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"createOrUpdate\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdateV1 is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Explanation:**\\\\r\\\\n- `@removed(Versions.v2)` removes the original synchronous operation in v2 and later.\\\\r\\\\n- `@renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"createOrUpdate\\\\\\\")` keeps the original name for v1.\\\\r\\\\n- `@added(Versions.v2)` adds the new asynchronous operation in v2 and later.\\\\r\\\\n- `@sharedRoute` ensures both operations can use the same route.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#05-authentication.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Authentication\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/05-authentication\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Introduction to the `@versioned` Decorator\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Introduction to the `@versioned` Decorator\\\\n\\\\nThe [`@versioned`](../../../libraries/versioning/reference/decorators/#@TypeSpec.Versioning.versioned) decorator is used to define different versions of your API. This decorator allows you to specify the versions that your API supports and manage changes across these versions.\\\\n\\\\n### Example: Defining API Versions\\\\n\\\\nLet's define two versions of our API, `v1` and `v2`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp title=main.tsp tryit=\\\\\\\"{\\\\\\\"emit\\\\\\\": [\\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\"]}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Pet Store\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\\\\"https://example.com\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Single server endpoint\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace PetStore;\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-start\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1: \\\\\\\"1.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2: \\\\\\\"2.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example:\\\\r\\\\n- We're importing and using a new module, `@typespec/versioning`, which provides versioning support.\\\\r\\\\n- The `@versioned` decorator is used to define the versions supported by the API, defined in the `Versions` enum.\\\\r\\\\n- The `Versions` enum specifies two versions: `v1` (1.0) and `v2` (2.0).\\\\n\\\\n### Generating OpenAPI Specifications for Different Versions\\\\n\\\\nOnce versions are added, the TypeSpec compiler generates individual OpenAPI specifications for each version.\\\\r\\\\n{/* prettier-ignore */}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cFileTree\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n- main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n- tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n- package.json\\\\r\\\\n- node_modules/\\\\r\\\\n- tsp-output/\\\\r\\\\n  - @typespec/\\\\r\\\\n    - openapi3\\\\r\\\\n      - openapi.1.0.yaml\\\\r\\\\n      - openapi.2.0.yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/FileTree\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\nGenerating separate specs for each version ensures backward compatibility, provides clear documentation for developers to understand differences between versions, and simplifies maintenance by allowing independent updates to each version's specifications.\\\\r\\\\nBy encapsulating different versions of the API within the context of the same TypeSpec project, we can manage all versions in a unified manner. This approach makes it easier to maintain consistency, apply updates, and ensure that all versions are properly documented and aligned with the overall API strategy.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Adding the Versioning Library\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Adding the Versioning Library\\\\n\\\\nBefore we can use the versioning decorators, we need to add the `@typespec/versioning` library to our project. This involves updating the `package.json` file and installing the necessary dependencies.\\\\n\\\\n### Step 1: Update `package.json`\\\\n\\\\nAdd the `@typespec/versioning` library to your `package.json` file, in both the `peerDependencies` and `devDependencies` sections. Your updated `package.json` should look like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"typespec-petstore\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    // highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"devDependencies\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/compiler\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    // highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"private\\\\\\\": true\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Step 2: Install Dependencies\\\\n\\\\nRun the following command to install the new dependencies:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`sh\\\\r\\\\ntsp
