...\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`go\\\\r\\\\n// NOT_SUPPORTED\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/ClientTabs\\\\u003e\\\\n\\\\nIn ARM services, `subscriptionId` is automatically elevated to the client level. By applying `@clientLocation` to `subscriptionId` and explicitly moving it to an operation, you can move it back down to the method-level.\\\\r\\\\nIn the following case, since all instances of the subscription ID parameter have been explicitly moved onto the method-level, there is no longer a subscription ID parameter to the client.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cClientTabs\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec title=\\\\\\\"main.tsp\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n@service\\\\r\\\\n@armProviderNamespace\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\n@armCommonTypesVersion(CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.ContosoProviderHub;\\\\r\\\\n/** Api versions */\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  /** 2024-04-01-preview api version */\\\\r\\\\n  V2024_04_01_PREVIEW: operation `get`\\\\r\\\\n@@clientLocation(CommonTypes.SubscriptionIdParameter.subscriptionId, get);\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n// Since Customizing operations with traits\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/azure-core/step08\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# 8. Customizing operations with traits\\\\n## Customizing the API version parameter\\\\n# getstarted#azure-core#step08.md\\\\n\\\\n# 8. Customizing operations with traits\\\\n\\\\n## Customizing the API version parameter\\\\n\\\\nYou can use the `VersionParameterTrait` to customize the API version parameter for resource operations, either at the level of interface or individual operation. To do this, use the `TraitOverride` type to override the existing `api-version` query parameter:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n/** The ApiVersion path parameter. */\\\\r\\\\nmodel ApiVersionPathParameter {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The API version to use for this operation. */\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"api\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @path(\\\\\\\"api-version\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  apiVersion: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nop deleteWidget is ResourceDelete\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n  Widget,\\\\r\\\\n  TraitOverride\\\\u003cVersionParameterTrait\\\\u003cApiVersionPathParameter\\\\u003e\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nUsing the `TraitOverride` modifier with the `VersionParameterTrait\\\\u003cApiVersionPathParameter\\\\u003e` causes any existing `VersionParameterTrait` instances in the operation signature to be overridden by the one you have supplied.\\\\r\\\\nThis will result in an operation that has the route path `/api/{apiVersion}/widgets/{widgetName}` while also removing the old `api-version` query parameter from the operation signature.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi Team, \\\\r\\\\nI am releasing a new API version and looks there is a new validation to check existing swagger with new tsp file  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\\\\\" \\\\r\\\\nWe want to keep both old and new api versoins. What is the suggestion here? Do you suggest to create different TSP file for each version/use versioning in existing TSP?  \\\\r\\\\nIf second case, can you share some example where APIs/Properties are added/removed in a newer version\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe idea behind TypeSpec versioning is to model the diffs in your API, encouraging best practices for API evolution. If you have questions about modeling particular changes, feel free to ask.\\\\r\\\\nAbout your concern: fixing a new validation causing changes to older APIs\\u2014this usually happens when new changes are added without using the appropriate version decorators. For example:\\\\r\\\\nIf you added properties or made a property optional, but didn\\u2019t annotate them with @added or @madeOptional, then they would apply to all versions by default, including older ones.\\\\r\\\\nThat\\u2019s likely why your stable version (e.g., 2024-12-01) got unintentionally updated when you only meant to target 2025-07-01-preview.\\\\r\\\\nTo avoid this, always use decorators like @added and @madeOptional to indicate version-specific changes.\\\\r\\\\nAs for the location field and the read/create mutability warning:\\\\r\\\\nThat rule is a warning meant to be advisory. In your case, it doesn\\u2019t seem to apply\\u2014so this is a good example where you should not change the service behavior just to satisfy a linting rule. It's fine to ignore the warning here.\\\\r\\\\nRegarding your question on renaming an API response (e.g., from MoveResponse to MoveResult):\\\\r\\\\nIf the new name is meant for a specific version, ensure it\\u2019s versioned properly in your TypeSpec. In your repro, the naming appears correct\\u2014MoveResult in 2021-10-01-preview, and MoveResponse in 2024-10-01-preview\\u2014so it\\u2019s working as expected.\\\\r\\\\nFinally, for adding or removing a parameter in only the new version:\\\\r\\\\nUnfortunately, you can\\u2019t directly decorate a spread parameter. The best way is to use operation-specific parameters, which you can decorate with versioning decorators. You could alternatively decorate the core parameter definition (e.g., with an augment decorator), but that would affect every usage\\u2014so for localized changes, use operation-specific ones. Since this is a method parameter, the APIs are equivalent and the change has no SDK impact.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"How to update any model without affecting old API versions\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to update any model without affecting old API versions\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to update any model without affecting old API versions\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi team,  \\\\r\\\\nI have a model in the v2_preview version, and now with the new v3_preview version, I want to update a pattern and add some additional fields. Could anyone advise on the best approach to make these updates in the new version without impacting the old version? \\\\r\\\\nExample:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nOLD:\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"The Branch resource type.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Neon.Postgres.Versions.v2_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(Project)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Branch is ProxyResource\\\\u003cBranchProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Resource = Branch,\\\\r\\\\n    KeyName = \\\\\\\"branchName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    SegmentName = \\\\\\\"branches\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    NamePattern = \\\\\\\"^\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S.{0,62}\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S$|^\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S$\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nUpdated:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"The Branch resource type.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Neon.Postgres.Versions.v2_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(Project)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Branch is ProxyResource\\\\u003cBranchProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Resource = Branch,\\\\r\\\\n    KeyName = \\\\\\\"branchName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    SegmentName = \\\\\\\"branches\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003cspan style=\\\\\\\"background-color:#DF9299\\\\\\\"\\\\u003eNamePattern = \\\\u003c/span\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"\\\\u003cspan style=\\\\\\\"background-color:#DF9299\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e^\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S.{0,126}\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S$|^\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S$\\\\u003c/span\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nTo update a model in a new API version without affecting the old one, especially when changing a pattern or adding fields, the challenge is that decorator contents (like NamePattern) are not versioned in TypeSpec. So, modifying them directly will affect all versions.\\\\r\\\\nThere are two main approaches:\\\\r\\\\nWorkaround with a new model: You can create a new model with a different name and use @renamedFrom, but this leads to a cascade of renames across operations, which is not ideal.\\\\r\\\\nApply the change across all versions: If the new regex is backwards compatible, and the change reflects how the service actually behaves across all versions, then it\\u2019s appropriate to update the existing model and apply the change to all API versions. This avoids inconsistencies and unnecessary duplication.\\\\r\\\\nIn practice, name validation changes usually apply across all versions, so updating the shared model is acceptable. Just be aware that this may be considered a breaking change depending on your service\\u2019s governance, and you might need approval.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getstarted#azure-core#step09.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"9. Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/azure-core/step09\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# 9. Versioning\\\\n## Versioning your service\\\\n# getstarted#azure-core#step09.md\\\\n\\\\n# 9. Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Versioning your service\\\\n\\\\nthe `Versions` enum:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nYou will also need to add the `@useDependency` decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nFinally, you can express changes to your service using the `@added` and `@removed` decorators. Here's an example of adding a new property to `Widget` and removing an old one:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n/** A widget. */\\\\r\\\\n@resource(\\\\\\\"widgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget name. */\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"widgetName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget color. */\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions.v2022_11_30)\\\\r\\\\n  color: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The ID of the widget's manufacturer. */\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions.v2022_11_30)\\\\r\\\\n  manufacturerId: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e You can do a lot more with versioning decorators, so consult the `typespec-versioning` [README.md](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/tree/main/packages/versioning#enable-versioning-for-service-or-library) for more information on how you can use them to annotate your service and describe changes between different versions.\\\\n\\\\nIt is inevitable that service specifications will change over time. It is a best practice to add versioning support to your specification from the first version. To do that, you will need to define an `enum` containing your service versions and then apply the `@versioned` decorator to your service namespace.\\\\r\\\\nHere is an example for the `WidgetManager` service:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Contoso Widget Manager\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Contoso.WidgetManager;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThere are a few things to point out here:\\\\r\\\\n- We define an `enum` called `Versions` inside of the service namespace. For each service version, we map a version symbol like `v2022_08_31` to a version string like `2022-08-31`. This service currently only has a single version, but we can add more to this enum as things change over time.\\\\r\\\\n- We add the `@versioned` decorator and reference the `Versions` enum we defined using the fully-qualified name `Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions`. This marks the service as being versioned and specifies the set of versions.\\\\r\\\\n- We change the `@useDependency` decorator we used previously to now link each service version to a specific version of `Azure.Core`. See the [Using Azure.Core Versions](#using-azurecore-versions) section for more information.\\\\r\\\\nImagine that it's 3 months later and you want to release a new version of your service with some slight changes. Add a new version to the `Versions` enum:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nYou will also need to add the `@useDependency` decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nFinally, you can express changes to your service using the `@added` and `@removed` decorators. Here's an example of adding a new property to `Widget` and removing an old one:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n/** A widget. */\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_http_specs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"versioning#returntypechangedfrom#main.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Usages for Test for the `@returnTypeChangedFrom` decorator.\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/tree/main/packages/http-specs/specs/versioning/returntypechangedfrom/main.tsp\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Usages for Test for the `@returnTypeChangedFrom` decorator.\\\\n## Scenario: This operation should be generated with latest version's signature.\\\\n# versioning#returntypechangedfrom#main.md\\\\n\\\\n# Usages for Test for the `@returnTypeChangedFrom` decorator.\\\\n\\\\n## Scenario: This operation should be generated with latest version's signature.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/test\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@post\\\\r\\\\n@returnTypeChangedFrom(\\\\r\\\\n  Versions.v2,\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    @header\\\\r\\\\n    contentType: \\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    @body\\\\r\\\\n    body: int32,\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nop test(@header contentType: \\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\", @body body: string): {\\\\r\\\\n  @header\\\\r\\\\n  contentType: \\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  @body\\\\r\\\\n  body: string;\\\\r\\\\n};\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"libraries#versioning#guide.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Tutorial\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/libraries/versioning/guide\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Tutorial\\\\n## Versioning APIs\\\\n# libraries#versioning#guide.md\\\\n\\\\n# Tutorial\\\\n\\\\n## Versioning APIs\\\\n\\\\nThe versioning library simplifies the process of versioning APIs. Let's start with a basic example. Assume we have a service with a single API that returns a list of widgets. We can define that API like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\nusing Rest;\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Contoso Widget Manager\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Contoso.WidgetManager;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@error\\\\r\\\\nmodel Error {\\\\r\\\\n  code: string;\\\\r\\\\n  message?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nop list(): Widget[] | Error;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNow, let's suppose that in version 2 of the service, we add a get operation to retrieve a single widget. We can add that like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1,\\\\r\\\\n  v2,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/widget\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop list(): Widget[] | Error;\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/widget/{id}\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop get(...Resource.KeysOf\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e): Widget | Error;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNow, let's suppose that in version 3 of the service, we realize that `name` is not accurate and that this field should be called `description`. Also, we decide that the description should be optional, not mandatory. We can implement these changes like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  widgetId: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v3, \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\n  description?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWe made the change to the actual model property so that it now reflects the correct name and optional nature of the property. Both the `@renamedFrom` and `@madeOptional` decorators indicate the version in which the change was made, and the `@renamedFrom` decorator also identifies the previous name of the property. This allows us to generate code that is aware of the change and can handle it appropriately.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI definition of `Widget` for version 3 reflects the change:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    description:\\\\n\\\\nname and optional nature of the property. Both the `@renamedFrom` and `@madeOptional` decorators indicate the version in which the change was made, and the `@renamedFrom` decorator also identifies the previous name of the property. This allows us to generate code that is aware of the change and can handle it appropriately.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI definition of `Widget` for version 3 reflects the change:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    description:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - id\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nHowever, the OpenAPI definition for versions 1 and 2 still reflect the original name and the mandatory nature of the property:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    name:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - id\\\\r\\\\n    - name\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis is a common pattern with the versioning decorators. The TypeSpec should represent the _current state_ of the API. The decorators indicate the version at which this definition became accurate and, depending on the decorator, the other parameters reflect the previous values to retain that information.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What decorator should be used in this case?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What decorator should be used in this case?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# What decorator should be used in this case?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi team, \\\\r\\\\nIn version v2, we introduced a new model model2 and updated featureA (originally added in v1) to use model2 as its parameter. In v1, featureA used model1 at the same position. \\\\r\\\\nHere\\u2019s the setup I tried (using @typeChangedFrom):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@added(v1)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel1;  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(v2)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel2;  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(v1)  \\\\r\\\\nfeatureA {  \\\\r\\\\n  @typeChangedFrom(v1, model1)  \\\\r\\\\n  body: model2;  \\\\r\\\\n} \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nHowever, this shows the error: \\\\\\\"model2 does not exist in v1\\\\\\\". \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the correct decorator to use in this situation? \\\\r\\\\nThank you!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nit should be `typedChangedFrom(v2, model1` here otherwise you are saying in v1 you changed from using model1 to model2 which then of course doesn't Sample:\\\\n\\\\n// main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\nusing TypeSpec.Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n/**\\\\r\\\\n * Test for the `@returnTypeChangedFrom` decorator.\\\\r\\\\n */\\\\r\\\\n@service\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"{endpoint}/versioning/return-type-changed-from/api-version:{version}\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"Testserver endpoint\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    /**\\\\r\\\\n     * Need to be set as 'http://localhost:3000' in client.\\\\r\\\\n     */\\\\r\\\\n    endpoint: url,\\\\r\\\\n    /**\\\\r\\\\n     * Need to be set as 'v1' or 'v2' in client.\\\\r\\\\n     */\\\\r\\\\n    version: Versions,\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Versioning.ReturnTypeChangedFrom;\\\\r\\\\n/**\\\\r\\\\n * The version of the API.\\\\r\\\\n */\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The version v1.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  v1: \\\\\\\"v1\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The version v2.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  v2: \\\\\\\"v2\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/test\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@post\\\\r\\\\n@returnTypeChangedFrom(\\\\r\\\\n  Versions.v2,\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n string;\\\\r\\\\n};\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Can we reorder the API versions like this, and should we remove the older preview version?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Can we reorder the API versions like this, and should we remove the older preview version?\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Can we reorder the API versions like this, and should we remove the older preview version?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi team, \\\\r\\\\nWe are adding 2025-11-01 GA and 2025-11-15-preview in TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\nFor 2025-11-01 GA:\\\\r\\\\nAdds new features feature1, feature2 compared to the last GA (2023-04-15)\\\\r\\\\nAdds new models model1, model2 compared to the last GA (2023-04-15)\\\\r\\\\nFor 2025-05-15-preview (older preview):\\\\r\\\\nAlready contains feature1, feature2, plus feature3, feature4 (which we do not want to expose in 2025-11-01 GA)\\\\r\\\\nContains models model1p, model2p (corresponding to model1, model2 but with different names) and model3p, model4p (which we also do not want to expose in 2025-11-01 GA)\\\\r\\\\nFor 2025-11-15-preview (new preview):\\\\r\\\\nShould align naming with 2025-11-01 GA\\\\r\\\\nIncludes feature1, feature2, feature3, feature4\\\\r\\\\nIncludes model1, model2, model3p, model4p\\\\r\\\\nTo simplify in TypeSpec, I think the easiest approach is to place GA versions together, since between GA releases we only need @added. Otherwise, we\\u2019d have to @remove from the older preview and then @add the not-exposed features/models again in the new preview.\\\\r\\\\nSo can we order the versions in enum Versions like:\\\\r\\\\n2023-04-15, 2025-11-01, 2025-05-15-preview, 2025-11-15-preview\\\\r\\\\nThis way, feature/model additions and renamings are handled more straightforwardly. \\\\r\\\\nOne more question: should we remove the older preview once we add a newer preview? For example, in this case, would we remove 2025-05-15-preview, keeping only 2023-04-15, 2025-11-01, and 2025-11-15-preview?\\\\r\\\\nThank you so much!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nthe current policy is to have a single preview version for Azure services. So removing the old preview and replacing the new one is the correct approach. However I do think you'll also need to delete the swagger for the CI to pass\\\"}]\"}"}]

response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"The correct usage of the @typeChangedFrom decorator is to specify the version in which the change occurs, not the version from which the new type is introduced. In your scenario, you should use @typeChangedFrom(v2, model1) on the property, not @typeChangedFrom(v1, model1). This tells TypeSpec that starting from v2, the type of 'body' changed from model1 (which existed in v1) to model2 (introduced in v2). The error occurs because your original usage implies model2 existed in v1, which is not the case.\\n\\nHere is the corrected TypeSpec code:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@added(v1)\\nmodel1;\\n\\n@added(v2)\\nmodel2;\\n\\n@added(v1)\\nfeatureA {\\n  @typeChangedFrom(v2, model1)\\n  body: model2;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis approach follows TypeSpec versioning best practices and ensures the correct evolution of your API signature across versions.\", \"ground_truth\": \"it should be `typedChangedFrom(v2, model1)` here otherwise you are saying in v1 you changed from using model1 to model2 which then of course doesn't exists\"}"}]

Hi team, could someone please help grant me permission to view the workflow for my Azure REST API PR?

actual.answer:
To gain visibility into the workflow and validation check details for your Azure REST API PR, you need to have the appropriate permissions. Specifically, you must:

1. Ensure your membership in the Azure GitHub organization is set to public (not private).
2. Request access via https://aka.ms/azsdk/access if you do not already have it.

Once these steps are completed, you should be able to view the workflow logs and validation errors for your PR before it is reviewed. This will allow you to debug and verify your changes ahead of time.

Is TypeSpec migration complete for folder: recoveryservicesbackup.

Output folder 'ContentUnderstanding' appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?

actual.answer: The addition of the service-under-conversion label to your stable API PR does not indicate a delay in merging your PR, nor does it require you to make additional changes solely because of the label. If your stable API PR represents a later API version than the conversion PR, the TypeSpec migration will typically be based on the latest checked-in version. The label is primarily for tracking and awareness during the migration process, not for blocking or requiring changes to your PR. You should proceed as usual, ensuring your PR meets all standard requirements for merging.

Adding Janine Zhang for awareness about the conversion.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#reproducibility.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Reproducibility\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/reproducibility\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Reproducibility\\\\n# handbook#reproducibility.md\\\\n\\\\n# Reproducibility\\\\n\\\\nA crucial aspect of service definition is ensuring consistent output over time. This is important in scenarios such as:\\\\r\\\\n- An update to a dependency or sub-dependency introduces an unexpected breaking change.\\\\r\\\\n- Updates to a new version of a service should not impact older versions.\\\\r\\\\n- Modifications are made to the TypeSpec specification.\\\\r\\\\nThese issues can be mitigated with a few precautionary measures:\\\\n\\\\n## 1. Defend against dependency changes\\\\n\\\\n_Note: This section applies if using `tsp install` or `npm install` to install dependencies. However other package managers (`yarn`, `pnpm`, etc.) have their own similar lock mechanisms._\\\\r\\\\nWhen using `tsp install` or `npm install` a `package-lock.json` will be installed. This file SHOULD be committed to source control. It will ensure that later calls to `tsp install` or `npm install` will use the exact versions resolved in the lock files unless the `package.json` was updated or a command like `npm update` was run.\\\\r\\\\nThe command `npm ci` can also be used in the CI to ensure that the `package.json` and `package-lock.json` are in sync.\\\\n\\\\n## 2. Work with multiple versions of a service\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec provides a library `@typespec/versioning` that can be used to describe changes to a service or library over time. Using this will ensure that a service can evolve while keeping track of the changes and allowing emitters to see the service representation at different versions.\\\\r\\\\n[See versioning docs](../libraries/versioning/reference/index.mdx)\\\\n\\\\n## 3. Change to the TypeSpec spec\\\\n\\\\nIf you don't directly control the spec, you might still want to make sure you remember which exact definition was used.\\\\r\\\\nUsing version control and pinning to a specific commit SHA will ensure that the spec will remain exactly as it was.\\\\n\\\\n## Summary\\\\n\\\\n1. Use `package-lock.json`\\\\r\\\\n2. Use [versioning library](../libraries/versioning/reference/index.mdx)\\\\r\\\\n3. Keep track of commit IDs\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_migration_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec-migration-docs-2025-09-05.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Extra Change(Cross-Version) failure\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe have the [PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22834) to introduce new API version with new features for existing RP. The [Breaking Changes(Cross-Version) detected problems](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22834/checks?check_run_id=43004413278). How to fix it?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIt depends.  Even across versions, some changes are discouraged/disallowed.  If the breaking changes reported in your PR are all intentional, then you just need to follow the instructions in the \\\\\\\"next steps to merge\\\\\\\" comment to work with the breaking changes board for approval: https://aka.ms/brch\\\\r\\\\nGenerally, breaking changes between preview api-versions are allowed if there are good reasons,  breaking changes relative to a stable api-version are more of a concern.  Also, if preview api-versions are old enough, they count as stable api-versions (I doubt that is the case here).\\\\r\\\\nThe case here is a preview with breaking changes relative to the last stable. And in this case, making a property optional would be considered breaking if the property occurs in responses.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#07-custom-response-models.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Custom Response Models\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/07-custom-response-models\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Custom Response Models\\\\n## Conclusion\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#07-custom-response-models.md\\\\n\\\\n# Custom Response Models\\\\n\\\\n## Conclusion\\\\n\\\\nIn this section, we focused on creating custom response models in your REST API. By defining and extending custom response models, we can reduce duplication, improve readability, and minimize errors in our API responses. Developers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/typespec-for-openapi-dev\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n## Consumes / Produces (OAS2)\\\\n# getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n\\\\n## Consumes / Produces (OAS2)\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI v2, the top-level `consumes` and `produces` fields specify a list of MIME types an operation can consume / produce\\\\r\\\\nwhen not overridden by a `consumes` or `produces` on an individual operation.\\\\r\\\\nThe typespec-autorest emitter previously supported `@produces` and `@consumes` decorators on a namespace, but these are deprecated\\\\r\\\\nin favor of explicit `content-type` and `accept` header properties in request and response bodies.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_resource_manager_rpc\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"v1.0#proxy-api-reference.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Proxy API Reference\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/proxy-api-reference.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Proxy API Reference\\\\n# v1.0#proxy-api-reference.md\\\\n\\\\n# Proxy API Reference\\\\n\\\\n- [Proxy API Reference](#proxy-api-reference) \\\\u003cbr/\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  - [Resource Action Requests](#resource-action-requests) \\\\u003cbr/\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  - [Subscription wide Reads and Actions](#subscription-wide-reads-and-actions) \\\\u003cbr/\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  - [Exposing Available Operations](#exposing-available-operations) \\\\u003cbr/\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  - [Check Name Availability Requests](#check-name-availability-requests) \\\\u003cbr/\\\\u003e\\\\n\\\\n## Proxy API reference ##\\\\n\\\\nARM will proxy requests to backing resource providers even if they are not related directly to resource management or subscription lifecycle changes. ARM does not check RP registration for proxy requests. \\\\r\\\\nThese requests are considered to be part of the \\\\\\\"Proxy API\\\\\\\" and examples include: restart a VM; fetch storage account keys; or increase the capacity of a mobile service.\\\\n\\\\n### Resource Action Requests ###\\\\n\\\\nchecks.\\\\r\\\\n#### Response ####\\\\r\\\\nThe response includes an HTTP status code, a set of response headers, and a response body.\\\\r\\\\n**Status Code**\\\\r\\\\nThe resource provider should return 200 (OK) to indicate that the action completed successfully. 202 (Accepted) can be returned to indicate that the action will complete asynchronously.\\\\r\\\\nIf the resource group or a relevant resource does not exist, 404 (NotFound) should be returned.\\\\r\\\\n**Response Headers**\\\\r\\\\nHeaders common to all responses.\\\\r\\\\n**Response Body**\\\\r\\\\nThe response body will be specific to the resource provider and the action, but it \\\\\\\\*must\\\\\\\\* adhere to the REST CEC guidelines and be JSON by default.\\\\r\\\\n#### Rules ####\\\\n\\\\nActions can be performed on objects (e.g. reimage VM instance), but still need to be modeled in a consistent way across internal and external resource providers. Through this consistency, resource providers will be able to \\\\\\\"light-up\\\\\\\" authorization / RBAC scenarios without changing their API surface.\\\\r\\\\nIn order to make the \\\\\\\"action\\\\\\\" consistent across resource providers, the action name must be included in the URL via a specific format (which is aligned with OData).\\\\r\\\\nThe HTTP verb and request body will \\\\\\\\*not\\\\\\\\* be used in identifying the \\\\\\\"action\\\\\\\" being taken on the resource provider if the action name is provided.\\\\r\\\\n**If no action name is provided, the HTTP Verb (e.g. GET / PUT) will be used as the action name.**\\\\r\\\\n#### Request ###\\\\r\\\\n| Method | Request URI |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| POST | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/resourceGroups/{resourceGroupName}/providers/{resourceProviderNamespace}/{resourceType}/{resourceName}/{actionName}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n**Arguments**\\\\r\\\\n[Common Arguments](./uri-format-and-arguments-for-crud-apis-on-resources.md)\\\\r\\\\nExamples of action names include: \\\\\\\"restartVM\\\\\\\" or \\\\\\\"listStorageKeys\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n**Request Body**\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"resourceDefinedProperty\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Resource defined value\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\nAll parameters for the action request should be contained in the request body \\u2013 and not in the URL. This matches the OData and Azure REST guidelines and will avoid impacting the authZ checks.\\\\r\\\\n#### Response ####\\\\r\\\\nThe response includes an HTTP status code, a set of response headers, and a response body.\\\\r\\\\n**Status Code**\\\\r\\\\nThe resource provider should return 200 (OK) to indicate that the action completed successfully. 202 (Accepted) can be returned to indicate that the action will complete asynchronously.\\\\r\\\\nIf the resource group or a relevant resource does not exist, 404 (NotFound) should be returned.\\\\r\\\\n**Response Headers**\\\\r\\\\nHeaders common to all responses.\\\\r\\\\n**Response Body**\\\\n\\\\n### General impact of violating the rules ###\\\\n\\\\n| \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-04 | A `POST` operation **must** return status code 404 (NotFound) to indicate that the resource or resource group does not exist. | Required |  | Runtime |  | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-05 | All parameters **must** be specified in the payload and not in the URI. | Required | This allows proper implementation of authorization checks. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/parameters-in-POST.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-06 | Response body of the `POST` operation *may* have any schema as defined by the Resource Provider. | Recommended |  | Design | | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-07 | A `POST` operation **must** apply either to a specific resource instance of a resource type or to the provider. It **must not** be applied to a resource type. | Required | ARM cannot route such requests to the Resource Provider. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/path-for-resource-action.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-08 | A `POST` operation *may* perform a read-only action at a subscription scope. | Recommended |  | Design |  | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-09 | Undefined | Undefined | Undefined | Undefined | Undefined | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-10 | Prefix the action name with the term `list` to allow template deployment to call the `POST` action. | Recommended | | Design |  |\\\\n\\\\nViolating these rules result in APIs across Azure becoming inconsistent with each other. Such inconsistencies degrade customer experience as they now have to deal with slightly different behaviors while interacting with each Resource Provider. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n| RPC Guideline code | Title | Conformance level | Additional impact |  Applicable scope | Linter rule |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-01 | An action name must be provided for a `POST` operation. | Required | ARM cannot route the request. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/path-for-resource-action.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-02 | A synchronous `POST` operation **must** specify status code 200 (OK) with response schema or 204 (No response content) to indicate successful completion. | Required | | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/POST-response-codes.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-03 | An asynchronous `POST` operation **must** specify 202 [Accepted] to indicate successful acceptance of the API. It **should** additionaly specify status code 200 (OK) with a response schema indicating the schema of the final response if the final response is expected to have one. If the final response is expected to not have any content, specifying only 202 is sufficient. | Required |  | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/POST-response-codes.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-04 | A `POST` operation **must** return status code 404 (NotFound) to indicate that the resource or resource group does not exist. | Required |  | Runtime |  | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-05 | All parameters **must** be specified in the payload and not in the URI. | Required | This allows proper implementation of authorization checks. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/parameters-in-POST.md) | \\\\r\\\\n|\\\\n\\\\n### Subscription Wide Reads and Actions ###\\\\n\\\\nThis applies to GETs and POSTs where some data needs to be exposed in a read-only fashion across a subscription or tenant. The Resource Provider contract allows for this functionality but recommends caution when exposing it (since it requires a \\\\u0026quot;global\\\\u0026quot; endpoint for the RP \\\\u0026amp; does not support regional routing).\\\\r\\\\nExamples include: available platform images for a subscription; available locations for their offer type; quotas or restrictions imposed on their subscription.\\\\r\\\\n**Please review all instances where this API is used with the current owners of the RP API document. Manageable entities should \\\\\\\\*never\\\\\\\\* be updated at this level.**\\\\r\\\\n#### Request (Subscription wide operations) ####\\\\r\\\\n| Method | Request URI |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| GET | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/providers/{resourceProviderNamespace}/{resourceType}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n| GET | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/providers/{resourceProviderNamespace}/{resourceType}/{resourceName}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n| POST | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/providers/{resourceProviderNamespace}/{actionName}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n#### Request (Tenant wide operations) ####\\\\r\\\\n| Method | Request URI |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| POST | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/providers/{resourceProviderNamespace}/{actionName}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n**Arguments**\\\\r\\\\n| Argument | Description |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| subscriptionId | The subscriptionId for the Azure user. |\\\\r\\\\n| api-version | Specifies the version of the protocol used to make this request. Format must match YYYY-MM-DD[{-preview} or  {-alpha}or{-beta}or{-rc}or{-privatepreview}]. |\\\\r\\\\n| resourceProviderNamespace| The resource provider namespace can only be ASCII alphanumeric characters and the \\\\\\\".\\\\\\\" character. |\\\\r\\\\n| resourceType| The type of the resource \\u2013 the resource providers declare the resource types they support at the time of registering with Azure.\\\\n\\\\n| The subscriptionId for the Azure user. |\\\\r\\\\n| api-version | Specifies the version of the protocol used to make this request. Format must match YYYY-MM-DD[{-preview} or  {-alpha}or{-beta}or{-rc}or{-privatepreview}]. |\\\\r\\\\n| resourceProviderNamespace| The resource provider namespace can only be ASCII alphanumeric characters and the \\\\\\\".\\\\\\\" character. |\\\\r\\\\n| resourceType| The type of the resource \\u2013 the resource providers declare the resource types they support at the time of registering with Azure. The resourceType should follow the lowerCamelCase convention and be plural (e.g. virtualMachines, resourceGroups, jobCollections, virtualNetworks). The resource type can only be ASCII alphanumeric characters.|\\\\r\\\\n**Request Headers**\\\\r\\\\nOnly headers common to all requests.\\\\r\\\\n**Request Body**\\\\r\\\\nControlled by the resource provider (e.g. GETs should have no body; POSTs can have a body as part of the action).\\\\r\\\\n#### Response ####\\\\r\\\\nThe response includes an HTTP status code, a set of response headers, and a response body if it applies.\\\\r\\\\n**Status Code**\\\\r\\\\nThe resource provider should return 200 (OK) to indicate that the action completed\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/typespec-for-openapi-dev\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n# getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n\\\\nThis guide introduces TypeSpec using concepts familiar to developers who build or use API definitions in OpenAPI v2 or v3.\\\\r\\\\nIn many cases, this will also describe how the typespec-autorest and openapi3 emitters translate\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec designs into OpenAPI.\\\\r\\\\nThe document is organized around the features of an OpenAPI v2 or v3 definition.\\\\r\\\\nThe idea is that if you know how to describe some API feature in OpenAPI, you can just navigate\\\\r\\\\nto the section of this document for that feature.\\\\n\\\\n## Data Types\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI [v2](https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/main/versions/2.0.md#data-types)/[v3](https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#data-types), data types are specified using the `type` and `format` fields in a schema.\\\\r\\\\nThe TypeSpec equivalents of OpenAPI data types are the TypeSpec primitive types or [built-in models](https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/built-in-types).\\\\n\\\\n### type and format\\\\n\\\\n| RFC 3339 date with offset                                                 |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `password`  | `@secret string` |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `boolean` |             | `boolean`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\nYou can also define a property with no type specified using the TypeSpec `unknown` type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  /** This property has no `type` defined. */\\\\r\\\\n  noType?: unknown;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOpenAPI allows any string as a format, and there is a [registry of common formats][Format Registry].\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec supports some of these directly.\\\\r\\\\n[Format Registry]: https://spec.openapis.org/registry/format\\\\r\\\\n| `type:`   | `format:`    | TypeSpec type | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------- | ------------ | ------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `decimal`    | `decimal`     |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `double-int` | `safeint`     |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int8`       | `int8`        |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int16`      | `int16`       |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `uint8`      | `uint8`       |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `uri`        | `url`         |       |\\\\r\\\\nFor formats that are not supported directly, you can use the built-in `@format` decorator to specify\\\\r\\\\nthe format explicitly.\\\\n\\\\nThe following table shows how common OpenAPI types map to TypeSpec types:\\\\r\\\\n| `type:`   | `format:`   | TypeSpec type    | Notes                                                                     |\\\\r\\\\n| --------- | ----------- | ---------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int32`     | `int32`          |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int64`     | `int64`          |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `float`     | `float32`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `double`    | `float64`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  |             | `string`         |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `byte`      | `bytes`          | for content-type == 'application/json' or 'text/plain'                    |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `binary`    | `bytes`          | for \\\\\\\"binary\\\\\\\" content types, e.g. 'application/octet-stream', 'image/jpeg' |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `date`      | `plainDate`      |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `date-time` | `utcDateTime`    | RFC 3339 date in coordinated universal time (UTC)                         |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `date-time` | `offsetDateTime` | RFC 3339 date with offset                                                 |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `password`  | `@secret string` |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `boolean` |             | `boolean`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\nYou can also define a property with no type specified using the TypeSpec `unknown` type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  /** This property has no `type` defined. */\\\\n\\\\n### JSON Schema assertions\\\\n\\\\nOpenAPI supports a variety of \\\\\\\"assertions\\\\\\\" that can be used to further restrict the values allowed for a data type.\\\\r\\\\nThese are actually borrowed into OpenAPI from JSON Schema.\\\\r\\\\nFor `type: integer` and `type: number` data types:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI/JSON Schema keyword | TypeSpec construct           | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------------------------- | ---------------------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `minimum: value`            | `@minValue(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `maximum: value`            | `@maxValue(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\nFor `type: string` data types:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI/JSON Schema keyword | TypeSpec construct            | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------------------------- | ----------------------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `minLength: value`          | `@minLength(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `maxLength: value`          | `@maxLength(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `pattern: regex`            | `@pattern(regex)` decorator   |       |\\\\r\\\\nFor `type: array` data types:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI/JSON Schema keyword | TypeSpec construct           | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------------------------- | ---------------------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `minItems: value`           | `@minItems(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `maxItems: value`           | `@maxItems(value)` decorator |       |\\\\n\\\\n### enum\\\\n\\\\nThere are two ways to define an `enum` data type in TypeSpec. One is with the [TypeSpec `enum` statement](https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/enums), e.g.:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- To retain the quotes from the enum values --\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- prettier-ignore-start --\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Color {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- prettier-ignore-end --\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\nAnother is to use the union operation to define the enum values inline, e.g.:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  size?: \\\\\\\"small\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"medium\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"large\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"x-large\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### default\\\\n\\\\nA model property that specifies a default value using \\\\\\\"=\\\\\\\" will produce a `default` field in the schema for this property.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  answer?: int32 = 42;\\\\r\\\\n  color?: string = \\\\\\\"purple\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nproduces\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nanswer:\\\\r\\\\n  type: integer\\\\r\\\\n  format: int32\\\\r\\\\n  default: 42\\\\r\\\\ncolor:\\\\r\\\\n  type: string\\\\r\\\\n  default: purple\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Host / BasePath / Servers\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI v2, the `host` and `basePath` fields at the top-level of the API definition combine to form the base URL for the API. The paths defined in the `paths` object are appended to this base URL to form the absolute URL for an operation.\\\\r\\\\nIn OpenAPI v3, the top-level `servers` field specifies an array of `server` objects [[v3][v3-server]] with a base URL, which may be parameterized, to which the operation path is appended.\\\\r\\\\n[v3-server]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#server-object\\\\r\\\\nIn TypeSpec, the `host` in OpenAPI v2 or `servers` in OpenAPI v3 can be specified with the `@server` decorator\\\\r\\\\non the namespace (from `@typespec/http` library). You can use this decorator multiple times to specify multiple servers.\\\\n\\\\n## Paths Object\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI, the `paths` object [[v2][v2-paths], [v3][v3-paths]] is the top-level structure for defining the operations of the API, organized by the \\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\" for the operation.\\\\r\\\\n[v2-paths]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/main/versions/2.0.md#paths-object\\\\r\\\\n[v3-paths]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#paths-object\\\\r\\\\nIn TypeSpec, you can specify the path for a namespace, interface, or operation using the `@route` decorator.\\\\r\\\\nWhen the value of the `@route` decorator contains path parameters, operations within the scope of the decorator\\\\r\\\\nmust declare parameters with the same name and type. If an operation declares a path parameter that is not present\\\\r\\\\nin the route, this defines a new path that is the value from the `@route` decorator with the path parameter appended.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/pets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Pets {\\\\r\\\\n  op create(@body pet: Pet): Pet; // uses path \\\\\\\"/pets\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  op read(@path petId: int32): Pet; // uses path \\\\\\\"/pets/{petId}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhen the `@route` decorator is used within a namespace or interface that also has a `@route` decorator, the path is\\\\r\\\\nobtained by concatenating the routes.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/widgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  // widgets operations\\\\r\\\\n  @route(\\\\\\\"/{id}/parts\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  namespace Parts {\\\\r\\\\n    op list(@path id: string): Part[] | Error; // uses path \\\\\\\"/widgets/{id}/parts\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Path Item Object\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI, a path item object [[v2][v2-pathitem], [v3][v3-pathitem]] describes the operations available on a single path. A path may have at most one `get`, `put`, `post`, `patch`, `delete`, or `head` operation.\\\\r\\\\n[v2-pathitem]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/main/versions/2.0.md#path-item-object\\\\r\\\\n[v3-pathitem]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#path-item-object\\\\r\\\\nIn TypeSpec, operations are defined within a namespace or interface with a syntax similar to typescript functions.\\\\r\\\\nThe HTTP method for an operation can be specified explicitly using a decorator: `@get`, `@put`, `@post`, `@patch`, `@delete`, or `@head`.\\\\r\\\\nIf an HTTP method decorator is not specified then the default is `post` if there is a body and `get` otherwise.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@tag(\\\\\\\"Gadgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/gadgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Gadgets {\\\\r\\\\n  op create(@body gadget: Gadget): Gadget | Error; // uses \\\\\\\"post\\\\\\\" method\\\\r\\\\n  op read(@path id: string): Gadget | Error; // uses \\\\\\\"get\\\\\\\" method\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOther path item fields:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI `pathItem` field | TypeSpec construct | Notes                    |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------------ | ------------------ | ------------------------ |\\\\r\\\\n| `summary`                |                    |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#04-common-parameters.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Common Parameters\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/04-common-parameters\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Common Parameters\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#04-common-parameters.md\\\\n\\\\n# Common Parameters\\\\n\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n\\\\nIn this section, we'll focus on reusing common parameters in your REST API. Common parameters are parameters that are used across multiple operations. By defining these parameters once and reusing them, we can make our API more consistent, easier to read, and easier to maintain.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getstarted#createproject.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Creating a project\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/createproject\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Creating a project\\\\n### Target Users\\\\n# getstarted#createproject.md\\\\n\\\\n# Creating a project\\\\n\\\\n### Target Users\\\\n\\\\n- **Rest-API-Spec Repo Projects**: Ideal for those contributing directly to the Azure REST API specifications, ensuring production-quality SDK generation.\\\\r\\\\n- **Standalone Projects**: Suited for API-first development, allowing users to generate OpenAPI specs, service code, and clients without conforming to the specs repo's structure.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM-Models-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec ARM Model Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec ARM Model Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n## 36. ProviderNamespace\\\\n\\\\n### Description\\\\n\\\\nModel describing the provider namespace. This represents the Azure Resource Manager provider namespace for organizing resources.\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Example\\\\n\\\\n```typescript\\\\r\\\\n@armProviderNamespace\\\\r\\\\n@service({\\\\r\\\\n  title: \\\\\\\"MyService\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n})\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.MyService;\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n### Swagger Output\\\\n\\\\n```json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"paths\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"/providers/Microsoft.MyService/operations\\\\\\\": {}\\\\r\\\\n Response Models\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/07-custom-response-models\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Custom Response Models\\\\n## Using Custom Response Models in Operations\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#07-custom-response-models.md\\\\n\\\\n# Custom Response Models\\\\n\\\\n## Using Custom Response Models in Operations\\\\n\\\\nNow that we have defined our custom response models, let's use them in our API operations.\\\\n\\\\n### Example: Applying Custom Response Models to Operations\\\\n\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n    @delete\\\\r\\\\n    @useAuth(BearerAuth)\\\\r\\\\n    op deleteToy(@path petId: int32, @path toyId: int32, ...CommonParameters): {\\\\r\\\\n      @statusCode statusCode: 204;\\\\r\\\\n    };\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@error\\\\r\\\\nmodel NotFoundError {\\\\r\\\\n  code: \\\\\\\"NOT_FOUND\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  message: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@error\\\\r\\\\nmodel ValidationError {\\\\r\\\\n  code: \\\\\\\"VALIDATION_ERROR\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  message: string;\\\\r\\\\n  details: string[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@error\\\\r\\\\nmodel UnauthorizedError {\\\\r\\\\n  code: \\\\\\\"UNAUTHORIZED\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  message: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@error\\\\r\\\\nmodel InternalServerError {\\\\r\\\\n  code: \\\\\\\"INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  message: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel InternalServerErrorResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  @statusCode statusCode: 500;\\\\r\\\\n  @body error: InternalServerError;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example:\\\\r\\\\n- The `listPets` operation uses the `PetListResponse` custom response model.\\\\r\\\\n- The `getPet` operation uses the `PetResponse` and `PetNotFoundResponse` custom response models.\\\\r\\\\n- The `createPet` operation uses the `PetCreatedResponse`, `PetAcceptedResponse`, `PetErrorResponse`, and `PetUnauthorizedResponse` custom response models.\\\\r\\\\n- The `updatePet` operation uses the `PetResponse`, `PetErrorResponse`, `PetUnauthorizedResponse`, `PetNotFoundResponse`, and `InternalServerErrorResponse` custom response models.\\\\r\\\\n- The `deletePet` operation uses the `PetNoContentResponse` and `PetUnauthorizedResponse` custom response models.\\\\r\\\\nNote that we could also define custom response models for the `Toys` operations, similar to the `Pets` operations. But for brevity, we're omitting them in this example.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp title=main.tsp tryit=\\\\\\\"{\\\\\\\"emit\\\\\\\": [\\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\"]}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Pet Store\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\\\\"https://example.com\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Single server endpoint\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace PetStore;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1: \\\\\\\"1.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2: \\\\\\\"2.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  @minLength(1)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @minValue(0)\\\\r\\\\n  @maxValue(100)\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  kind: petType;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nenum petType {\\\\r\\\\n  dog: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  cat: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  fish: \\\\\\\"fish\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  bird: \\\\\\\"bird\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  reptile: \\\\\\\"reptile\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Toy {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel CommonParameters {\\\\r\\\\n  @header\\\\r\\\\n  requestID: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @query\\\\r\\\\n  locale?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @header\\\\r\\\\n  clientVersion?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-start\\\\r\\\\nmodel PetListResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  ...OkResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Body\\\\u003cPet[]\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel PetResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  ...OkResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Body\\\\u003cPet\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel PetCreatedResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  ...CreatedResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Body\\\\u003cPet\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel PetAcceptedResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  ...AcceptedResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Body\\\\u003cPet\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel PetErrorResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  ...BadRequestResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Body\\\\u003cValidationError\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel PetNotFoundResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  ...NotFoundResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Body\\\\u003cNotFoundError\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel PetUnauthorizedResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  ...UnauthorizedResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Body\\\\u003cUnauthorizedError\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel PetSuccessResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  ...OkResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Body\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel PetNoContentResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  ...NoContentResponse;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/pets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Pets {\\\\r\\\\n  @get\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\n  op listPets(...CommonParameters): PetListResponse;\\\\r\\\\n @useAuth(BearerAuth)\\\\r\\\\n  @post\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-start\\\\r\\\\n  op createPet(@body pet: Pet):\\\\r\\\\n    | PetCreatedResponse\\\\r\\\\n    | PetAcceptedResponse\\\\r\\\\n    | PetErrorResponse\\\\r\\\\n    | PetUnauthorizedResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n  @useAuth(BearerAuth)\\\\r\\\\n  @put\\\\n\\\\nnamespace Pets {\\\\r\\\\n  @get\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\n  op listPets(...CommonParameters): PetListResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  @get\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-start\\\\r\\\\n  op getPet(@path petId: int32, @header ifMatch?: string): PetResponse | PetNotFoundResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n  @useAuth(BearerAuth)\\\\r\\\\n  @post\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-start\\\\r\\\\n  op createPet(@body pet: Pet):\\\\r\\\\n    | PetCreatedResponse\\\\r\\\\n    | PetAcceptedResponse\\\\r\\\\n    | PetErrorResponse\\\\r\\\\n    | PetUnauthorizedResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n  @useAuth(BearerAuth)\\\\r\\\\n  @put\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-start\\\\r\\\\n  op updatePet(@path petId: int32, @body pet: Pet):\\\\r\\\\n    | PetResponse\\\\r\\\\n    | PetErrorResponse\\\\r\\\\n    | PetUnauthorizedResponse\\\\r\\\\n    | PetNotFoundResponse\\\\r\\\\n    | InternalServerErrorResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n  @useAuth(BearerAuth)\\\\r\\\\n  @delete\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-start\\\\r\\\\n  op deletePet(@path petId: int32): PetNoContentResponse | PetUnauthorizedResponse;\\\\r\\\\n  // highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n  @route(\\\\\\\"{petId}/toys\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  namespace Toys {\\\\r\\\\n    @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n    @get\\\\r\\\\n    op listToys(@path petId: int32, ...CommonParameters): {\\\\r\\\\n      @body toys: Toy[];\\\\r\\\\n    };\\\\r\\\\n    @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n    @post\\\\r\\\\n    @useAuth(BearerAuth)\\\\r\\\\n    op createToy(@path petId: int32, @body toy: Toy, ...CommonParameters): {\\\\r\\\\n      @statusCode statusCode: 201;\\\\r\\\\n      @body newToy: Toy;\\\\r\\\\n    };\\\\r\\\\n    @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n    @put\\\\r\\\\n    @useAuth(BearerAuth)\\\\r\\\\n    op updateToy(@path petId: int32, @path toyId: int32, @body toy: Toy, ...CommonParameters): {\\\\r\\\\n      @body updatedToy: Toy;\\\\r\\\\n    };\\\\r\\\\n    @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n    @delete\\\\r\\\\n    @useAuth(BearerAuth)\\\\r\\\\n NotFoundError {\\\\r\\\\n  code: \\\\\\\"NOT_FOUND\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  message: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@error\\\\r\\\\nmodel ValidationError {\\\\r\\\\n  code:
