Evolution\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Scenarios for API Evolution\\\\n## Scenarios to Consider\\\\n# azure#apiVersionEvolution.md\\\\n\\\\n# Scenarios for API Evolution\\\\n\\\\nThis document describe how to evolute api version for a management plane services.\\\\n\\\\n## Scenarios to Consider\\\\n\\\\nadd a new stable version\\\\r\\\\nadd a new preview version\\\\r\\\\nMaking a preview api stable\\\\r\\\\nReplacing a preview API with a new preview API\\\\r\\\\nReplacing a preview API with a stable API\\\\r\\\\nReplacing a preview API with a stable API and a new preview API\\\\r\\\\nAdding a preview API (previous stable API)\\\\r\\\\nConverting existing specs with mixes of preview and stable APIs\\\\r\\\\nNote that, in this new scenario, new services will always have only a single version in their specs until they have their first stable version.  This should drastically reduce the amount of decoration in preview APIs\\\\n\\\\n## Add a new stable version\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n1. Check the Latest Version\\\\r\\\\n   1. Determine whether the latest version is a preview version or a stable (GA) version.\\\\r\\\\n2. If the Latest Version is Stable (GA):\\\\r\\\\n   1. Add a new entry for the new stable version at the bottom of the Versions enumeration\\\\r\\\\n   2. Add a new example folder for the new version and copy any still-relevant examples\\\\r\\\\n   3. Make changes to the API using versioning decorators to mark each change\\\\r\\\\n3. if the latest version is preview version: \\\\r\\\\n   1. Add a new stable (GA) version enum before the existing preview enum value.\\\\r\\\\n   2. Add a new example folder for the new version and copy any still-relevant examples\\\\r\\\\n   3. Update all items that are GA\\u2019ing:\\\\r\\\\n      1. Change their @added version value to match the new GA enum value.\\\\r\\\\n   4. Handle remaining preview-only features:\\\\r\\\\n      1. If some features are not GAed, create a new preview version and Decorate non-GA items with @added pointing to the new preview version.\\\\r\\\\n      2. If all features in the preview version are GAed, delete the existing preview version.\\\\n\\\\n## Replacing a Preview API with a new Preview API (Adding a Preview API to a spec with an active preview)\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Use 'rename symbol' to rename the version in the \\\\\\\"versions\\\\\\\" enumeration and all references to match the new preview api-version\\\\r\\\\n- rename the example folder to use the new version\\\\r\\\\n- Remove any api changes not in the new version (simply remove types or type change decorators that do not apply)\\\\r\\\\n- Change the API inline decorating any type changes or new types in the new versionSome tooling to pick which resources, types, and operations are part of the new API could be useful.\\\\n\\\\n### Check-in Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Add new tag to readme (can this be automated)?\\\\n\\\\n### CI Checks and Process\\\\n\\\\n- Investigate whether ci checks will flag existing swagger generated from previous typespec and adjust checks as necessary\\\\r\\\\n- Cleanup process for retired api-versions\\\\n\\\\n## Replacing a Preview API with a Stable API (Adding a stable API to a spec with an active preview)\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Use 'rename symbol' to rename the version in the \\\\\\\"versions\\\\\\\" enumeration and all references to match the new stable api-version. \\\\r\\\\n- Remove any @previewVersion decorator\\\\r\\\\n- rename the example folder to use the new stable api version\\\\r\\\\n- Remove any api changes not in the new stable API version. Some tooling to pick which resources, types, and operations are part of the new API could be useful.\\\\r\\\\n- Add any api changes in the new stable version, using versioning decorators unless it is the only api-version\\\\n\\\\n### Check-in Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Add new tag to readme (can this be automated)?\\\\n\\\\n### CI Checks and Process\\\\n\\\\n- Investigate whether ci checks will flag existing swagger generated from previous typespec and adjust checks as necessary\\\\r\\\\n- Cleanup process for retired api-versions\\\\n\\\\n## Replacing a Preview API with a new Stable and a Preview API (previous stable API exists)\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Use 'rename symbol' to rename the preview version in the \\\\\\\"versions\\\\\\\" enumeration to match the new preview version and all references\\\\r\\\\n- Add a new Stable version entry immediately before the renamed version entry\\\\r\\\\n- rename the example folder to use the new preview api version\\\\r\\\\n- Create a new example folder for the stable API and copy relevant examples\\\\r\\\\n- Relabel any api changes in the new stable API version, that is, any changes in the preview that are now considered stable. \\\\r\\\\n    - Some tooling to pick which resources, types, and operations from the previous preview became stable and which ones became part of the new preview APIs.\\\\r\\\\n- Add any api changes in the new stable version, using versioning decorators (automatically included in the new preview version)\\\\r\\\\n- Add any api changes still in preview in the new preview API-version, using versioning decorators\\\\n\\\\n### Check-in Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Add new tags to readme (can this be automated)?\\\\n\\\\n### CI Checks and Process\\\\n\\\\n- Investigate whether ci checks will flag existing swagger generated from previous typespec and adjust checks as necessary\\\\r\\\\n- Cleanup process for retired api-versions\\\\n\\\\n## Replacing a Preview API with the first Stable API and a new Preview API (no previous stable api)\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Replace the current versions enum member with the new stable api-version (first) and the new preview api-version (last)\\\\r\\\\n- Decorate the preview api-version with the @previewVersion decorator\\\\r\\\\n- Rename the example folder to use the new preview api version and update examples as needed\\\\r\\\\n- Create a new example folder for the stable API and copy relevant examples\\\\r\\\\n- Leave any resources, types and operations in the new stable version undecorated (automatically included in both the new stable and the new preview version)\\\\r\\\\n- Decorate any resources, types, and operations only in the new preview API version, that is, any types that are not considered stable. Some tooling to pick - which resources, types, and operations from the previous preview became stable and which ones became part of the new preview APIs.\\\\r\\\\n- Add any new preview api changes in the new preview API-version, using versioning decorators\\\\n\\\\n### Check-in Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Add new tags to readme (can this be automated)?\\\\n\\\\n### CI Checks and Process\\\\n\\\\n- Investigate whether ci checks will flag existing swagger generated from previous typespec and adjust checks as necessary\\\\r\\\\n- Cleanup process for retired api-versions\\\\n\\\\n## Adding a Preview API (Previous Stable API)\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Add a new entry for the new preview version at the bottom of the Versions enumeration and decorate with @previewVersion\\\\r\\\\n- Add a new example folder for the new version and copy any still-relevant examples\\\\r\\\\n- Make changes to the API using versioning decorators to mark each change\\\\n\\\\n### Check-in Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Add new tag to readme (can this be automated)?\\\\n\\\\n## Converting Existing Specs With mixes of Preview and Stable APIs\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n- For each preview api-version, in order\\\\r\\\\n  - For each versioning decorator, forward the version to the next version, except\\\\r\\\\n    - if this would result in a duplicated decorator application (including all decorator parameters) at that version, discard the forwarded decorator\\\\r\\\\n    - if this would result in an @added and @removed pair at a version, then discard the forwarded decorator\\\\r\\\\n    - If this would result in @typeChangedFrom or @renamedFrom with conflicting parameters, use the forwarded decorator\\\\r\\\\n  - Remove the preview api-version\\\\r\\\\n- For the first stable version\\\\r\\\\n  - Remove any @madeOptional, @added,  @typeChangedFrom, or @renamedFrom decorators\\\\r\\\\n  - Remove any types marked with the @removed decorator, unless they have @added decoration in subsequent versions\\\\n\\\\n### Check-in Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Add new tags to readme (can this be automated)?\\\\n\\\\n## Rules for api-version Changes\\\\n\\\\n@added decorator in version b, both decorators can be removedsafe: @removed(a) @added(b) myType: string-\\\\u003e myType: string\\\\r\\\\n  - if there is an@addeddecorator in version a and an  @removeddecorator in version b, safe: @added(a) @removed(b) myType: string-\\\\u003e \\\\r\\\\n  - There should never be a backward-looking decorator from version a forwarded to version b if version b has an @added decoratorThis is because such a versioning would already be inconsistent:  A type cannot be transformed before it exists\\\\r\\\\n  - There should never be a forward looking (@removed) decorator from version a forwarded to version b if version b has any backward-looking decorator and does not have@addedThis is because such a versioning would already be inconsistent:  a type cannot be transformed after it is removed\\\\n\\\\ndecorator on type T from a to b, provided there are no other versioning decorators on type T that use version b.\\\\r\\\\n    - safe:  @added(a) -\\\\u003e @added(b)\\\\r\\\\n    - possibly unsafe: @added(a)@removed(b) -\\\\u003e @added(b) @removed(b)\\\\r\\\\n  - It is safe to forward an @added decorator on type T from a to b and remove any backward-looking decorator on type T using version b:\\\\r\\\\n    - safe: @added(a) @added(b) -\\\\u003e @added(b)\\\\r\\\\n    - safe: @added(a) @madeOptional(b) myType?: int32 -\\\\u003e @added(b) myType?: int32\\\\r\\\\n    - safe: @added(a) @typeChangedFrom(b, string) myType: int32 -\\\\u003e @added(b) myType: int32\\\\r\\\\n    - safe: @added(a) @renamedFrom(b, \\\\\\\"oldName\\\\\\\") newName: string -\\\\u003e @added(b) newName: string\\\\r\\\\n  - It is safe to forward a @madeOptionaldecorator on type T from a to b and remove any @madeOptional decorator using version b on type T :safe: @madeOptional(a) @madeOptional(b) myType?: int32 -\\\\u003e @madeOptional(b) myType?: int32\\\\r\\\\n  - This is similarly true for @typeChangedFrom and @renamedFrom decorators:safe: @typeChangedFrom(a, integer) @typeChangedFrom(b, int32) myType?: int64 -\\\\u003e @typeChangedFrom(b, integer) myType?: int64\\\\r\\\\nsafe: @renamedFrom(a, \\\\\\\"veryOldName\\\\\\\") @renamedFrom(b, \\\\\\\"oldName\\\\\\\") newName?: string -\\\\u003e @renamedFrom(b, \\\\\\\"veryOldName\\\\\\\") newName?: string\\\\r\\\\n  - It is safe to forward a @madeOptionaldecorator on type T from a to b and leave any @typeChangedFrom or @renamedFrom decorator using version b on type T :safe: @madeOptional(a) @typeChangedFrom(b, string) myType?: int32 -\\\\u003e @madeOptional(b) @typeChangedFrom(b, string) myType: int32\\\\r\\\\nsafe: @madeOptional(a) @renamedFrom(b, \\\\\\\"oldName\\\\\\\") newName?: string -\\\\u003e @madeOptional(b) @re\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Service under conversation label\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Service under conversation label\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Service under conversation label\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion, \\\\r\\\\nMy team currently has a PR open to release a new stable API. However, due to backend delays, it\\u2019s been open since July. During that time, the [typespec migration PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36556) was drafted against our preview API. Now, the service-under-conversion label has been added to our stable PR. I\\u2019d like to understand does this label indicate a delay in merging in our [stable api PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36219), or will we need to make additional changes?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe label should not impact your previous PR, and , if this is a later api-version thatn the conversion PR, the conversion would normally be based on that version once checked in.  Adding Janine Zhang for awareness about the conversion.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_api_guidelines\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"azure#ConsiderationsForServiceDesign.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Considerations for Service Design\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/blob/vNext/azure/ConsiderationsForServiceDesign.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Considerations for Service Design\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n# azure#ConsiderationsForServiceDesign.md\\\\n\\\\n# Considerations for Service Design\\\\n\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n\\\\nGreat APIs make your service usable to customers. They are intuitive, naturally reflecting and communicating the underlying model and its behavior. They lend themselves easily to client library implementations in multiple programming languages. And they don't \\\\\\\"get in the way\\\\\\\" of the developer, by remaining stable and predictable, _especially over time_.\\\\r\\\\nThis document provides Microsoft teams building Azure services with a set of guidelines that  help service teams build great APIs. The guidelines create APIs that are approachable, sustainable, and consistent across the Azure platform. We do this by applying a common set of patterns and web standards to the design and development of the API.\\\\r\\\\nFor developers, a well defined and constructed API enables them to build fault-tolerant applications that are easy to maintain, support, and grow. For Azure service teams, the API is often the source of code generation enabling a broad audience of developers across multiple languages.\\\\r\\\\nAzure Service teams should engage the Azure HTTP/REST Stewardship Board early in the development lifecycle for guidance, discussion, and review of their API. In addition, it is good practice to perform a security review, especially if you are concerned about PII leakage, compliance with GDPR, or any other considerations relative to your situation.\\\\r\\\\nIt is critically important to design your service to avoid disrupting users as the API evolves:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#principles-api-versioning\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"principles-api-versioning\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** implement API versioning starting with the very first release of the service.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#principles-compatibility\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"principles-compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** ensure that customer workloads never in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\\n## The impact to ongoing PRs\\\\n# Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors.md\\\\n\\\\n# After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\\n\\\\n## The impact to ongoing PRs\\\\n\\\\n1. If the ongoing PRs are targeting to a release-* or dev-* branch which are not created or syncing from the latest main, we recommend to merge these PRs first.\\\\r\\\\n1. If the ongoing PRs are targeting to public main branch, Here's the suggestion to resolve the conflict. \\\\r\\\\n      1. Merge latest main \\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n          git checkout main\\\\r\\\\n          git pull origin main // origin points to Azure rest api specs repo.\\\\r\\\\n          git merge main \\\\u003cyour-pr-branch\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n      2. Resolve conflicts  \\\\r\\\\n        - For most of the conflicts, accept the incoming changes.  \\\\r\\\\n        - If it's unclear, please accept both and then update based on your judgement with the folder structure changes above.  \\\\r\\\\n      3. Make sure the new change is aligned with folder structure v2  \\\\r\\\\n         There are some cases where the PR is adding a new version in the original location, but the file diffs don't show as conflict. we should move them into the correct place so that it doesn't break the folder structure v2 as instructions in **Understanding Folder Migration sections** \\\\r\\\\n      4. clean up the previous folder if exists.  \\\\r\\\\n**Important**: It's strongly recommended to understand what's really changed in the folder refactor. Always ensure the new PR doesn't include any things that breaks the folder structure.\\\\n\\\\n### After Resolution\\\\n\\\\nMake sure to compile the TypeSpec project so that the TypeSpec Validation could pass.\\\\r\\\\n1. **Comprehensive validation**:\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi Team, \\\\r\\\\nI am releasing a new API version and looks there is a new validation to check existing swagger with new tsp file  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\\\\\" \\\\r\\\\nWe want to keep both old and new api versoins. What is the suggestion here? Do you suggest to create different TSP file for each version/use versioning in existing TSP?  \\\\r\\\\nIf second case, can you share some example where APIs/Properties are added/removed in a newer version\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe idea behind TypeSpec versioning is to model the diffs in your API, encouraging best practices for API evolution. If you have questions about modeling particular changes, feel free to ask.\\\\r\\\\nAbout your concern: fixing a new validation causing changes to older APIs\\u2014this usually happens when new changes are added without using the appropriate version decorators. For example:\\\\r\\\\nIf you added properties or made a property optional, but didn\\u2019t annotate them with @added or @madeOptional, then they would apply to all versions by default, including older ones.\\\\r\\\\nThat\\u2019s likely why your stable version (e.g., 2024-12-01) got unintentionally updated when you only meant to target 2025-07-01-preview.\\\\r\\\\nTo avoid this, always use decorators like @added and @madeOptional to indicate version-specific changes.\\\\r\\\\nAs for the location field and the read/create mutability warning:\\\\r\\\\nThat rule is a warning meant to be advisory. In your case, it doesn\\u2019t seem to apply\\u2014so this is a good example where you should not change the service behavior just to satisfy a linting rule. It's fine to ignore the warning here.\\\\r\\\\nRegarding your question on renaming an API response (e.g., from MoveResponse to MoveResult):\\\\r\\\\nIf the new name is meant for a specific version, ensure it\\u2019s versioned properly in your TypeSpec. In your repro, the naming appears correct\\u2014MoveResult in 2021-10-01-preview, and MoveResponse in 2024-10-01-preview\\u2014so it\\u2019s working as expected.\\\\r\\\\nFinally, for adding or removing a parameter in only the new version:\\\\r\\\\nUnfortunately, you can\\u2019t directly decorate a spread parameter. The best way is to use operation-specific parameters, which you can decorate with versioning decorators. You could alternatively decorate the core parameter definition (e.g., with an augment decorator), but that would affect every usage\\u2014so for localized changes, use operation-specific ones. I guess the tsp and OpenAPI json are not in sync.\\\\r\\\\nHence, wanted to check if the migration is really complete for this folder.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nMain typespec validation should always be passing are you sure you are up you are with dependencies locally?\\\\r\\\\nMake sure to follow instructions here https://aka.ms/ci-fix\\\\r\\\\nJust to reiterate, this is almost always because you need to pull the latest from the target branch into your local clone of the repo, and re-install dependencies at the root.\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation#running-locally\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Service under conversation label\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Service under conversation label\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Service under conversation label\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion, \\\\r\\\\nMy team currently has a PR open to release a new stable API. However, due to backend delays, it\\u2019s been open since July. During that time, the [typespec migration PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36556) was drafted against our preview API. testcase: Design question about suppression rules

expected.answer: suppression can only be provided inline for now. Linter rules can be disabled globally but that would apply to the whole project, can't filter by files

references.title: Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models

knowledges.title: Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models
ARM Rules, TypeSpec Linting, and Suppression
Same response model is used both in pageable operation and non-pageable operation
Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models
Suppress validation failures on a PR
Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing

actual.answer: Currently, TypeSpec suppression rules can only be provided inline within the TypeSpec files themselves. There is no supported mechanism to package suppressions with a shared definitions library such that they apply only to the imported definitions and not to the rest of the consumer's project. Linter rules can be disabled globally in the consumer's project, but this would affect the entire project and cannot be scoped to just the imported definitions. Therefore, if you need to suppress specific linting rules for your shared definitions, you must do so inline in those TypeSpec files. There is no way to ship a definitions package with scoped suppressions that are automatically applied only to those definitions when imported.

TypeSpec-Validation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Validation Rule Suppression\\\\n\\\\nYou can suppress specific validation rules within `TypeSpecValidation` by creating or modifying a `suppressions.yaml` file in the root directory of your service specification.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e **Note:** Currently, only the `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule supports suppression.\\\\n\\\\n## Suppressing SdkTspConfigValidation Rules\\\\n\\\\nThe `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule is responsible for validating emitter options and parameters defined in your `tspconfig.yaml` file. You have the flexibility to suppress this rule entirely or target specific sub-rules within it.\\\\n\\\\n### Suppress the Entire SdkTspConfigValidation Rule\\\\n\\\\nIf you need to skip **all** validation checks for emitter options and parameters within a particular `tspconfig.yaml` file, you can suppress the entire `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule.\\\\r\\\\nTo do this, add or update the `suppressions.yaml` file in your service's root folder with the following content:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply\\\\r\\\\n    - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  reason: the-reason-you-want-to-suppress # Explain why this suppression is necessary\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Suppress Specific Sub-rules within SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\n\\\\nIf you only need to bypass validation for **specific** emitter options or parameters, you can suppress individual sub-rules.\\\\r\\\\nAdd or update your `suppressions.yaml` file with the following structure, specifying the sub-rules to ignore:\\\\r\\\\nSub-rule Syntax:\\\\r\\\\n- For parameters: `parameters.\\\\u003cparameter-key\\\\u003e.default`\\\\r\\\\n- For emitter options: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003coption-key\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n- For nested options (e.g., `package-details: name: \\\\\\\"xxx\\\\\\\"`), use dot notation: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.package-details.name`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply\\\\r\\\\n    - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  sub-rules:\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific parameter's default value\\\\r\\\\n    - parameters.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e.default \\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a nested emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.package-details.name \\\\r\\\\n  reason: the-reason-you-want-to-suppress # Explain why this suppression is necessary\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Swagger breaking change\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Swagger breaking change\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Swagger breaking change\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nPR check run: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346/checks?check_run_id=44501918225\\\\r\\\\nMy typespec conversion PR is failing in swagger breaking change check with the following error: \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"new\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/a1ac3f6f98bb1ea3583b765d00dfceab6d85654f/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"old\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"details\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"incompatible properties : tags\\\\\\\\n definitions/TrackedResource/properties/tags\\\\\\\\n at file:///mnt/vss/_work/1/azure-rest-api-specs/specification/common-types/resource-management/v3/types.json#L489:8\\\\\\\\n definitions/Resource/properties/tags\\\\\\\\n at file:///mnt/vss/_work/1/azure-rest-api-specs/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json#L12397:8\\\\\\\" \\\\r\\\\nThis PR is just having typespec conversion change and I am avoiding any change to the swagger file that is generated as part of typespec conversion. In the old swagger there is a Resource definitionwhich is similar Azure resource definition. Should I suppress this check and how to do it?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThis occurs because in your original swagger, you did not use swagger common-types. \\\\r\\\\nThe 'tags' definitions are compatible, so there is no change in the actual api from this.  This could result in changes in some management sdks, although this change to using the common resource types has generally been accepted. \\\\r\\\\ndocs on suppressions for false positives are here: [Suppress validation failures on a PR](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions) \\\\r\\\\nNote that it is important to go through these and non-pageable operation\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec-migration-docs-2025-08-07.md\\\\n\\\\n# Same response model is used both in pageable operation and non-pageable operation\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nSame response model is used both in pageable operation and non-pageable operation\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nUltimately, the solution agreed upon is to add nextLink and use the core paging schema in TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\r\\\\n#suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/documentation-required\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n- model ListAppIdResponse is Azure.Core.Page\\\\u003cAppId\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n+ model ListAppIdResponse {\\\\r\\\\n+    /*\\\\r\\\\n+    * List of AppIds\\\\r\\\\n+    */\\\\r\\\\n+    @TypeSpec.pageItems\\\\r\\\\n+    value: string[];\\\\r\\\\n+\\\\r\\\\n+    /*\\\\r\\\\n+    * next Link\\\\r\\\\n+    */\\\\r\\\\n+    @TypeSpec.nextLink\\\\r\\\\n+    nextLink?: string;\\\\r\\\\n+ }\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\r\\\\n  #suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"non-standard operations\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  @operationId(\\\\\\\"LocalRulestacks_listAppIds\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n+ @TypeSpec.list\\\\r\\\\n  listAppIds is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      LocalRulestackResource,\\\\r\\\\n      void,\\\\r\\\\n      ArmResponse\\\\u003cListAppIdResponse\\\\u003e,\\\\r\\\\n      Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n          #suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/documentation-required\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          @query(\\\\\\\"appIdVersion\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n          appIdVersion?: string;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n          #suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/documentation-required\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          @query(\\\\\\\"appPrefix\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n          appPrefix?: string;\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n  };\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nif it's pageable, then add decorator @TypeSpec.List to the operation\\\\n\\\\n[ref link](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2932):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nissue title: Same response model is used both in pageable operation and non-pageable operation\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\ncontent: \\\\r\\\\nThis is an example,\\\\r\\\\npageable operation[https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/03a6598cdc38924f9eaaeb03f8ef151f5aeff449/specification/guestconfiguration/resource-manager/Microsoft.GuestConfiguration/stable/2024-04-05/guestconfiguration.json#L1046]\\\\r\\\\nnon-pageable operation[https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/03a6598cdc38924f9eaaeb03f8ef151f5aeff449/specification/guestconfiguration/resource-manager/Microsoft.GuestConfiguration/stable/2024-04-05/guestconfiguration.json#L358]\\\\r\\\\nThey share the same response model GuestConfigurationAssignmentReportList.\\\\r\\\\nIn swagger, pageable is marked at operation level, while in TypeSpec pageable is marked at model level. We need to figure out a way for this case.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nsolution:\\\\r\\\\nAs discussed, TypeSpec\\u2019s core paging system supports both client-driven and server-driven paging, but it requires explicit specification\\u2014there is no default assumption like nextLink. If a response model lacks nextLink, it\\u2019s not considered pageable in the traditional sense, and setting x-ms-pageable would be a misinterpretation.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThe recommendation is to use the standard ARM paging mechanism. Since nextLink is optional, adding it is not a breaking change. This ensures that if paging is implemented later, it follows the standard. Ultimately, the solution agreed upon is to add nextLink and use the core paging schema in TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\r\\\\n#suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/documentation-required\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n- model ListAppIdResponse is Azure.Core.Page\\\\u003cAppId\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n+ model ListAppIdResponse {\\\\r\\\\n+    /*\\\\r\\\\n+    * List of AppIds\\\\r\\\\n+    */\\\\r\\\\n+    @TypeSpec.pageItems\\\\r\\\\n+    value: string[];\\\\r\\\\n+\\\\r\\\\n+    /*\\\\r\\\\n+    * next Link\\\\r\\\\n+    */\\\\r\\\\n+    @TypeSpec.nextLink\\\\r\\\\n+    nextLink?: string;\\\\r\\\\n+ }\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n\\\\nAs an exception to the previous note, resource-manager specs **may** be able to suppress `AvoidAnonymousTypes`, but only if the error is inside a 202 response from a long-running operation (LRO).  It is known that SDKs do not need to generate type names for such ErrCode ReasonMsg` statement. The error code is the string reported in compiler output.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n//suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-providerhub/no-identifier-property-in-array-item\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"Error items have no unique identifier.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n/** An array of details about specific errors that led to this reported error. */\\\\r\\\\ndetails: Error[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-Requirement.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Renaming Specs\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Requirement\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Renaming Specs\\\\n# TypeSpec-Requirement.md\\\\n\\\\n# Renaming Specs\\\\n\\\\nThe check may return a \\\\\\\"false positive\\\\\\\" if you rename an existing spec folder in a PR, since the new name doesn't exist in `main`.  You can use a suppression in these cases.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n\\\\nHear directly from teams who have successfully transitioned to TypeSpec Azure and learn about their experiences:\\\\n\\\\n### Azure Batch\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EUkgwSc69lpPsBjQBfLfMEgB0WCTBe9x7ozU8VNK2s8mAw?e=1MIXZi)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"There's definitions in Swagger, but \\u2026 TypeSpec has much more flexibility when it comes to doing things like mix or not mixing in traits and defining core things that you export.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I want to highlight the tooling improvements, like not having to figure out how to install things locally [like Swagger tooling], having it all in the same tool set that includes the emitters and things like that is really nice. The VS code integration right out of the box is something I've really liked.\\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n### MS Learn\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EXjQ3t7i-z9BpxVUgZVcS6QBxjLYdRLUquX2y8xczNxfbA?e=nesl3Q)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\u201cOne of the highlights [of using TypeSpec] was our ability to author API specs in a very simple and intuitive language. This meant that even [our PMs] who are not engineers were able to understand these API specifications. They could review them, make comments, and participate in designing those APIs.\\u201d\\\\n\\\\n### Azure AI Content Safety\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EdlE2PYtZ9BKoXQ-R0h-O10B9RidePBT4mwB1JgIqRC01A?e=JRneI2)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I find TypeSpec to be much simpler to learn and write compared to Swagger. In my experience, Swagger often encounters many conflicts due to its JSON format. TypeSpec proves to be a much better alternative as it allows everyone to work independently on their own sections, making it more user-friendly. Furthermore, TypeSpec allows for the separate definition of models and routes. So, from my perspective, it's a superior choice at present.\\\\\\\"\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"troubleshoot#suppresswarnings.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"How to suppress warnings\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/troubleshoot/suppresswarnings\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to suppress warnings\\\\n# troubleshoot#suppresswarnings.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to suppress warnings\\\\n\\\\nThis article helps you to suppress warning messages generated by TypeSpec and libraries.\\\\n\\\\n## Symptoms\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec core and libraries could generate and output warning messages based on linting rules.\\\\n\\\\n## Cause\\\\n\\\\nThese linting rules are introduced to ensure high-quality specs being generated. Sometimes they are used to call out areas needs developer attention to meet library or organization guidelines.\\\\n\\\\n## Workaround\\\\n\\\\nSome of the rules after review can be suppressed to get clean compile outputs using `#suppress ErrCode ReasonMsg` statement. The error code is the string reported in compiler output.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n//suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-providerhub/no-identifier-property-in-array-item\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"Error items have no unique identifier.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n/** An array of details about specific errors that led to this reported error. */\\\\r\\\\ndetails: Error[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\\n\\\\n# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nendpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Have observed some RPs have leveraged from commonTypes but renamed as PrivateEndpointConnectionResource in their tsp file.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n2. Avocado error: I have removed an API revokeCertificate and added a new api revokeCertificates which takes an array. \\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nHow do I fix both errors?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n [Added private endpoint connection, bulk revocation and c2pa certificate type by amritas \\u00b7 Pull Requ\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24553)\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nModel validation Error - Additional properties not allowed: groupIds, privateLinkServiceConnectionState,privateEndpoint,provisioningState\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nPEC contract - \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.CodeSigning;\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Private endpoint connection resource.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection\\\\r\\\\n    is ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnectionProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n    ...PrivateEndpointConnectionParameter;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations(PrivateEndpointConnection)\\\\r\\\\ninterface PrivateEndpointConnections {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Get a specific private connection */\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Create a Private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Delete the private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** List private endpoint connections on the given resource */\\\\r\\\\n  list is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\n\\\\nlistPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\r\\\\nThis will then get consumed by teams authoring Azure APIs. As such, they have the Azure linting in place (naming conventions and whatnot).\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe wanted to know whether definitions can also come with suppressions (not inline, as this definition is auto-importer on a regular basis), which would apply ONLY to the definitions we share, not to the rest of the consumer's project?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nThanks!\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nsuppression can only be provided inline for now. Linter rules can be disabled globally but that would apply to the whole project, can't filter by files\\\\n\\\\noperations to any resourc,e see: \\\\r\\\\n[typespec-azure/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-end\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-endpoints.tsp#L69-L94)\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointConnectionResource;\\\\r\\\\nalias PrivateEndpointOperations = PrivateEndpoints\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cEmployee, EmployeeProperties\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  getPrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.Read\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdatePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.CreateOrUpdateAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  updatePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.CustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  deletePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.DeleteAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\n\\\\nI have the below PR [adding shared limit typespec by parthshah2305 \\u00b7 Pull Request #24115 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24115) where some of the LintDiff validations are failing with the exception \\\\r\\\\n``` \\\\r\\\\n  Violation: file:///home/runner/work/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/after/specification/limit/resource-manager/Microsoft.Limit/Limit/stable/2025-08-15/Limit.json:578\\\\r\\\\n    Level: error\\\\r\\\\n    Code: RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel\\\\r\\\\n    Message: Model definition 'SharingDetail' must have the properties 'name', 'id' and 'type' in its hierarchy and these properties must be marked as readonly.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThis particular model is defined as follows - \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel SharingDetail {\\\\r\\\\n  role: SharingRole;\\\\r\\\\n  sharedLimits?: QuotaLimitProperties[];\\\\r\\\\n  guestSubscriptions?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  host?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nIs it possible have a suppression for this validation? If so, how?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nthe link for lintdiff suppressions:\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nyou probably want to fix this in your spec, not suppress the error\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nYou need to fix check \\\\\\\"TypeSpec Validation\\\\\\\" in your PR, before other check results will even be valid.  This is documented in the \\\\\\\"next steps to merge\\\\\\\" comment in your PR.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Model validations are failing although am referring from common-types\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\n1. I have reused the model Private endpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Have observed some RPs have leveraged from commonTypes but renamed as PrivateEndpointConnectionResource in their tsp file.\\\\n\\\\nis ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Create a Private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Delete the private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** List private endpoint connections on the given resource */\\\\r\\\\n  list is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateLink is ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateLinkResourceProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...PrivateLinkResourceParameter;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n updated the operationId and it worked. Let me know if the PrivateEndpointConnection should be a customized name or can retain same name as in commonTypes?\\\\r\\\\n Would this be guided by the reviewer?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nLooking at your PR, it seems that the avocado error is the only remaining one - this is just reporting that you have removed an API.  If you do not need to continue supporting the older preview, you might consider removing it,  otherwise, this is an error you can safely suppress (https://aka.ms/ci-fix is a great link to remember, as it has links to all kinds of useful info about ci errors, including a link to the suppression guides).\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nFor PrivateEndpointConnections, RPs have done both, as the name of the private endpoint connection type doesn't really matter to the API, however, there is a new template that greatly simplifies adding private endpoint connection operations to any resourc,e see: \\\\r\\\\n[typespec-azure/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-end\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-endpoints.tsp#L69-L94)\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointConnectionResource;\\\\r\\\\nalias PrivateEndpointOperations = PrivateEndpoints\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Only enable emitter2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/configuration/configuration\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Only enable emitter2\\\\n### `linter` - Setting Up Linters\\\\n# handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Only enable emitter2\\\\n\\\\n### `linter` - Setting Up Linters\\\\n\\\\nThis allows you to configure the linter rules to be enabled in this repository. When referencing a rule or ruleset, use their ID, which follows the format `\\\\u003clibraryName\\\\u003e:\\\\u003cruleName\\\\u003e`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nlinter:\\\\r\\\\n  extends: # Extend `recommended` ruleset from @typespec/best-practices library\\\\r\\\\n    - \\\\\\\"@typespec/best-practices/recommended\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  enable: # Explicitly enable some rules\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/best-practices/no-x\\\\\\\": true\\\\r\\\\n  disable: # Disable some rules defined in one of the ruleset extended.\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/best-practices/no-y\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"This rule cannot be applied in this project because X\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"extending-typespec#basics.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Creating a TypeSpec Library\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/extending-typespec/basics\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Creating a TypeSpec Library\\\\n## Step 1: Initial setup\\\\n### e. Create `lib.ts`\\\\n# extending-typespec#basics.md\\\\n\\\\n# Creating a TypeSpec Library\\\\n\\\\n## Step 1: Initial setup\\\\n\\\\n### e. Create `lib.ts`\\\\n\\\\nOpen `./src/lib.ts` and create your library definition that registers your library with the TypeSpec compiler and defines any diagnostics your library will emit. Make sure to export the library definition as `$lib`.\\\\r\\\\n:::caution\\\\r\\\\nIf `$lib` is not accessible from your library package (for example, `import {$lib} from \\\\\\\"my-library\\\\\\\";`), some features such as linting and emitter option validation will not be available.\\\\r\\\\n:::\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typescript\\\\r\\\\nimport { createTypeSpecLibrary } from \\\\\\\"@typespec/compiler\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nexport const $lib = createTypeSpecLibrary({\\\\r\\\\n  name: \\\\\\\"myLibrary\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  diagnostics: {},\\\\r\\\\n} as const);\\\\r\\\\n// Optional but convenient, these are meant to be used locally in your library.\\\\r\\\\nexport const { reportDiagnostic, createDiagnostic } = $lib;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nDiagnostics are used for linters and decorators, which are covered in subsequent topics.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\\n## suppressions.yaml\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\\n\\\\n## suppressions.yaml\\\\n\\\\nFile `suppressions.yaml` is used for all checks created in 2024 or later, like\\\\r\\\\n`TypeSpec Requirement` and `TypeSpec Validation`.\\\\r\\\\nFor simplicity, we recommend adding all suppressions to a single file at the root of your spec folder:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nspecification/myservice/suppressions.yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAlternatively, you can use multiple files in separate folders.  Currently, tools will use the first\\\\r\\\\ninstance of `suppressions.yaml` found walking up the directory tree.  We are planning\\\\r\\\\nfuture support for \\\\\\\"merging\\\\\\\" files up the hierarchy.\\\\r\\\\nA suppression follows this general format:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- tool: ToolName\\\\r\\\\n  path: applies/to/**/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Why this can't be fixed\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n`path` uses \\\\\\\"glob\\\\\\\" matching.  For syntax, see https://www.npmjs.com/package/minimatch.\\\\r\\\\nScope your `path` as narrowly as possible.  For example, if a suppression only applies\\\\r\\\\nto a single version of your spec:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"extending-typespec#linters.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Linters\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/extending-typespec/linters\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Linters\\\\n## Creating a linter\\\\n### Register the rules\\\\n# extending-typespec#linters.md\\\\n\\\\n# Linters\\\\n\\\\n## Creating a linter\\\\n\\\\n### Register the rules\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- cspell:disable-next-line --\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\nExport a `$linter` variable from your library entrypoint:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`ts title=\\\\\\\"index.ts\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nexport { $linter } from \\\\\\\"./linter.js\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`ts title=\\\\\\\"linter.ts\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport { defineLinter } from \\\\\\\"@typespec/compiler\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n// Import the rule defined previously\\\\r\\\\nimport { requiredDocRule } from \\\\\\\"./rules/required-doc.rule.js\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nexport const $linter = defineLinter({\\\\r\\\\n  // Include all the rules your linter is defining here.\\\\r\\\\n  rules: [requiredDocRule],\\\\r\\\\n  // Optionally a linter can provide a set of rulesets\\\\r\\\\n  ruleSets: {\\\\r\\\\n    recommended: {\\\\r\\\\n      // (optional) A ruleset takes a map of rules to explicitly enable\\\\r\\\\n      enable: { [`@typespec/my-linter/${requiredDocRule.name}`]: true },\\\\r\\\\n      // (optional) A rule set can extend another rule set\\\\r\\\\n      extends: [\\\\\\\"@typespec/best-practices/recommended\\\\\\\"],\\\\r\\\\n      // (optional) A rule set can disable a rule enabled in a ruleset it extended.\\\\r\\\\n      disable: {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"`@typespec/best-practices/no-a\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"This doesn't apply in this ruleset.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      },\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n});\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhen referencing a rule or ruleset (in `enable`, `extends`, `disable`), you must use the rule or rule set id, which is in this format: `\\\\u003clibraryName\\\\u003e/\\\\u003cruleName\\\\u003e`.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi Team, \\\\r\\\\nI am releasing a new API version and looks there is a new validation to check existing swagger with new tsp file  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\\\\\" \\\\r\\\\nWe want to keep both old and new api versoins. What is the suggestion here? Do you suggest to create different TSP file for each version/use versioning in existing TSP?  \\\\r\\\\nIf second case, can you share some example where APIs/Properties are added/removed in a newer version\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe idea behind TypeSpec versioning is to model the diffs in your API, encouraging best practices for API evolution. If you have questions about modeling particular changes, feel free to ask.\\\\r\\\\nAbout your concern: fixing a new validation causing changes to older APIs\\u2014this usually happens when new changes are added without using the appropriate version decorators. For example:\\\\r\\\\nIf you added properties or made a property optional, but didn\\u2019t annotate them with @added or @madeOptional, then they would apply to all versions by default, including older ones.\\\\r\\\\nThat\\u2019s likely why your stable version (e.g., 2024-12-01) got unintentionally updated when you only meant to target 2025-07-01-preview.\\\\r\\\\nTo avoid this, always use decorators like @added and @madeOptional to indicate version-specific changes.\\\\r\\\\nAs for the location field and the read/create mutability warning:\\\\r\\\\nThat rule is a warning meant to be advisory. In your case, it doesn\\u2019t seem to apply\\u2014so this is a good example where you should not change the service behavior just to satisfy a linting rule. It's fine to ignore the warning here.\\\\r\\\\nRegarding your question on renaming an API response (e.g., from MoveResponse to MoveResult):\\\\r\\\\nIf the new name is meant for a specific version, ensure it\\u2019s versioned properly in your TypeSpec. In your repro, the naming appears correct\\u2014MoveResult in 2021-10-01-preview, and MoveResponse in 2024-10-01-preview\\u2014so it\\u2019s working as expected.\\\\r\\\\nFinally, for adding or removing a parameter in only the new version:\\\\r\\\\nUnfortunately, you can\\u2019t directly decorate a spread parameter. The best way is to use operation-specific parameters, which you can decorate with versioning decorators. You could alternatively decorate the core parameter definition (e.g., with an augment decorator), but that would affect every usage\\u2014so for localized changes, use operation-specific ones. Since this is a method parameter, the APIs are equivalent and the change has no SDK impact.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion, \\\\r\\\\nCI has been failing constantly for our PR ([Azure Load Testing\\\\\\\\] Add 2025-03-01-preview Data-Plane APIs by Harshan01 \\u00b7 Pull Request #32585 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/32585)) for Typespec Validation step. The logs show that we are missing the Go SDK configuration and I am able to produce this error locally as well. However, our service doesnt have a Go SDK and we are not planning to put it in scope right now. This check has suddenly started failing for our PRs, what should we do?\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nExecuting rule\\uff1aSdkTspConfigVa1idation\\\\r\\\\n[SdkTspconfigVa1idation]\\uff1avalidation failed\\uff0e\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\\\\\\"\\uff0ePlease add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject\\u4e00spans\\u201c\\uff0ePlease add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject\\u4e00spans.\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\\\\\\"\\uff0ePlease add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\\\\\\"\\uff0ePlease add\\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\nPlease See https://aka.ms/azsdk/spec-gen-sdk-config for more info\\uff0e\\\\r\\\\nFor additional information on TypeSpec validation, please refer to https://aka.ms/azsdk/specs/typespec-validation.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nSuppressing go specific rules worked for me (locally, checking CI now). Thanks Mike. Also FYI Darren Cohen. Here's our suppression file:\\\\r\\\\n```yml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    - tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  sub-rules:\\\\r\\\\n    # Suppress validation for a Go emitter options\\\\r\\\\n    - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# After migration - response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"Currently, TypeSpec suppression rules can only be provided inline within the TypeSpec files themselves. There is no supported mechanism to package suppressions with a shared definitions library such that they apply only to the imported definitions and not to the rest of the consumer's project. Linter rules can be disabled globally in the consumer's project, but this would affect the entire project and cannot be scoped to just the imported definitions. Therefore, if you need to suppress specific linting rules for your shared definitions, you must do so inline in those TypeSpec files. There is no way to ship a definitions package with scoped suppressions that are automatically applied only to those definitions when imported.\", \"ground_truth\": \"suppression can only be provided inline for now. Linter rules can be disabled globally but that would apply to the whole project, can't filter by files\"}"}]

knowledge_match_unexpected_refs.title: Handling multiple API versions using typespec

testcase: what's typespec

expected.answer:
TypeSpec is a language and toolset developed by Microsoft for defining APIs and data models in a structured, reusable, and extensible way. It is similar to TypeScript in syntax, but is specifically designed for describing the shape and behavior of APIs (such as REST, gRPC, or GraphQL), not for general-purpose programming.
TypeSpec allows you to:
Define the interface of your API, including operations, request/response models, and error handling.
Generate artifacts such as OpenAPI (Swagger) specifications, SDKs, and documentation from a single source of truth.
Enforce API design consistency and reduce errors, especially in large organizations or when following strict guidelines (like Azure's API standards).
Reuse and extend models and patterns using TypeSpec libraries and templates.
For Azure, TypeSpec has dedicated extensions and libraries that help you follow Azure API guidelines and make it easier to build ARM (Azure Resource Manager) and data-plane services. Using TypeSpec leads to APIs that are easier to review, more consistent, and better supported by tooling.
You can get started by installing the TypeSpec CLI and using templates to quickly scaffold a project. For more information, see the official documentation linked below.

actual.answer: TypeSpec is a modern, open-source language and toolset developed by Microsoft for defining cloud service APIs, including both data plane and management plane APIs for Azure. It provides a structured way to describe the shape and behavior of data and services, allowing you to generate OpenAPI specifications, client code, documentation, and other artifacts directly from your API definitions. TypeSpec uses a compact, JavaScript-like syntax and supports advanced features such as templates, decorators, and extensibility through libraries. For Azure, TypeSpec is now the mandatory standard for authoring new API specifications, ensuring consistency, efficiency, and high-quality developer experiences across all Azure services. TypeSpec also offers enhanced tooling, including VS Code integration, early error detection, and support for non-technical stakeholders to participate in API design and review.

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: How to reserve \\\"x-ms-discriminator-value\\\"\\n\\nquestion: I'm doing migration for an swagger project.\\nthe old version swagger is:\\n```\\n\\\"AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest\\\": {\\n\\\"type\\\": \\\"object\\\",\\n\\\"title\\\": \\\"AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest\\\",\\n\\\"properties\\\": {\\n\\\"recoveryPointId\\\": {\\n\\\"type\\\": \\\"string\\\"\\n}\\n},\\n\\\"required\\\": [\\n\\\"recoveryPointId\\\"\\n],\\n\\\"allOf\\\": [\\n{\\n\\\"$ref\\\": \\\"#/definitions/AzureBackupRestoreRequest\\\"\\n}\\n],\\n\\\"x-ms-discriminator-value\\\": \\\"AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest\\\"\\n},\\n```\\nthe converted typespec is:\\n```\\n@discriminator(\\\"objectType\\\")\\nmodel AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest\\nextends AzureBackupRestoreRequest {\\nrecoveryPointId: string;\\n}\\n@discriminator(\\\"objectType\\\")\\nmodel AzureBackupRestoreRequest {\\nobjectType: string;\\n/**\\n* Gets or sets the restore target information.\\n*/\\nrestoreTargetInfo: RestoreTargetInfoBase;\\n/**\\n* Gets or sets the type of the source data store.\\n*/\\nsourceDataStoreType: SourceDataStoreType;\\n/**\\n* Fully qualified Azure Resource Manager ID of the datasource which is being recovered.\\n*/\\nsourceResourceId?: string;\\n/**\\n* ResourceGuardOperationRequests on which LAC check will be performed\\n*/\\nresourceGuardOperationRequests?: string[];\\n/**\\n* Contains information of the Identity Details for the BI.\\n* If it is null, default will be considered as System Assigned.\\n*/\\nidentityDetails?: IdentityDetails;\\n}\\n```\\nand the generated swagger from typespec is:\\n```\\n\\\"AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest\\\": {\\n\\\"type\\\": \\\"object\\\",\\n\\\"properties\\\": {\\n\\\"objectType\\\": {\\n\\\"type\\\": \\\"string\\\"\\n},\\n\\\"recoveryPointId\\\": {\\n\\\"type\\\": \\\"string\\\"\\n}\\n},\\n\\\"discriminator\\\": \\\"objectType\\\",\\n\\\"required\\\": [\\n\\\"objectType\\\",\\n\\\"recoveryPointId\\\"\\n],\\n\\\"allOf\\\": [\\n{\\n\\\"$ref\\\": \\\"#/definitions/AzureBackupRestoreRequest\\\"\\n}\\n]\\n},\\n```\\nThere has two problems:\\n1.The generated swagger missed x-ms-discriminator-value flag but add discriminator flag, does it by design?\\n2.The generated swagger has duplicate property 'objectType' since AzureBackupRestoreRequest already has this property\", \"response\": \"1. Regarding the missing `x-ms-discriminator-value` and the presence of the standard `discriminator` field in the generated Swagger: This is by design. TypeSpec uses the `@discriminator` decorator to indicate the property used for polymorphic serialization, and the OpenAPI emitter generates the standard OpenAPI `discriminator` field. The legacy `x-ms-discriminator-value` extension is not emitted by default in TypeSpec-generated OpenAPI, as the OpenAPI v3 specification now expects the standard `discriminator` field. Azure guidelines require using the standard discriminator mechanism for new specs. If you have a legacy client that depends on `x-ms-discriminator-value`, you would need to add it manually using an OpenAPI extension decorator, but this is discouraged for new Azure services.\\n\\n2. Regarding the duplicate `objectType` property: This is a modeling issue in your TypeSpec. When you use inheritance (`extends`) and both the base and derived models declare the same property (`objectType`), the property will appear in both places in the generated schema, resulting in duplication. To avoid this, only declare `objectType` in the base model (`AzureBackupRestoreRequest`). In the derived model (`AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest`), set the value of `objectType` as a string literal, like:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@discriminator(\\\"objectType\\\")\\nmodel AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest extends AzureBackupRestoreRequest {\\n  objectType: \\\"AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest\\\";\\n  recoveryPointId: string;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis ensures that the derived model sets the discriminator value correctly and does not duplicate the property definition. The generated OpenAPI will have the correct discriminator mapping and only one `objectType` property per schema.\\n\\nSummary:\\n- The absence of `x-ms-discriminator-value` is by design; use the standard `discriminator` field for new specs.\\n- Avoid duplicate discriminator properties by only declaring them in the base model and setting their value as a literal in derived models.\", \"ground_truth\": \"Let's address both of your issues with the TypeSpec migration and generated Swagger:\\n1. Missing x-ms-discriminator-value and presence of discriminator:\\nYes, this is by design. The TypeSpec emitter uses the standard OpenAPI 3 discriminator property, not the Azure-specific x-ms-discriminator-value. The @discriminator decorator in TypeSpec results in the discriminator field in the generated OpenAPI, as per the latest OpenAPI and Azure SDK standards. This approach provides better compatibility with code generators and client SDKs. The use of x-ms-discriminator-value is not needed when the discriminator field is present and correctly configured.\\nSee the TypeSpec documentation and Azure guidelines for more.\\n2. Duplicate objectType property in generated Swagger:\\nThis is a known limitation of how inheritance and discriminator are currently handled in TypeSpec to OpenAPI conversion. If both the base (AzureBackupRestoreRequest) and the derived model (AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest) define the objectType property, OpenAPI will reflect both in the derived model, leading to apparent duplication.\\nThis does not cause functional issues, but it can be confusing. The current best practice is to only define the discriminator property (objectType) in the base model and set its value in the derived models, rather than redefining the property. In TypeSpec, this would look like:\\n```\\n@discriminator(\\\"objectType\\\")\\nmodel AzureBackupRestoreRequest {\\nobjectType: string;\\n// ... other properties ...\\n}\\nmodel AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest extends AzureBackupRestoreRequest {\\nobjectType: \\\"AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest\\\";\\nrecoveryPointId: string;\\n}\\n```\\nThis way, the objectType property is only defined in the base model, and the derived model just sets its value. This should prevent duplication in the emitted Swagger.\\nAction Items:\\nRefactor your TypeSpec so that only the base model defines the discriminator property (objectType), and the derived models assign its value.\\nDo not worry about x-ms-discriminator-value not being present: it is not required when the standard discriminator property is used.\"}"}]
