Let's start with a basic example. Assume we have a service with a single API that returns a list of widgets. We can define that API like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\nusing Rest;\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Contoso Widget Manager\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Contoso.WidgetManager;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@error\\\\r\\\\nmodel Error {\\\\r\\\\n  code: string;\\\\r\\\\n  message?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nop list(): Widget[] | Error;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNow, let's suppose that in version 2 of the service, we add a get operation to retrieve a single widget. We can add that like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1,\\\\r\\\\n  v2,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/widget\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop list(): Widget[] | Error;\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/widget/{id}\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop get(...Resource.KeysOf\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e): Widget | Error;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNow, let's suppose that in version 3 of the service, we realize that `name` is not accurate and that this field should be called `description`. Also, we decide that the description should be optional, not mandatory. We can implement these changes like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  widgetId: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v3, \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\n  description?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWe made the change to the actual model property so that it now reflects the correct name and optional nature of the property. Both the `@renamedFrom` and `@madeOptional` decorators indicate the version in which the change was made, and the `@renamedFrom` decorator also identifies the previous name of the property. This allows us to generate code that is aware of the change and can handle it appropriately.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI definition of `Widget` for version 3 reflects the change:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    description:\\\\n\\\\nname and optional nature of the property. Both the `@renamedFrom` and `@madeOptional` decorators indicate the version in which the change was made, and the `@renamedFrom` decorator also identifies the previous name of the property. This allows us to generate code that is aware of the change and can handle it appropriately.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI definition of `Widget` for version 3 reflects the change:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    description:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - id\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nHowever, the OpenAPI definition for versions 1 and 2 still reflect the original name and the mandatory nature of the property:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    name:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - id\\\\r\\\\n    - name\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis is a common pattern with the versioning decorators. The TypeSpec should represent the _current state_ of the API. The decorators indicate the version at which this definition became accurate and, depending on the decorator, the other parameters reflect the previous values to retain that information.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/typespec-for-openapi-dev\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n## Schema Object\\\\n### allOf and polymorphism using allOf\\\\n# getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n\\\\n## Schema Object\\\\n\\\\n### allOf and polymorphism using allOf\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec supports single inheritance of models with the `extends` keyword. This construct can be used to produce an `allOf` with a single element (the parent schema) in OpenAPI. For example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec title=main.tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  meow: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  bark: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec does not currently provide a means to produce an `allOf` with more than one element -- these are generally treated as \\\\\\\"composition\\\\\\\" in code generators and thus better represented in TypeSpec with the spread operator.\\\\r\\\\nModels with a `@discriminator` decorator can be extended to produce polymorphic schemas in either OpenAPI v2 or v3 using `allOf`.\\\\r\\\\nThis schema produced for the base model will be defined with a `discriminator` property and schemas for the child models will `allOf` the base schema and add additional properties.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminator(\\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  weight?: float32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  meow?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  bark?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\ngenerates:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nCat:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      enum:\\\\r\\\\n        - cat\\\\r\\\\n    meow:\\\\r\\\\n      type: integer\\\\r\\\\n      format: int32\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - kind\\\\r\\\\n  allOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Pet\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nDog:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      enum:\\\\r\\\\n        - dog\\\\r\\\\n    bark:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - kind\\\\r\\\\n  allOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Pet\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      description: Discriminator property for Pet.\\\\r\\\\n    name:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    weight:\\\\r\\\\n      type: number\\\\r\\\\n      format: float\\\\r\\\\n  discriminator:\\\\r\\\\n    propertyName: kind\\\\r\\\\n    mapping:\\\\r\\\\n      cat: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      dog: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - name\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"emitters#openapi3#openapi.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"OpenAPI v3 emitter\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/openapi3/openapi\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# OpenAPI v3 emitter\\\\n## Model Composition\\\\n### Extends Keyword\\\\n# emitters#openapi3#openapi.md\\\\n\\\\n# OpenAPI v3 emitter\\\\n\\\\n## Model Composition\\\\n\\\\n### Extends Keyword\\\\n\\\\nThe `extends` keyword creates an inheritance relationship:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  breed: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn OpenAPI, this creates a schema `Dog` that references the schema `Pet` using `allOf`.\\\\r\\\\n#### Discriminated Union with Extends\\\\r\\\\nYou can create discriminated type hierarchies using the `@discriminator` decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminator(\\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  kind: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\"; // Must be a literal string value\\\\r\\\\n  breed: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\"; // Must be a literal string value\\\\r\\\\n  whiskerCount: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis creates a discriminator object in the OpenAPI schema with a mapping from discriminator values to schemas.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure REST API Specification Directory Structure\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure REST API Specification Directory Structure\\\\n# Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure REST API Specification Directory Structure\\\\n\\\\nThis article provides a comprehensive guide to the recommended directory structure and folder layout for Azure REST API specifications within the `specification` folder. The structure outlined here is designed to support both ARM (Azure Resource Manager) and data-plane services while maintaining compatibility with both TypeSpec-based and OpenAPI-based API development workflows.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e [!IMPORTANT]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e The structure described in this article is the **recommended standard** for all new Azure services. While some existing services may follow legacy patterns for historical reasons, all new services must adopt this structure. We are actively working on migrating legacy patterns to align with these guidelines.\\\\n\\\\n## Key concepts and terminology\\\\n\\\\nTo better understand the directory structure, it's essential to familiarize yourself with these key concepts as defined in the [glossary]:\\\\r\\\\n- **Service**: A customer-facing Azure service (e.g., Azure Key Vault, Azure Container Registry)\\\\r\\\\n- **Organization**: The Azure team or group responsible for one or more services\\\\r\\\\n- **Resource Provider Namespace (RPNS)**: The ARM namespace for resource management operations (e.g., `Microsoft.KeyVault`)\\\\r\\\\n- **API Version**: All Azure services use the YYYY-MM-DD(-preview) format for consistent versioning.\\\\n\\\\n## Overview of the folder structure\\\\n\\\\nThe `specification` folder follows a hierarchical organization designed to accommodate both ARM and data-plane services. The structure ensures clear separation between different service types while maintaining consistency across all Azure service specifications.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nspecification/\\\\r\\\\n\\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/\\\\r\\\\n    \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 cspell.yaml                     # Spell-check configuration\\\\r\\\\n    \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 resource-manager/               # ARM services\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2502   \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cRPNS\\\\u003e/                    # Resource Provider Namespace\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2502       \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cservice1\\\\u003e/             # Individual service\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2502       \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cservice2\\\\u003e/             # Individual service\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 data-plane/                    # Data-plane services\\\\r\\\\n        \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cservice1\\\\u003e/                 # Individual service\\\\r\\\\n        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cservice2\\\\u003e/                 # Individual service\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Organization structure:**\\\\r\\\\nEach organization folder contains up to two main directories:\\\\r\\\\n- **One `resource-manager/\\\\u003cRPNS\\\\u003e/` folder** for ARM services (where `\\\\u003cRPNS\\\\u003e` is the Resource Provider Namespace) containing **one or more** `\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e` folders\\\\r\\\\n- **One `data-plane/` folder** for non-ARM APIs containing **one or more** `\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e` folders\\\\r\\\\n**Important notes:**\\\\r\\\\n- Organizations may have only ARM services, only data-plane services, or both\\\\r\\\\n- The presence of both directories is not mandatory - it depends on the services offered by the organization\\\\n\\\\n### ARM services: `resource-manager/\\\\u003cRPNS\\\\u003e` folder\\\\n\\\\nThe `\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/resource-manager/\\\\u003cRPNS\\\\u003e` folder corresponds to an ARM **Resource Provider (RP) namespace**. This namespace defines the scope of resource management operations for the organization's ARM services.\\\\r\\\\n**Example structure:**\\\\r\\\\n- RPNS example: `Microsoft.Automation`\\\\r\\\\n- Full path: `specification/containerservice/resource-manager/Microsoft.ContainerService/aks`\\\\r\\\\n- Service: `aks` service within the `Microsoft.ContainerService` ARM Resource Provider namespace\\\\r\\\\nFor a complete list of Resource Providers, see the [Resource Provider list].\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e [!NOTE]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e **Legacy pattern to avoid**: Many Azure teams with a single ARM service historically placed it directly in `specification/\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/resource-manager/` instead of following the proper `specification/\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/resource-manager/\\\\u003cRPNS\\\\u003e/\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e` structure. This legacy pattern is deprecated and strongly discouraged for new services.\\\\n\\\\n### Data-plane services: `data-plane` folders\\\\n\\\\nThe `\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/data-plane` folder contains data-plane service APIs, which differ from ARM services in several key ways:\\\\r\\\\n**Key characteristics:**\\\\r\\\\n- Contains data-plane service APIs (not ARM service APIs)\\\\r\\\\n- No Resource Provider Namespace (`\\\\u003cRPNS\\\\u003e`) concept applies\\\\r\\\\n- Each service gets its own folder directly under `data-plane/`\\\\r\\\\n- Simpler structure: `\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/data-plane/\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\nEach `\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/data-plane` folder contains one or more `\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e` folders corresponding to the data-plane services owned by the organization.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e [!NOTE]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e **Legacy patterns to avoid**: Some organizations historically used additional grouping folders like `\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/data-plane/\\\\u003cgroupingDir\\\\u003e/\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e` or prefixed service names with `Azure.\\\\u003cSomeService\\\\u003e` or `Microsoft.\\\\u003cSomeService\\\\u003e`. These legacy patterns are deprecated and strongly discouraged for new services.\\\\n\\\\n## Service folder structure\\\\n\\\\nEvery service folder follows a consistent structure regardless of whether it's an ARM or data-plane service. This consistency simplifies navigation and tooling across all Azure services.\\\\r\\\\n**Standard service folder paths:**\\\\r\\\\n- **ARM services**: `specification/\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/resource-manager/\\\\u003cRPNS\\\\u003e/\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n- **Data-plane services**: `specification/\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/data-plane/\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e`\\\\n\\\\n### Contents of a service folder\\\\n\\\\nEach service folder contains a standardized set of files and directories organized by their purpose and the development approach used (TypeSpec vs. OpenAPI).\\\\r\\\\nA service folder contains the following elements:\\\\r\\\\n**TypeSpec files** (for TypeSpec-based services):\\\\r\\\\n- `main.tsp` - Main TypeSpec entry point for the service\\\\r\\\\n- `tspconfig.yaml` - TypeSpec compilation configuration with OpenAPI/SDK emitter options\\\\r\\\\n- Additional `*.tsp` files - Supporting TypeSpec files for the service\\\\r\\\\n- `examples/\\\\u003capiVersion\\\\u003e/` - TypeSpec examples organized by API version\\\\r\\\\n**README and configuration files**:\\\\r\\\\n- `readme.md` - Central file that groups APIs into different tags for tooling purposes\\\\r\\\\n- `readme.lang.md` - Language-specific README files for SDK generation (deprecated when TypeSpec is used)\\\\r\\\\n**Generated OpenAPI specifications**:\\\\r\\\\n- `stable/\\\\u003capiVersion\\\\u003e/` - Contains stable API version specifications\\\\r\\\\n- `preview/\\\\u003capiVersion\\\\u003e/` - Contains preview API version specifications\\\\r\\\\nThe `stable` and `preview` folders contain OpenAPI specifications in their respective [lifecycle stages][aka.ms/azsdk/api-versions], organized in `\\\\u003capiVersion\\\\u003e` subfolders for each service API version.\\\\n\\\\n### `\\\\u003capiVersion\\\\u003e` folders\\\\n\\\\nAPI version folders reflect the actual service API version, following Azure's standard `YYYY-MM-DD(-preview)` format for consistent versioning across all services.\\\\r\\\\n**Folder structure by service type:**\\\\r\\\\n**ARM services**:\\\\r\\\\n- `\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/resource-manager/\\\\u003cRPNS\\\\u003e/\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e/stable/\\\\u003cYYYY-MM-DD\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n- `\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/resource-manager/\\\\u003cRPNS\\\\u003e/\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e/preview/\\\\u003cYYYY-MM-DD-preview\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n**Data-plane services**:\\\\r\\\\n- `\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/data-plane/\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e/stable/\\\\u003cYYYY-MM-DD\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n- `\\\\u003corganization\\\\u003e/data-plane/\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e/preview/\\\\u003cYYYY-MM-DD-preview\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n**Contents of each API version folder:**\\\\r\\\\n- `.json` files containing OpenAPI specifications (typically emitted from TypeSpec)\\\\r\\\\n- `examples/` subfolder containing `.json` files with [`x-ms-examples`] content referenced from the OpenAPI specifications\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e [!NOTE]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e **TypeSpec examples organization**: The `examples/` folder under the `\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e` directory contains TypeSpec examples and serves as a superset of all API version examples. The TypeSpec team is actively working on new designs to reduce redundancy in example organization.\\\\r\\\\nFor detailed information about API versioning practices, see the [API versioning guidelines].\\\\n\\\\n## `specification/common-types`\\\\n\\\\nThe [`specification/common-types`] directory serves a special purpose in the repository structure, containing shared definitions that can be reused across all Azure service specifications.\\\\r\\\\n**Purpose and usage:**\\\\r\\\\n- Contains common models, types, and operations used across multiple Azure services\\\\r\\\\n- Enables consistency and reduces duplication across service specifications\\\\r\\\\n- Provides standardized definitions for common Azure patterns\\\\r\\\\n**Important limitations:**\\\\r\\\\nWhen you need to share definitions beyond those available in [`specification/common-types`], you must duplicate them in each service's own folder. This requirement ensures that each service maintains independent control over the versioning lifecycle of shared definitions.\\\\r\\\\n**Best practice for managing shared definitions:**\\\\r\\\\nTo minimize the maintenance burden of duplicate copies, service teams can implement a shared ownership pattern:\\\\r\\\\n1. **Designate an owner service** - The service that creates or updates the shared models becomes the owner.\\\\r\\\\n2. **Create a `sharable/` folder** - The owner service creates this folder to make definitions available for copying.\\\\r\\\\n3. **Use `copyFrom*Sharable` folders** - Other services create these folders to indicate copied content that should not be edited directly.\\\\r\\\\n**Example structure:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`diff\\\\r\\\\nspecification/compute/resource-manager/Microsoft.Compute/\\\\r\\\\n\\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 ComputeRP\\\\r\\\\n+\\u2502   \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 sharable/\\\\r\\\\n\\u2502   \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 *.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2502   \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2502   \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\u2502   \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 readme.md\\\\r\\\\n\\u2502   \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 preview/\\\\r\\\\n\\u2502   \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 stable/\\\\r\\\\n\\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 RecommenderRP\\\\r\\\\n+    \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 copyFromComputeSharable\\\\r\\\\n    \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 *.tsp\\\\r\\\\n    \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n    \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n    \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 readme.md\\\\r\\\\n    \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 preview/\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 stable/\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Naming guidelines for `specification` folder contents\\\\n\\\\nConsistent naming conventions across the repository improve readability and reduce ambiguity. Follow these guidelines when creating new folders and files:\\\\r\\\\n**Folder naming rules:**\\\\r\\\\n- Use singular forms (e.g., `keyvault` not `keyvaults`) to eliminate ambiguity for non-English speakers\\\\r\\\\n- Generic folder names should be lowercase\\\\r\\\\n- Resource Provider Namespace (`\\\\u003cRPNS\\\\u003e`) folders may use PascalCase (e.g., `KeyVault`)\\\\r\\\\n**File naming rules:**\\\\r\\\\n- Any casing is acceptable for file names\\\\r\\\\n- such.\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Example\\\\n\\\\n```typespec\\\\r\\\\n@customAzureResource\\\\r\\\\nmodel CustomResource {\\\\r\\\\n  id?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  type?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  properties?: CustomResourceProperties;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nmodel CustomResourceProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  displayName?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n### Swagger Output\\\\n\\\\n```json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"CustomResource\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      },\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      },\\\\r\\\\n {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n Convert component schemas into models\\\\n# emitters#openapi3#cli.md\\\\n\\\\n# OpenAPI3 to TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Examples\\\\n\\\\n### 1. Convert component schemas into models\\\\n\\\\nAll schemas present at `#/components/schemas` will be converted into a model or scalar as appropriate.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctable\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003eOpenAPI3\\\\u003c/td\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003eTypeSpec\\\\u003c/td\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/tr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- --\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yml\\\\r\\\\ncomponents:\\\\r\\\\n  schemas:\\\\r\\\\n    Widget:\\\\r\\\\n      type: object\\\\r\\\\n      required:\\\\r\\\\n        - id\\\\r\\\\n        - weight\\\\r\\\\n        - color\\\\r\\\\n      properties:\\\\r\\\\n        id:\\\\r\\\\n          type: string\\\\r\\\\n        weight:\\\\r\\\\n          type: integer\\\\r\\\\n          format: int32\\\\r\\\\n        color:\\\\r\\\\n          type: string\\\\r\\\\n          enum:\\\\r\\\\n            - red\\\\r\\\\n            - blue\\\\r\\\\n    uuid:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      format: uuid\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/td\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  weight: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  color: \\\\\\\"red\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"blue\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@format(\\\\\\\"uuid\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nscalar uuid extends string;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/td\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/tr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/table\\\\u003e\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#04-common-parameters.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Common Parameters\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/04-common-parameters\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Common Parameters\\\\n## Reusing Common Parameters Across Multiple Operations\\\\n### Example: OpenAPI Specification for Common Parameters\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#04-common-parameters.md\\\\n\\\\n# Common Parameters\\\\n\\\\n## Reusing Common Parameters Across Multiple Operations\\\\n\\\\n### Example: OpenAPI Specification for Common Parameters\\\\n\\\\nLet's take a closer look at how the common parameters model with the `spread` operator is represented in the generated OpenAPI specification by looking at the `deletePet` operation:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n//### Generated OpenAPI Specification:\\\\r\\\\npaths:\\\\r\\\\n  /pets/{petId}:\\\\r\\\\n    delete:\\\\r\\\\n      operationId: Pets_deletePet\\\\r\\\\n      parameters:\\\\r\\\\n        - name: petId\\\\r\\\\n          in: path\\\\r\\\\n          required: true\\\\r\\\\n          schema:\\\\r\\\\n            type: integer\\\\r\\\\n            format: int32\\\\r\\\\n        // highlight-start\\\\r\\\\n        - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/parameters/CommonParameters.requestID\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/parameters/CommonParameters.locale\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        - $ref: V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## 5. Azure Service Change Impact\\\\n### Table 2: Changes requiring a review with Azure's Breaking Change Review Board\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 5. Azure Service Change Impact\\\\n\\\\n### Table 2: Changes requiring a review with Azure's Breaking Change Review Board\\\\n\\\\nvalue |\\\\r\\\\n| Weaken output constraint (ex: max value 5 to 6) | Old client gets value it never expected |\\\\r\\\\n| Change default value | Old client doesn't expect new default behavior |\\\\r\\\\n| Change discriminator field value | Old client doesn't expect/send new value |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input parameter order in swagger | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameter order |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove body Content-Type (ex: application/json) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n| Add response code | Old client has no code to handle new response code |\\\\r\\\\n| Modify path/operation Id | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method name |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove protocol (ex: http) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n\\u00b2 Removing an extensible enum value typically happens when a service retires some feature (like a VM SKU). Retirements must be discussed with Azure Retirements Reviewers (\\\\u003chttps://dev.azure.com/msazure/AzureWiki/_wiki/wikis/AzureWiki.wiki/88597/Azure-Retirement-Policy-and-Process\\\\u003e). Based on the outcome this breaking change may be doable in a new api-version of the service. And, in some extreme cases, this breaking change may be doable in an existing api-version.\\\\n\\\\n**NOTE:** These changes are strongly discouraged:\\\\r\\\\n| Change | Why this change is breaking for old clients |\\\\r\\\\n|--------|---------------------------------------------|\\\\r\\\\n| Add pagination support | Old client expects response to include all results and will only ever see 1st page |\\\\r\\\\n| Add required input | Old client doesn't send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove input/output | Old client always sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add new output enum value | Old client will crash when deserializing |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove input/output enum value | Old client sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove extensible enum (string) value\\u00b2 | Old client sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input from optional to required | Old clients don't send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Change output from optional to required | New client doesn't expect nullable field (for some language SDKs) |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input/output required to optional | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameters |\\\\r\\\\n| Change case (ex: RBAC to Rbac) | Old client sends wrong case |\\\\r\\\\n| Change format (ex: minutes to time) | Old client can't parse new format |\\\\r\\\\n| Change data type (ex: bool to string) | Old client can't parse new type's value |\\\\r\\\\n| Widen input integer (ex: Int32 to Int64) | Old client doesn't expect larger value |\\\\r\\\\n| Widen output integer (ex: Int32 to Int64) | Old client loses precision |\\\\r\\\\n| Narrow input/output integer (ex: Int64 to Int32) | New service loses precision |\\\\r\\\\n| Strengthen input constraint (ex: max value 5 to 4) | Old client sends bigger value |\\\\r\\\\n| Weaken output constraint (ex: max value 5 to 6) | Old client gets value it never expected |\\\\r\\\\n| Change default value | Old client doesn't expect new default behavior |\\\\r\\\\n| Change discriminator field value | Old client doesn't expect/send new value |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input parameter order in swagger | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameter order |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove body Content-Type (ex: application/json) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n| Add response code |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"how do i use discriminated union\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# how do i use discriminated union\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# how do i use discriminated union\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI'm wondering if I can model mutually exclusive properties and came across this thread recommending discriminated union, but I'm not able to make it work. \\\\r\\\\nI want to have a model where only one property object can be specified. So only blobAccount xor onelakeAccount could be specified in this example:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel StorageDestination {\\\\r\\\\n  blobAccount : BlobAccount;\\\\r\\\\n  onelakeAccount: OneLakeAccount;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nGenerally, it is an anti-pattern to have a polymorphic resource type.  Instead of having one resource with two distinct rp-specific properties schemas, you generally should have two resources, or have a property of the rp-specific properties be polymorphic. \\\\r\\\\nDiscriminated unions are not yet handled by Azure emitters, so this isn't a good choice for Azure APIs.  You can use inheritance based discrimination instead. \\\\r\\\\nHere's a sample using inheritance-based discrimination for a property of the rp-specific resource properties. \\\\r\\\\nNote that you can use the 'kind' envelope property to make a resource polymorphic analogously, but this is, as I indicated, an anti-pattern.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"standard-library#built-in-decorators.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Built-in Decorators\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Built-in Decorators\\\\n## TypeSpec\\\\n### `@discriminator` {#@discriminator}\\\\n# standard-library#built-in-decorators.md\\\\n\\\\n# Built-in Decorators\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n### `@discriminator` {#@discriminator}\\\\n\\\\nSpecify the property to be used to discriminate this type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminator(propertyName: valueof string)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Target\\\\r\\\\n`Model`\\\\r\\\\n#### Parameters\\\\r\\\\n| Name | Type | Description |\\\\r\\\\n|------|------|-------------|\\\\r\\\\n| propertyName | [valueof `string`](#string) | The property name to use for discrimination |\\\\r\\\\n#### Examples\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminator(\\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet{ kind: string }\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat extends Pet {kind: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\", meow: boolean}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Pet  {kind: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\", bark: boolean}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"standard-library#built-in-data-types.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Built-in Data types\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-data-types\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Built-in Data types\\\\n## TypeSpec\\\\n### `DiscriminatedOptions` {#DiscriminatedOptions}\\\\n# standard-library#built-in-data-types.md\\\\n\\\\n# Built-in Data types\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n### `DiscriminatedOptions` {#DiscriminatedOptions}\\\\n\\\\nOptions for `@discriminated` decorator.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel DiscriminatedOptions\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Properties\\\\r\\\\n| Name | Type | Description |\\\\r\\\\n|------|------|-------------|\\\\r\\\\n| envelope? | `\\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\\| \\\\\\\"none\\\\\\\"` | How is the discriminated union serialized. |\\\\r\\\\n| discriminatorPropertyName? | [`string`](#string) | Name of the discriminator property |\\\\r\\\\n| envelopePropertyName? | [`string`](#string) | Name of the property envelopping the data Developers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/typespec-for-openapi-dev\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n## Parameter Object\\\\n### OpenAPI v3\\\\n# getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n\\\\n## Parameter Object\\\\n\\\\n### OpenAPI v3\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| `example`                    | `@example` on data types (e.g. models, scalars), `@opExample` to describe in-line parameters of operations      | Open API 3.0 only supports a single example when using `@example` on data types |\\\\r\\\\n| `examples`                   | `@example` on data types (e.g. models, scalars), `@opExample` to describe parameters/return types of operations | Open API 3.1 always outputs `examples` instead of `example`.                    |\\\\r\\\\n| `content`                    |                                                                                                                 | Not currently supported.                                                        |\\\\n\\\\nThe following fields of a parameter object are specific to OpenAPI v3:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI v3 `parameter` field | TypeSpec construct                                                                                              | Notes                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| ---------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `style`                      | `explode` parameter on `@query` or `@header` and `@encode` `@header`                                                                    |                                                                                 |\\\\r\\\\n| `schema`                     | parameter schema                                                                                                | see [Schema Object](#schema-object)                                             |\\\\r\\\\n| `deprecated`                 | `#deprecated` directive.                                                                                        |                                                                                 |\\\\r\\\\n| `example`                    | `@example` on data types (e.g. models, scalars), `@opExample` to describe in-line parameters of operations      | Open API 3.0 only supports a single example when using `@example` on data types |\\\\r\\\\n| `examples`                   | `@example` on data types (e.g. models, scalars), `@opExample` to describe parameters/return types of operations | Open API 3.1 always outputs `examples` instead of `example`. TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n### Azure Batch\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n\\\\n### Azure Batch\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EUkgwSc69lpPsBjQBfLfMEgB0WCTBe9x7ozU8VNK2s8mAw?e=1MIXZi)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"There's definitions in Swagger, but \\u2026 TypeSpec has much more flexibility when it comes to doing things like mix or not mixing in traits and defining core things that you export.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I want to highlight the tooling improvements, like not having to figure out how to install things locally [like Swagger tooling], having it all in the same tool set that includes the emitters and things like that is really nice. The VS code integration right out of the box is something I've really liked.\\\\\\\"\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Multiple layers of inheritance for discriminative model\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Multiple layers of inheritance for discriminative model\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Multiple layers of inheritance for discriminative model\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nLike this\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@discriminator(\\\\\\\"discountType\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel DiscountTypeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  discountType: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nmodel DiscountTypeCustomPrice extends DiscountTypeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  discountType: \\\\\\\"CustomPrice\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nmodel DiscountTypeCustomPriceMultiCurrency extends DiscountTypeCustomPrice {\\\\r\\\\n  discountType: \\\\\\\"CustomPriceMultiCurrency\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nDiscountTypeCustomPriceMultiCurrency is extending DiscountTypeCustomPrice, but these two have different discriminator values. How could I represent it?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nthis is not supported in TypeSpec with the inheritance based discriminator, I think we talked about that in the past and that was an anti pattern.\\\\r\\\\nYou could use discriminated union to represent that instead but I don' think they will be supported in the same way in emitters for now\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi everyone, \\\\r\\\\nI am making a property optional in typespec and to be a non-breaking change, I see that is required to have a default. However my change seems to also change the existing version instead of only the new version. \\\\r\\\\nBefore:\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists: SubResource[]; \\\\r\\\\nAfter:\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v2025_10_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists?: SubResource[] = #[]; \\\\r\\\\n1) How can I make the change in typespec so that the generation of the openapi jsons will not affect the existing version? Currently generation also adds the empty array default to the existing API version (2025-05-01) which causes the breaking change CI to flag.\\\\r\\\\n2) Is there a way I can default the SubResource[] array to null instead? \\\\r\\\\nThis is in accordance to the documentation here (Made optional with/without default case): [non-breaking-versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-core/rules/non-breaking-versioning/#-incorrect)\\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Release 2025-10-01-preview for DNS Resolver by jamesvoongms \\u00b7 Pull Request #24470 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-res\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24470)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should not add OpenApi extensions directly - x-ms-identifiers are automatically added based on the `@key` properties of a model,  or you should use the `@identifiers` decorator if you need to override the default setting. \\\\r\\\\nThe problem is that this is two changes (making a property optional and providing a default), but there is only versioning decoration for one change.  Compounding this, there is no versioning decoration for adding a default value, this is being tracked here: [Add additional versioning decorators \\u00b7 Issue #2761 \\u00b7 microsoft/typespec](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues/2761).  Ideally we should combine these two changes into a single decorator to promote non-breaking changes. \\\\r\\\\nMeanwhile, you can do this using the added/removed/rename pattern to replace one property with another property in a new version, as this example.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldStuff: string[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  stuff?: string[] = #[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_http_specs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"azure#client-generator-core#client-location#move-to-new-sub-client#main.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Usages for Test for @clientLocation decorator - moving operations between clients\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/azure-http-specs/specs/azure/client-generator-core/client-location/move-to-new-sub-client/main.tsp\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Usages for Test for @clientLocation decorator - moving operations between clients\\\\n## Scenario: Test moving an operation to a new sub client specified by string name.\\\\n# azure#client-generator-core#client-location#move-to-new-sub-client#main.md\\\\n\\\\n# Usages for Test for @clientLocation decorator - moving operations between clients\\\\n\\\\n## Scenario: Test moving an operation to a new sub client specified by string name.\\\\n\\\\nOperation `archiveProduct` from interface `ProductOperations` should be moved to a new sub client named \\\\\\\"ArchiveOperations\\\\\\\" using @clientLocation(\\\\\\\"ArchiveOperations\\\\\\\").\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` typespec\\\\r\\\\n// Scenario 1: Move an operation to a new sub client (string name)\\\\r\\\\ninterface ProductOperations {\\\\r\\\\n  @route(\\\\\\\"/products\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @get\\\\r\\\\n  listProducts(): void;\\\\r\\\\n  @route(\\\\\\\"/products/archive\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @post\\\\r\\\\n  @global.Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.clientLocation(\\\\\\\"ArchiveOperations\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  archiveProduct(): void;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi everyone, \\\\r\\\\nI am making a property optional in typespec and to be a non-breaking change, I see that is required to have a default. However my change seems to also change the existing version instead of only the new version. \\\\r\\\\nBefore:\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists: SubResource[]; \\\\r\\\\nAfter:\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v2025_10_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists?: SubResource[] = #[]; \\\\r\\\\n1) How can I make the change in typespec so that the generation of the openapi jsons will not affect the existing version? Currently generation also adds the empty array default to the existing API version (2025-05-01) which causes the breaking change CI to flag.\\\\r\\\\n2) Is there a way I can default the SubResource[] array to null instead? \\\\r\\\\nThis is in accordance to the documentation here (Made optional with/without default case): [non-breaking-versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-core/rules/non-breaking-versioning/#-incorrect)\\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Release 2025-10-01-preview for DNS Resolver by jamesvoongms \\u00b7 Pull Request #24470 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-res\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24470)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should not add OpenApi extensions directly - x-ms-identifiers are automatically added based on the `@key` properties of a model,  or you should use the `@identifiers` decorator if you need to override the default setting. \\\\r\\\\nThe problem is that this is two changes (making a property optional and providing a default), but there is only versioning decoration for one change.  Compounding this, there is no versioning decoration for adding a default value, this is being tracked here: [Add additional versioning decorators \\u00b7 Issue #2761 \\u00b7 microsoft/typespec](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues/2761).  Ideally we should combine these two changes into a single decorator to promote non-breaking changes. \\\\r\\\\nMeanwhile, you can do this using the added/removed/rename pattern to replace one property with another property in a new version, as this example.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldStuff: string[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  stuff?: string[] = #[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/typespec-for-openapi-dev\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n## Schema Object\\\\n### Polymorphism using anyOf and oneOf (OAS3)\\\\n# getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n\\\\n## Schema Object\\\\n\\\\n### Polymorphism using anyOf and oneOf (OAS3)\\\\n\\\\nPolymorphism can also be represented in OpenAPI v3 with `anyOf` or `oneOf` constructs.\\\\r\\\\nThese can be represented in TypeSpec with a union type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nunion Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  cat: Cat,\\\\r\\\\n  dog: Dog,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat {\\\\r\\\\n  meow?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  bark?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\ngenerates a Pet schema with `anyOf`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  anyOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe openapi emitter uses `anyOf` by default because the schemas may not be mutually exclusive.\\\\r\\\\nBut the `@oneOf` decorator of the OpenAPI library can be used to force the use of `oneOf` instead.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing OpenAPI;\\\\r\\\\n@oneOf\\\\r\\\\nunion Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  cat: Cat,\\\\r\\\\n  dog: Dog,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nproduces:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  oneOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo make Pet a discriminated union, add the `@discriminator` decorator and add the discriminator property\\\\r\\\\nwith a string literal value to each of the child schemas.\\\\r\\\\nView the [`@discriminated` documentation](https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators/#@discriminated) to learn how to further customize what is emitted.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminated(#{ envelope: \\\\\\\"none\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\nunion Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  cat: Cat,\\\\r\\\\n  dog: Dog,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  meow?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  bark?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nresults in the following schema for Pet:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  oneOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  discriminator:\\\\r\\\\n    propertyName: kind\\\\r\\\\n    mapping:\\\\r\\\\n      cat: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      dog: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Does TypeSpec have the option to achieve mutually exclusive?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Does TypeSpec have the option to achieve mutually exclusive?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Does TypeSpec have the option to achieve mutually exclusive?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe have 2 properties `awsCloudProfile`and `gcpCloudProfilein` our preperties in our typespec update. These 2 properties are mutually exclusive(ensuring that only one of `awsCloudProfile` or `gcpCloudProfile` can exist at a time). Besides setting both of them to optional, is there any other options in TypeSpec that we can achieve the mutually exclusive without causing a breaking change?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThere isn't currently a built-in way in TypeSpec to enforce mutual exclusivity between properties like `awsCloudProfile` and `gcpCloudProfile`.\\\\r\\\\nIn your PR, you're making both properties optional \\u2014 but that\\u2019s actually a breaking change. Clients may have previously assumed that `awsCloudProfile` was always present, and now that constraint is being relaxed, which breaks existing behavior.\\\\r\\\\nAzure's recommended pattern for such cases is to use **explicit discriminated unions** to simplify the client experience. That means defining a `CloudProfile` union with a `@discriminator(\\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\")` to clearly indicate which cloud provider the profile belongs to. For example:\\\\r\\\\n```typescript\\\\r\\\\n@discriminator(\\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nunion CloudProfile {\\\\r\\\\n  aws: AwsCloudProfile;\\\\r\\\\n  gcp: GcpCloudProfile;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nmodel AwsCloudProfile {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"aws\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  awsAccountId: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nmodel GcpCloudProfile {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"gcp\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  projectProperties?: GcpProjectProperties;\\\\r\\\\n  organizationProperties?: GcpOrganizationProperties;\\\\r\\\\n  isOrganization?: boolean = false;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nWith this structure, your `CloudConnectorProperties` model just needs a single `cloudProfile` property. It allows you to support AWS, GCP, or any other provider in future API versions without breaking changes.\\\\r\\\\nTo clarify a few key points:\\\\r\\\\n1. **Is the `kind` property set by the customer?**\\\\r\\\\n   Yes, it appears on the wire. In some SDKs, the customer needs to set it explicitly; in others, it may be inferred by the SDK type system.\\\\r\\\\n2. **Does `kind` already exist in your types?**\\\\r\\\\n   No, it doesn\\u2019t. This change would be a breaking change \\u2014 but one that allows forward compatibility when adding more cloud providers.\\\\r\\\\n3. **Would the `hostType` property still be needed?**\\\\r\\\\n   No, it would become redundant if you adopt this `@discriminator` union pattern.\\\\r\\\\nAs a side note: TypeSpec has introduced a `@discriminated` decorator for unions, which supports more flexible patterns, but it is not yet supported by all SDK emitters.\\\\n\\\\n2. **Does `kind` already exist in your types?**\\\\r\\\\n   No, it doesn\\u2019t. This change would be a breaking change \\u2014 but one that allows forward compatibility when adding more cloud providers.\\\\r\\\\n3. **Would the `hostType` property still be needed?**\\\\r\\\\n   No, it would become redundant if you adopt this `@discriminator` union pattern.\\\\r\\\\nAs a side note: TypeSpec has introduced a `@discriminated` decorator for unions, which supports more flexible patterns, but it is not yet supported by all SDK emitters. It\\u2019s under investigation and targeted for support around August. However, the `@discriminator` pattern (which you are using here) is already required to be supported by all SDK emitters and is safe to use today.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#generate-client-libraries#08types.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Generated Types\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/08types\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Generated Types\\\\n## Models\\\\n### Discriminator\\\\n# howtos#generate-client-libraries#08types.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Generated Types\\\\n\\\\n## Models\\\\n\\\\n### Discriminator\\\\n\\\\ninterface for type Cat.\\\\r\\\\nfunc (c *Cat) GetCat() *Cat { return c }\\\\r\\\\ntype Ragdoll struct {\\\\r\\\\n\\\\t// CONSTANT; undefinedField has constant value \\\\\\\"ragdoll\\\\\\\", any specified value is ignored.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\tKind *string\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// GetCat implements the CatClassification interface for type Ragdoll.\\\\r\\\\nfunc (e *Ragdoll) GetCat() *Cat {\\\\r\\\\n\\\\treturn \\\\u0026Cat{\\\\r\\\\n\\\\t\\\\tKind:     e.Kind,\\\\r\\\\n\\\\t}\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\ntype Siamese struct {\\\\r\\\\n\\\\t// CONSTANT; undefinedField has constant value \\\\\\\"siamese\\\\\\\", any specified value is ignored.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\tKind *string\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// GetCat implements the CatClassification interface for type Siamese.\\\\r\\\\nfunc (e *Siamese) GetCat() *Cat {\\\\r\\\\n\\\\treturn \\\\u0026Cat{\\\\r\\\\n\\\\t\\\\tKind:     e.Kind,\\\\r\\\\n\\\\t}\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/ClientTabItem\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/ClientTabs\\\\u003e\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec uses `@discriminator` decorator to add a discriminator to a model.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cClientTabs\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cClientTabItem lang=\\\\\\\"typespec\\\\\\\" \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\nClient emitters now only support a single way to represent a discriminated set in TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n1. Use model\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminator(\\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Siamese extends Cat response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"1. Regarding the missing `x-ms-discriminator-value` and the presence of the standard `discriminator` field in the generated Swagger: This is by design. TypeSpec uses the `@discriminator` decorator to indicate the property used for polymorphic serialization, and the OpenAPI emitter generates the standard OpenAPI `discriminator` field. The legacy `x-ms-discriminator-value` extension is not emitted by default in TypeSpec-generated OpenAPI, as the OpenAPI v3 specification now expects the standard `discriminator` field. Azure guidelines require using the standard discriminator mechanism for new specs. If you have a legacy client that depends on `x-ms-discriminator-value`, you would need to add it manually using an OpenAPI extension decorator, but this is discouraged for new Azure services.\\n\\n2. Regarding the duplicate `objectType` property: This is a modeling issue in your TypeSpec. When you use inheritance (`extends`) and both the base and derived models declare the same property (`objectType`), the property will appear in both places in the generated schema, resulting in duplication. To avoid this, only declare `objectType` in the base model (`AzureBackupRestoreRequest`). In the derived model (`AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest`), set the value of `objectType` as a string literal, like:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@discriminator(\\\"objectType\\\")\\nmodel AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest extends AzureBackupRestoreRequest {\\n  objectType: \\\"AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest\\\";\\n  recoveryPointId: string;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis ensures that the derived model sets the discriminator value correctly and does not duplicate the property definition. The generated OpenAPI will have the correct discriminator mapping and only one `objectType` property per schema.\\n\\nSummary:\\n- The absence of `x-ms-discriminator-value` is by design; use the standard `discriminator` field for new specs.\\n- Avoid duplicate discriminator properties by only declaring them in the base model and setting their value as a literal in derived models.\", \"ground_truth\": \"Let's address both of your issues with the TypeSpec migration and generated Swagger:\\n1. Missing x-ms-discriminator-value and presence of discriminator:\\nYes, this is by design. The TypeSpec emitter uses the standard OpenAPI 3 discriminator property, not the Azure-specific x-ms-discriminator-value. The @discriminator decorator in TypeSpec results in the discriminator field in the generated OpenAPI, as per the latest OpenAPI and Azure SDK standards. This approach provides better compatibility with code generators and client SDKs. The use of x-ms-discriminator-value is not needed when the discriminator field is present and correctly configured.\\nSee the TypeSpec documentation and Azure guidelines for more.\\n2. Duplicate objectType property in generated Swagger:\\nThis is a known limitation of how inheritance and discriminator are currently handled in TypeSpec to OpenAPI conversion. If both the base (AzureBackupRestoreRequest) and the derived model (AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest) define the objectType property, OpenAPI will reflect both in the derived model, leading to apparent duplication.\\nThis does not cause functional issues, but it can be confusing. The current best practice is to only define the discriminator property (objectType) in the base model and set its value in the derived models, rather than redefining the property. In TypeSpec, this would look like:\\n```\\n@discriminator(\\\"objectType\\\")\\nmodel AzureBackupRestoreRequest {\\nobjectType: string;\\n// ... other properties ...\\n}\\nmodel AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest extends AzureBackupRestoreRequest {\\nobjectType: \\\"AzureBackupRecoveryPointBasedRestoreRequest\\\";\\nrecoveryPointId: string;\\n}\\n```\\nThis way, the objectType property is only defined in the base model, and the derived model just sets its value. This should prevent duplication in the emitted Swagger.\\nAction Items:\\nRefactor your TypeSpec so that only the base model defines the discriminator property (objectType), and the derived models assign its value.\\nDo not worry about x-ms-discriminator-value not being present: it is not required when the standard discriminator property is used.\"}"}]

actual.answer:
Yes, TypeSpec provides a decorator to set a customized `final-state-via` value for long-running operation (LRO) APIs. You should use the `@Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia` decorator from the `@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core` library. This decorator allows you to explicitly specify the desired final state resolution strategy for an LRO operation. The supported values are: "original-uri", "operation-location", "location", and "azure-async-operation".

Example usage:
```typespec
@Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia("azure-async-operation")
op createResource(): ArmAcceptedLroResponse<...>;
```
This will ensure that the generated OpenAPI includes the correct `x-ms-long-running-operation-options` with your chosen `final-state-via` value for the operation.

Note: This decorator should be applied directly to the operation you want to customize.

testcase: Brownfield TypeSpec migration

expected.answer:
Migration to TypeSpec for existing services is not yet mandatory, but it is suggested, and teams should be planning for it in Bromine and Krypton
Services must wholly switch to TypeSpec, there is no allowed mixing of hand-written and generated swagger
Servicesmust conform to a single, unified api-version for their service, servicesthat currently use different api-versions for parts of their service are going to need to plan for conformance -this either means SDK splitting or version uniformity.  Teams that use this 'different api-versions for different resources in the same sdk' pattern are not good candidates for conversion at the moment
In generally, the more compliant your service is to the RPC and best practices, the easier conversion will be
There is documentation on converting here: [Getting started | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/01-get-started/)

knowledges.title: How to create an Example for a typespec model?
Resolving Folder Migration Conflicts: A Guide for PR Authors
Handling multiple API versions using typespec

actual.answer:
There is a clear timeframe for brownfield resource providers (RPs) to migrate from OpenAPI Swagger to TypeSpec: all existing (brownfield) services must transition to TypeSpec Azure by March 30, 2026. Starting in Q4FY26, PRs for new API versions that are not based on TypeSpec will be blocked, and SDK releases from non-TypeSpec specs will also be blocked. This requirement is enforced to ensure consistency and quality across Azure APIs.

Regarding migration strategy, mixing TypeSpec with handwritten Swagger is NOT allowed. Services must wholly switch to TypeSpec; partial migration (such as migrating one resource type at a time and mixing TypeSpec with Swagger) is not supported. The migration must result in a single, unified API version for the service, and all resources must be defined in TypeSpec. If your service currently uses different API versions for different resources, you will need to plan for conformance—either by splitting SDKs or achieving version uniformity.

The recommended approach is to plan and execute a full migration, using the provided OpenAPI-to-TypeSpec conversion tools and following the documented migration process. You should not attempt to mix or phase migration at the resource level using both Swagger and TypeSpec. For guidance and help during migration, refer to the official documentation and community support channels.

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Unable to apply client flatten to a top level resource property.\\n\\nquestion: my existing open api spec, of a proxy resource is such\\n```\\n\\\"ArcSetting\\\": {\\n\\\"description\\\": \\\"ArcSetting details.\\\",\\n\\\"type\\\": \\\"object\\\",\\n\\\"allOf\\\": [\\n{\\n\\\"$ref\\\": \\\"../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v5/types.json#/definitions/ProxyResource\\\"\\n}\\n],\\n\\\"properties\\\": {\\n\\\"properties\\\": {\\n\\\"description\\\": \\\"ArcSetting properties.\\\",\\n\\\"$ref\\\": \\\"#/definitions/ArcSettingProperties\\\",\\n\\\"x-ms-client-flatten\\\": true\\n}\\n}\\n},\\n```\\nTo convert it to typespec, here is what my tsp looks\\n```\\n/**\\n* ArcSetting details.\\n*/\\n@parentResource(Cluster)\\nmodel ArcSetting is Azure.ResourceManager.ProxyResource<ArcSettingProperties> {\\n...ResourceNameParameter<\\nResource = ArcSetting,\\nKeyName = \\\"arcSettingName\\\",\\nSegmentName = \\\"arcSettings\\\",\\nNamePattern = \\\"\\\"\\n>;\\n}\\n```\\nthe output is missing, the client-flatten property\\n```\\n\\\"ArcSetting\\\": {\\n\\\"type\\\": \\\"object\\\",\\n\\\"description\\\": \\\"ArcSetting details.\\\",\\n\\\"properties\\\": {\\n\\\"properties\\\": {\\n\\\"$ref\\\": \\\"#/definitions/ArcSettingProperties\\\",\\n\\\"description\\\": \\\"ArcSetting properties.\\\"\\n}\\n},\\n\\\"allOf\\\": [\\n{\\n\\\"$ref\\\": \\\"../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v6/types.json#/definitions/ProxyResource\\\"\\n}\\n]\\n},\\n```\\nIs there a possible way to add this flag, or what is the implication for the existing SDK\", \"response\": \"To apply the `x-ms-client-flatten` flag to a top-level resource property when converting an OpenAPI spec to TypeSpec, you should use the `@flattenProperty` decorator from the `Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy` namespace on the relevant property in your TypeSpec model. This decorator is the direct replacement for the OpenAPI extension and is the recommended approach for migration scenarios where flattening is required for SDK compatibility.\\n\\nHere is how you can update your TypeSpec:\\n\\n```typespec\\n/**\\n * ArcSetting details.\\n */\\n@parentResource(Cluster)\\nmodel ArcSetting is Azure.ResourceManager.ProxyResource<ArcSettingProperties> {\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter<ArcSetting>;\\n  @doc(\\\"ArcSetting properties.\\\")\\n  @Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty\\n  properties: ArcSettingProperties;\\n}\\n```\\n\\n**Implications for the SDK if `x-ms-client-flatten` is missing:**\\n- If you omit the flattening, the generated SDKs will not flatten the `properties` bag, resulting in less ergonomic client models (i.e., users will need to access properties via `resource.properties.foo` instead of `resource.foo`).\\n- This can be a breaking change for existing SDK consumers who expect flattened models, so it is important to preserve this behavior for back-compatibility unless you are intentionally redesigning the API surface.\\n\\n**Best Practice:**\\n- For new services, avoid using flattening unless absolutely necessary. For migration/back-compat, use `@flattenProperty` as shown above.\\n- Do not use OpenAPI decorators directly in TypeSpec; always use the TypeSpec-native decorators for Azure services.\\n\\n**Note:** If your SDK validation fails due to missing flattening, ensure you are using the latest TypeSpec toolset and that the decorator is applied as shown. If you need to restrict flattening to specific languages, you can pass a scope parameter to `@flattenProperty`.\\n\\nFor more details, see the official migration guidance and decorator documentation.\", \"ground_truth\": \"Add\\n@@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty(ArcSettings.propeties)\\nBy convention put this in a back-compatible.tsp file.\"}"}]

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: In Resource provider, what is the type I should declare for an object or dictionary of string, string?\\n\\nquestion: In Resource provider, what is the type I should declare for an object or dictionary of string, string?\\nI initially use\\n{}, but type spec asks for model.\\nHowever, I do not have model, so I want to use a dictionary of string, string\\nmetadata?: Record<string, string>; is not correct either.\\nWhat I should use?\", \"response\": \"For a property that represents a dictionary/object with string keys and string values in a Resource Provider TypeSpec specification, you should use `Record<string>` as the type. The correct declaration in your model would be:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmetadata?: Record<string>;\\n```\\n\\nThis is the recommended approach for Azure Resource Manager and management-plane specs. Do not use `{}` or an untyped model, as TypeSpec requires explicit types. Also, avoid using `Record<unknown>` or mixing known properties with a Record, as per Azure guidelines. If you want to make the property optional, use the `?` suffix as shown above.\\n\\nExample usage in a resource model:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmodel MyResourceProperties {\\n  metadata?: Record<string>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis will emit as an OpenAPI schema with `additionalProperties` of type `string`, which is the standard for representing a string-to-string dictionary in Azure ARM specs.\", \"ground_truth\": \"For a property in a TypeSpec ARM resource provider model that represents a dictionary (object) mapping strings to strings, you should use the built-in `Record<string>` type.\\nFor example:\\n```\\nmodel MyResourceProperties {\\nmetadata?: Record<string>;\\n}\\n```\\nThis models a property (`metadata`) that is an object/dictionary where all keys and values are strings, equivalent to `{ [key: string]: string }` in TypeScript or `Dictionary<string, string>` in .NET.\\nYou should not use `{}` (empty model) or just `Record` (without specifying the value type) as these are either incomplete or invalid in TypeSpec. The correct, type-safe way is `Record<string>`, which will be emitted to OpenAPI/Swagger as an `object` with `additionalProperties: { type: \\\"string\\\" }`.\\nIf your API spec review asks for a 'model', you can define a named type:\\n```\\nmodel MetadataModel is Record<string>;\\nmodel MyResourceProperties {\\nmetadata?: MetadataModel;\\n}\\n```\\nBut `Record<string>` is the canonical, recommended approach for a string-to-string dictionary in TypeSpec ARM resource definitions.\\nNote: While this is technically correct, ARM guidelines recommend against unbounded dictionary/object types unless absolutely necessary, as they can limit Azure Policy and ARG capabilities. Use with care, and document any supported/expected keys in your @doc comments if possible.\"}"}]
