ProviderParameter\\\\n\\\\n### Description\\\\n\\\\nTemplate for adding provider namespace as a parameter. This is used internally for path generation.\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Example\\\\n\\\\n```typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel MyResourceParameters {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ProviderParameter\\\\u003cMyResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // other parameters\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n### Swagger Output\\\\n\\\\n```json\\\\r\\\\n// This model is used internally for provider namespace path parameters.\\\\r\\\\n// It generates the provider segment in the path but not a separate schema definition.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"language-basics#models.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Models\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/models\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Models\\\\n# language-basics#models.md\\\\n\\\\n# Models\\\\n\\\\nModels in TypeSpec are utilized to define the structure or schema of data.\\\\n\\\\n## Types of models\\\\n\\\\nModels can be categorized into two main types:\\\\r\\\\n- [Record](#record)\\\\r\\\\n- [Array](#array)\\\\n\\\\n### Record\\\\n\\\\nA Record model is a structure that consists of named fields, referred to as properties.\\\\r\\\\n- The name can be an [`identifier`](./identifiers.md) or `string literal`.\\\\r\\\\n- The type can be any type reference.\\\\r\\\\n- Properties are arranged in a specific order. Refer to [property ordering](#property-ordering) for more details.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  age: uint8;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Optional properties\\\\r\\\\nProperties can be designated as optional by using the `?` symbol.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  address?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Default values\\\\r\\\\nProperties can be assigned a default value using the `=` operator.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  address?: string = \\\\\\\"wild\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  age: uint8 = 0;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Property ordering\\\\r\\\\nProperties are arranged in the order they are defined in the source. Properties acquired via `model is` are placed before properties defined in the model body. Properties obtained via `...` are inserted at the point where the spread appears in the source.\\\\r\\\\nExample:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  age: uint8;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel HasHome {\\\\r\\\\n  address: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat is Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  meow: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  ...HasHome;\\\\r\\\\n  furColor: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// The resulting property order for Cat is:\\\\r\\\\n// name, age, meow, address, furColor\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Additional properties\\\\n\\\\nThe `Record\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e` model can be used to define a model with an arbitrary number of properties of type T. It can be combined with a named model to provide some known properties.\\\\r\\\\nThere are three ways to achieve this, each with slightly different semantics:\\\\r\\\\n- Using the `...` operator\\\\r\\\\n- Using the `is` operator\\\\r\\\\n- Using the `extends` operator\\\\r\\\\n#### Using the `...` operator\\\\r\\\\nSpreading a Record into your model implies that your model includes all the properties you have explicitly defined, plus any additional properties defined by the Record. This means that a property in the model could be of a different and incompatible type with the Record value type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n// In this example, the Person model has a property `age` that is an int32, but also has other properties that are all strings.\\\\r\\\\nmodel Person {\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Using the `is` operator\\\\r\\\\nWhen using `is Record\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`, it indicates that all properties of this model are of type T. This means that each property explicitly defined in the model must also be of type T.\\\\r\\\\nThe example below would be invalid\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Person is Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  //   ^ int32 is not assignable to string\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nBut the following would be valid\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Person is Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Using the `extends` operator\\\\r\\\\nThe `extends` operator has similar semantics to `is`, but it defines the relationship between the two models. In many languages, this would probably result in the same emitted code as `is` and it is recommended to use `is Record\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e` instead.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Person extends Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Special property types\\\\n\\\\n#### `never`\\\\r\\\\nA model property can be declared as having the type `never`. This can be interpreted as the model not having that property.\\\\r\\\\nThis can be useful in a model template to omit a property.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Address\\\\u003cTState\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  state: TState;\\\\r\\\\n  city: string;\\\\r\\\\n  street: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel UKAddress is Address\\\\u003cnever\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n:::note\\\\r\\\\nThe responsibility of removing `never` properties lies with the emitter. The TypeSpec compiler will not automatically omit them.\\\\r\\\\n:::\\\\n\\\\n### Array\\\\n\\\\nArrays are models created using the `[]` syntax, which is a shorthand for using the `Array\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e` model type.\\\\n\\\\n## Model composition\\\\n\\\\n### Spread\\\\n\\\\nThe spread operator (`...`) copies the members of a source model into a target model. This operation doesn't create any nominal relationship between the source and target, making it useful when you want to reuse common properties without generating complex inheritance relationships.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Animal {\\\\r\\\\n  species: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  ...Animal;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Pet;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// The Dog model is equivalent to the following declaration:\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  species: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Extends\\\\n\\\\nThere are times when you want to create an explicit relationship between two models, such as when you're generating class definitions in languages that support inheritance. The `extends` keyword can be used to establish this relationship.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Animal {\\\\r\\\\n  species: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Animal {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Is\\\\n\\\\nThere are instances when you want to create a new type that is an exact copy of an existing type but with additional properties or metadata, without creating a nominal inheritance relationship. The `is` keyword can be used for this purpose. It copies all the properties (like spread), but also copies [decorators](./decorators.md) as well. A common use case is to provide a better name to a [template](#model-templates) instantiation:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@decorator\\\\r\\\\nmodel Thing\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  property: T;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel StringThing is Thing\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n// The StringThing declaration is equivalent to the following declaration:\\\\r\\\\n@decorator\\\\r\\\\nmodel StringThing {\\\\r\\\\n  property: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Model templates\\\\n\\\\nRefer to [templates](./templates.md) for more details on templates.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Page\\\\u003cItem\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  size: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  item: Item[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel DogPage {\\\\r\\\\n  ...Page\\\\u003cDog\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Meta type references\\\\n\\\\nSome model property meta types can be referenced using `::`.\\\\r\\\\n| Name | Example          | Description                              |\\\\r\\\\n| ---- | ---------------- | ---------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| type | `Pet.name::type` | Reference the type of the model property |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM.CommonTypes-Models-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n## 17. names\\\\n\\\\nThere is some cases where the name you have in TypeSpec might differ from the name over the wire or for a certain language.\\\\n\\\\n## Update name for a given target\\\\n\\\\nTo update the name of a TypeSpec entity you can use the `@encodedName` decorator. This decorator takes 2 parameters:\\\\r\\\\n| Parameter     | Type     | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                            |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------- | -------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `mimeType`    | `string` | Mime type this should apply to. The mime type should be a known mime type as described here https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types without any suffix (e.g. `+json`) |\\\\r\\\\n| `encodedName` | `string` | The name should be when serialized to the given mime type.                                                                                                                                                             |\\\\r\\\\nExample:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Foo {\\\\r\\\\n  // Specify that when serializing to JSON `expireAt` property should be named `exp`\\\\r\\\\n  @encodedName(\\\\\\\"json\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"exp\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  expireAt: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel CertificateAttributes {\\\\r\\\\n  @encodedName(\\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"nbf\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  notBefore: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  @encodedName(\\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"exp\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @encodedName(\\\\\\\"application/xml\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"ExpireAt\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  expires: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  created: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  updated: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctable\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cthead\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cth\\\\u003eJson\\\\u003c/th\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cth\\\\u003eXml\\\\u003c/th\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cth\\\\u003eYaml\\\\u003c/th\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/tr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/thead\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003eWhen serialized to `application/json` properties will use the encodedName for `application/json` if available or default to the property name.\\\\u003c/td\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003eWhen serialized to `application/xml` properties will use the encodedName for `application/xml` if available or default to the property name.\\\\u003c/td\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003eYaml didn't provide any different names so it will serialize using the property names.\\\\u003c/td\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/tr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n the value of `@encodedName` in your library or emitter you can use `resolveEncodedName(target: Type, mimeType: string): string` from the Contracts\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/common-api-contracts.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Common API Contracts\\\\n# v1.0#common-api-contracts.md\\\\n\\\\n# Common API Contracts\\\\n\\\\nThis document describes preferred schemas for resource APIs that are to remain consistent between resource types.\\\\n\\\\n## Table of Contents ##\\\\n\\\\n- [System Metadata for all Azure resources](#system-metadata-for-all-azure-resources) \\\\u003c/br\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n- [Describing Location for off-Azure resources](#describing-location-for-off-azure-resources)\\\\r\\\\n- [Customer-managed Key encryption](#customer-managed-key-encryption)\\\\r\\\\n- [Singleton Resources](#singleton-resources)\\\\n\\\\n## System Metadata for all Azure resources ##\\\\n\\\\nAs of 2020, all Azure resources may implement a read-only `systemData` object property in the top-level envelope. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"id\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"/subscriptions/{id}/resourceGroups/{group}/providers/{rpns}/{type}/{name}\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"{name}\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"{resourceProviderNamespace}/{resourceType}\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"location\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"North US\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"systemData\\\\\\\":{\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"createdBy\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"createdByType\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cUser|Application|ManagedIdentity|Key\\\\u003e\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"createdAt\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdate-time\\\\u003e\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"lastModifiedBy\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"lastModifiedByType\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cUser|Application|ManagedIdentity|Key\\\\u003e\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"lastModifiedAt\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdate-time\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"tags\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"key1\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"value 1\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"key2\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"value 2\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"resource kind\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"comment\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Resource defined structure\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Properties ###\\\\n\\\\n| Name  | Description |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------- | ------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| createdBy | a string identifier for the identity that created the resource  |\\\\r\\\\n| createdByType | the type of identity that created the resource: user, application, managedIdentity|\\\\r\\\\n| createdAt | the timestamp of resource creation (UTC) |\\\\r\\\\n| lastModifiedBy | a string identifier for the identity that last modified the resource |\\\\r\\\\n| lastModifiedByType | the type of identity that last modified the resource: user, application, managedIdentity|\\\\r\\\\n| lastModifiedAt | the timestamp of resource last modification (UTC) |\\\\r\\\\nARM will provide the values in the `x-ms-arm-resource-system-data` header to the provider on resource write and resource action calls in JSON format (as shown above). For ProxyOnly resources, the resource provider is the source of truth. ARM will provide best effort values in the header, but the provider should update the values, including missing values, from known metadata. The `systemData` object should be defined in the resource swagger and persisted in provider storage to serve on all responses for the resource (GET, PUT, PATCH).\\\\r\\\\n**You should only update the systemData properties of a resource if there is a change that affects a user-modifiable property in the control plane JSON configuration of that resource.**\\\\n\\\\n### POST operations ###\\\\n\\\\nFor POST operations on tracked resources, ARM will send all the header values. For POST (create) operations on proxy resources, ARM will send all the header values. For POST (action) operations on proxy resources, ARM sends the lastModified* values only.\\\\n\\\\n### Resource move ###\\\\n\\\\nResource move is treated as a combination of creation and deletion. The RP should be consistent with this logic and replace all values accordingly.\\\\r\\\\nARM passes one single x-ms-arm-resource-system-data header for the complete move operation. For example, if you have 20 resources to be moved in one request, the expectation from RPs is to save the same system data for each of these 20 resources. In this example,  moving 20 resources is equal to creating 20 resources, and therefore, the systemData values are the same.\\\\n\\\\n### FAQ ###\\\\n\\\\nif there is a change that affects a user-modifiable property in the control plane JSON configuration of that resource. Children resources should have their own systemData values.\\\\r\\\\n#### What is the format of the timestamps being sent? What if the value is null (i.e. can\\u2019t supply the createdAt)? ####\\\\r\\\\nRPs should either return null or emit the property. \\\\r\\\\n#### Should internal adminstration operations like updating VM images results in an update of the related resources' systemData properties?\\\\r\\\\nOperations should only change the systemData properties if the change affects user-modifiable properties within the resource's JSON configuration. If a user-modifiable property changes, it should update the systemData values.\\\\r\\\\n#### Can I use a new *ByType value? ####\\\\r\\\\nRPs should only use *ByType values supported by the related enum in the [common types definition](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/common-types/resource-management/v1/types.json). The currently supported *ByType values are User, Application, ManagedIdentity, and Key.\\\\r\\\\n#### Can I add systemData to my current API version? ####\\\\r\\\\nNo. Adding systemData is a breaking change and should only be included as part of a new API version.\\\\r\\\\n#### Is there any situation where the RP will have to interpret the values we are passed and do something? Or do we just store the data and return it? ####\\\\r\\\\nFor tracked resources, the values can simply be stored. Since ARM is not aware of all changes to proxy or dataplane-modifiable resources, the values may have to be interpreted for these resource types.\\\\r\\\\n#### How should we store the *ByType values so that we do not have to update the API when more values are added to the identity types? ####\\\\r\\\\nYou should store the *ByType values as a string.\\\\n\\\\n#### Is it OK to collect this data in Microsoft telemetry streams (e.g., Geneva, Kusto, COSMOS, etc.)? ####\\\\r\\\\n**No.** This data is considered Customer Data [Customer Content and End User Identifiable Information (EUII)] and must **NOT** be collected in any telemetry streams in order to meet our data handling requirements. It should only be included in the activity log for and accessible by each individual customer.\\\\r\\\\n#### What values should I use for long-running operations? ####\\\\r\\\\nThe systemData properties should reflect the values from when the operation was triggered.\\\\r\\\\n#### Should I replace the values if the operation fails or is cancelled? ####\\\\r\\\\nDo not update system data on a request that was rejected synchronously, but keep the values the triggered-time values if an async operation fails or is cancelled. \\\\r\\\\n#### What is expected for resources that already exist prior to an RP's implementation of systemData? ####\\\\r\\\\nARM doesn\\u2019t maintain the systemData details and will not fill them up before returning to the client. As a result, as the RP, you are expected to save the values from the first PUT. If the resource already existed prior to your systemData implementation, you can supply null or omit the value when it is not returned by ARM.\\\\r\\\\n#### Should a parent resource's systemData values be impacted by the creation or modification of children resources? ####\\\\r\\\\nNo. You should only update the systemData properties of a resource if there is a change that affects a user-modifiable property in the control plane JSON configuration of that resource. Children resources should have their own systemData values.\\\\r\\\\n#### What is the format of the timestamps being sent? What if the value is null (i.e. can\\u2019t supply the createdAt)? ####\\\\r\\\\nRPs should either return null or emit the property. \\\\r\\\\n#### Should internal adminstration operations like updating VM images results in an update of the related resources' systemData properties?\\\\n\\\\n## Describing location for off-Azure resources ##\\\\n\\\\nIn some cases, resources described in ARM are hosted outside of an Azure datacenter. In this case, an optional `locationData` property is appropriate to allow the user to supply metadata pertaining to the resource geographic location. The locationData property should be in the `properties` object of the resoure.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"id\\\\\\\": experiences:\\\\n\\\\n### Azure Batch\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EUkgwSc69lpPsBjQBfLfMEgB0WCTBe9x7ozU8VNK2s8mAw?e=1MIXZi)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"There's definitions in Swagger, but \\u2026 TypeSpec has much more flexibility when it comes to doing things like mix or not mixing in traits and defining core things that you export.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I want to highlight the tooling improvements, like not having to figure out how to install things locally [like Swagger tooling], having it all in the same tool set that includes the emitters and things like that is really nice. The VS code integration right out of the box is something I've really liked.\\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n### MS Learn\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EXjQ3t7i-z9BpxVUgZVcS6QBxjLYdRLUquX2y8xczNxfbA?e=nesl3Q)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\u201cOne of the highlights [of using TypeSpec] was our ability to author API specs in a very simple and intuitive language. This meant that even [our PMs] who are not engineers were able to understand these API specifications. They could review them, make comments, and participate in designing those APIs.\\u201d\\\\n\\\\n### Azure AI Content Safety\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EdlE2PYtZ9BKoXQ-R0h-O10B9RidePBT4mwB1JgIqRC01A?e=JRneI2)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I find TypeSpec to be much simpler to learn and write compared to Swagger. In my experience, Swagger often encounters many conflicts due to its JSON format. TypeSpec proves to be a much better alternative as it allows everyone to work independently on their own sections, making it more user-friendly. Furthermore, TypeSpec allows for the separate definition of models and routes. Understanding identifier rules is essential for writing valid TypeSpec code.\\\\n\\\\n## Identifier syntax rules\\\\n\\\\nAn identifier must follow these rules:\\\\r\\\\n- **Start with**: A letter (a-z, A-Z), emoji, underscore (`_`), or dollar sign (`$`)\\\\r\\\\n- **Followed by**: Any combination of letters, numbers (0-9), emoji, underscores, or dollar signs\\\\r\\\\n- **Length**: One or more characters\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec implements [UAX31-R1b stable identifiers](http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr31/#R1b) with the [emoji profile](http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr31/#Emoji_Profile), providing full Unicode support for international characters.\\\\n\\\\n### Examples\\\\n\\\\n- \\u2705 `cat`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u2705 `Dog`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u2705 `_Item2`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u2705 `$money$`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u2705 `\\ud83c\\udf89`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u2705 `\\ud83d\\ude80`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u274c `1cat`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u274c `*dog`\\\\n\\\\n## Escaping identifiers\\\\n\\\\nWhen you need to use reserved keywords or invalid identifiers, TypeSpec provides an escaping mechanism using backticks (`` ` ``). This allows you to use:\\\\r\\\\n- Reserved keywords as identifiers\\\\r\\\\n- Identifiers that don't follow normal syntax rules\\\\r\\\\n- Identifiers with special characters or unusual formats\\\\r\\\\n#### Examples\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel `enum` {}\\\\r\\\\nmodel `interface` {}\\\\r\\\\nop `import`(): void;\\\\r\\\\nmodel `123InvalidName` {}\\\\r\\\\nmodel `my-special-model` {}\\\\r\\\\nmodel `User Profile` {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"standard-library#discriminated-types.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Discriminated Types\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/discriminated-types\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Discriminated Types\\\\n# standard-library#discriminated-types.md\\\\n\\\\n# Discriminated Types\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec allows for the expression of unions and inheritance. However, when transmitting types over the network, many languages require a mechanism to distinguish between different union variants or models within an inheritance hierarchy.\\\\n\\\\n### Implementing Discriminated Unions\\\\n\\\\nUnions can be marked as discriminated using the `@discriminated` decorator. This discriminator will assume the variant name is the discriminator value.\\\\r\\\\n#### Default serialization\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminated\\\\r\\\\nunion Pet It is recommended to use `Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e` instead of `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n2. Specifying a type with Record and some known properties is also not recommended.\\\\r\\\\n#### \\u274c Incorrect\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  data: Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet is Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### \\u2705 Correct\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  tags: Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet is Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n## Examples of TypeSpec Azure in Action\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## Examples of TypeSpec Azure in Action\\\\n\\\\nWhether you're working with Data Plane (DP) or Azure Resource Manager (ARM), having clear examples to follow can make your transition to TypeSpec smoother. Here are some resources that can help:\\\\r\\\\n- **Playground Examples**: Our playground provides ARM and DP examples that serve as excellent models for teams new to TypeSpec Azure. These examples are concise and take full advantage of our standard operation templates. You can use these as a gold standard for your own TypeSpec definitions. Visit the [TypeSpec Azure Playground](https://aka.ms/trytypespec/azure) to explore these examples.\\\\r\\\\n- **ARM Samples**: For more specific scenarios, check out our additional [ARM samples](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/tree/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/arm-scenarios). These are tutorial-like examples that cover various scenarios. You can adapt these to fit your specific needs.\\\\r\\\\nThe playground examples are a great starting point for getting familiar with TypeSpec Azure. As you gain more experience, you can leverage the ARM samples to understand how to apply TypeSpec to a variety of scenarios.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#resource-type.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"ARM Resource Types\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/resource-type\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# ARM Resource Types\\\\n## Designing Resource-specific Properties\\\\n# howtos#arm#resource-type.md\\\\n\\\\n# ARM Resource Types\\\\n\\\\n## Designing Resource-specific Properties\\\\n\\\\nEach resource model consists of two distinct parts\\\\r\\\\n- An outer _envelope_ of information that provides metadata for optional standardized ARM functionality, like entity-tags and managed identities, and is processed by Azure Resource Manager.\\\\r\\\\n- An inner set of properties that are specific to the resource and are defined by the resource provider.\\\\r\\\\nModifying the ARM envelope is discussed in later sections on [mixing in standard ARM envelope add-ons](#adding-optional-standard-envelope-properties).\\\\r\\\\nThe inner _rp-specific property bag_ consists of all of the properties that the RP needs to manage about the resource. Properties should be completely specified, should not duplicate properties from the _ARM envelope_, and may consist of simple types, arrays, or other complex properties.\\\\r\\\\nHere is an example of a property bag for the `EmployeeResource` resource.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeResource is TrackedResource\\\\u003cEmployeeProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The employee name, using 'Firstname Lastname' notation */\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"employees\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"employeeName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nunion EmployeeProvisioningState {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource create request has been accepted */\\\\r\\\\n  Accepted: \\\\\\\"Accepted\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource is being provisioned */\\\\r\\\\n  Provisioning: \\\\\\\"Provisioning\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource is updating */\\\\r\\\\n  Updating: \\\\\\\"Updating\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Resource has been created. */\\\\r\\\\n  Succeeded: \\\\\\\"Succeeded\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Resource creation failed. */\\\\r\\\\n  Failed: \\\\\\\"Failed\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Resource creation was canceled. */\\\\r\\\\n  Canceled: \\\\\\\"Canceled\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource is being deleted */\\\\r\\\\n  Deleting: \\\\\\\"Deleting\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@minValue(50)\\\\r\\\\n@maxValue(70)\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeLevel extends int32;\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeResourceId\\\\r\\\\n  extends Azure.Core.armResourceIdentifier\\\\u003c[\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      type: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.HR/employees\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@secret\\\\r\\\\nscalar Password extends string;\\\\r\\\\nmodel Job {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  companyName: string;\\\\r\\\\n  start: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  end: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  role: string;\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\"Failed\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Resource creation was canceled. */\\\\r\\\\n  Canceled: \\\\\\\"Canceled\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource is being deleted */\\\\r\\\\n  Deleting: \\\\\\\"Deleting\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@minValue(50)\\\\r\\\\n@maxValue(70)\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeLevel extends int32;\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeResourceId\\\\r\\\\n  extends Azure.Core.armResourceIdentifier\\\\u003c[\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      type: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.HR/employees\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@secret\\\\r\\\\nscalar Password extends string;\\\\r\\\\nmodel Job {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  companyName: string;\\\\r\\\\n  start: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  end: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  role: string;\\\\r\\\\n  notes?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The current title of the employee */\\\\r\\\\n  title: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read, Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  level: EmployeeLevel;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  employeeId: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  biography?: string = \\\\\\\"No biography provided\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  colleagues: EmployeeResourceId[];\\\\r\\\\n  employmentHistory: Job[];\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  password: Password;\\\\r\\\\n  provisioningState?: EmployeeProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n`EmployeeProperties` specifies the employee metadata that the RP needs to track and manage. Notice that the model uses built-in scalar types like `string` and `int32`, new types built from scalar types with added constraints, like `Password` and `EmployeeLevel`, enumerations of values, like `EmployeeProvisioningState`, and complex types. The individual components of this model are described below.\\\\r\\\\nNote that _documentation comments on all models and model properties are required when specs are checked in_. Here they are omitted for clarity. The TypeSpec compiler and TypeSpec IDE tooling will emit warning diagnostics if you emit required documentation, and about most of the ARM rules described in this document.\\\\n\\\\n### The `provisioningState` Property for Tracked Resources\\\\n\\\\nAll Tracked Resources are required to implement a 'provisioningState' property in their rp-specific property bag. This is used by ARM and some ARM clients to track the provisioning state of a resource as it is created and deleted. At minimum, the provisioning state must contain the standard terminal values that ARM is looking for. There are contained in the `ResourceProvisioningState` enumeration in the Azure.ResourceManager library. If RPs have other provisioning states they would like to track, they can define their own provisioning state enum, and mix in the value, as shown in the sample above, or they may simply use the standard provisioning state as shown in the sample below:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel ResourceProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNote that this example uses the spread operator `...`, which allows you to simply include the properties from a source model in the target model you are constructing. This has the effect of copying the properties of the source model and their decorations into the target model, without creating any nominal inheritance relationship.\\\\r\\\\nAlternately, this is also equivalent:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel ResourceProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The status of the last provisioning operation performed on the resource. */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  provisioningState?: ResourceProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Required and Optional properties and Property Defaults\\\\n\\\\nIn the examples, note that some model properties use the optional operator `?` after the property name, like `biography?` and some do not, like `title`. Property names using the `?` are optional properties, which may or may not be provided in the request body for CreateOrUpdate (PUT) requests. Property names without the `?` are required properties, which must be provided in PUT requests. The exception is that properties that have 'readOnly' visibility do not appear in requests, but may be required or optional in responses.\\\\r\\\\nAlso note that optional properties may specify defaults, as with `biography?: string = \\\\\\\"No biography provided\\\\\\\"`. The default indicates the value that will be recorded on the server if no value is sent by the client.\\\\n\\\\n### Defining Custom Types\\\\n\\\\nIn the sample, new constrained scalar types and new complex model types are defined and used inside the _rp-specific property bag_. TypeSpec allows you to define custom types for use in your specification.\\\\r\\\\nYou will often want to define scalar types or properties that have constraints. For example, numeric values may be constrained to have a certain minimum or maximum, strign values may be constrained to follow a particular regex pattern, and so on. Whenever these constrained types are used in your spec, the constraints will be transmitted to the usage.\\\\r\\\\nThe example creates a numeric type with minimum and maximum constraints:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@minValue(50)\\\\r\\\\n@maxValue(70)\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeLevel extends int32;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis defines 'EmployeeLevel' as an integer value between 50 and 70. The example also defines a complex type used in an array:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Job {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  companyName: string;\\\\r\\\\n  start: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  end: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  role: string;\\\\r\\\\n  notes?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nMode details on what to consider when using complex types in an array are discussed in the section on [modeling arrays of complex types](#modeling-arrays-of-complex-types).\\\\n\\\\n### Using Resource identifiers\\\\n\\\\nIt is often the case that resources need to reference other resources to provide specific pieces of functionality. For example, resources may need to reference a storage account to use for storing user data, or a NIC to attach to a Network. The `Azure.ResourceManager` library defines a `ResourceIdentifier` template that allows you to easily represent references to resources in your API. The template allows you to specify one or more acceptable resource types, automatically designating the value as a resource reference, and providing the appropriate pattern validation - which helps in generating better code, better ARM templates, and better documentation for your API.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeResourceId\\\\r\\\\n  extends Azure.Core.armResourceIdentifier\\\\u003c[\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      type: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.HR/employees\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nscalar NetworkInterfaceId\\\\r\\\\n  extends Azure.Core.armResourceIdentifier\\\\u003c[\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      type: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.Network/networkInterfaces\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      type: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.ClassicNetwork/networkInterfaces\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe `NetworkInterfaceId example shows how to allow multiple resource types in a reference.\\\\n\\\\n### Property Visibility and Other Constraints\\\\n\\\\nThe sample uses the `@visibility` decorator to indicate how the resource definition is used in requests to PUT and PATCH operations, and in responses to PUT, PATCH, GET, and LIST operations.\\\\r\\\\nThis table shows how visibility is used to determine whether a property is used in requests and responses:\\\\r\\\\n| Visibility           | In Create Request? | In Patch Request/ Updateable in PUT | In Responses | Sample                                         |\\\\r\\\\n| -------------------- | ------------------ | ----------------------------------- | ------------ | ---------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| None                 | Yes                | Yes                                 | Yes          | Most properties                                |\\\\r\\\\n| read, create, update | Yes                | Yes                                 | Yes          | Most properties                                |\\\\r\\\\n| read, create         | Yes                | No                                  | Yes          | resource location                              |\\\\r\\\\n| read, update         | No                 | Yes                                 | Yes          | Properties only settable after creation (keys) |\\\\r\\\\n| create, update       | Yes                | Yes                                 | No           | Secrets (e.g. password)                        |\\\\r\\\\n| read                 | No                 | No                                  | Yes          | Calculated properties, e.g. ProxyResource\\\\n### TypeSpec Example\\\\n# TypeSpec-ARM-Models-Documentation.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec ARM Model Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n\\\\n## 37. ProxyResource\\\\n\\\\n### Description\\\\n\\\\nConcrete proxy resource types can be created by aliasing this type using a specific property type. See more details on [different Azure Resource Manager resource type here.](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/ARM/resource-type)\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Example\\\\n\\\\n```typescript\\\\r\\\\n/** Configuration resource demonstrating ProxyResource */\\\\r\\\\nmodel Configuration is ProxyResource\\\\u003cConfigurationProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The configuration name */\\\\r\\\\n  @pattern(\\\\\\\"^[a-zA-Z0-9-_]+$\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"configName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"configurations\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n/** Properties for configuration */\\\\r\\\\nmodel ConfigurationProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Configuration data */\\\\r\\\\n  configData?: Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\r\\\\n  /** Configuration type */\\\\r\\\\n  configurationType?: \\\\\\\"Basic\\\\\\\" | The correct declaration in your model would be:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmetadata?: Record<string>;\\n```\\n\\nThis is the recommended approach for Azure Resource Manager and management-plane specs. Do not use `{}` or an untyped model, as TypeSpec requires explicit types. Also, avoid using `Record<unknown>` or mixing known properties with a Record, as per Azure guidelines. If you want to make the property optional, use the `?` suffix as shown above.\\n\\nExample usage in a resource model:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmodel MyResourceProperties {\\n  metadata?: Record<string>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis will emit as an OpenAPI schema with `additionalProperties` of type `string`, which is the standard for representing a string-to-string dictionary in Azure ARM specs.\", \"ground_truth\": \"For a property in a TypeSpec ARM resource provider model that represents a dictionary (object) mapping strings to strings, you should use the built-in `Record<string>` type.\\nFor example:\\n```\\nmodel MyResourceProperties {\\nmetadata?: Record<string>;\\n}\\n```\\nThis models a property (`metadata`) that is an object/dictionary where all keys and values are strings, equivalent to `{ [key: string]: string }` in TypeScript or `Dictionary<string, string>` in .NET.\\nYou should not use `{}` (empty model) or just `Record` (without specifying the value type) as these are either incomplete or invalid in TypeSpec. The correct, type-safe way is `Record<string>`, which will be emitted to OpenAPI/Swagger as an `object` with `additionalProperties: { type: \\\"string\\\" }`.\\nIf your API spec review asks for a 'model', you can define a named type:\\n```\\nmodel MetadataModel is Record<string>;\\nmodel MyResourceProperties {\\nmetadata?: MetadataModel;\\n}\\n```\\nBut `Record<string>` is the canonical, recommended approach for a string-to-string dictionary in TypeSpec ARM resource definitions.\\nNote: While this is technically correct, ARM guidelines recommend against unbounded dictionary/object types unless absolutely necessary, as they can limit Azure Policy and ARG capabilities. Use with care, and document any supported/expected keys in your @doc comments if possible.\"}"}]

We are getting [XmsPageableForListCalls](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/xms-pageable-for-list-calls.md)  lintDiff finding since it is missing the x-ms-pageable in the operation, however the nextLink is emitted in the response model.\\n```\\nmodel ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList is Azure.Core.Page<ElasticVolume>;\\n/**\\n* Get elastic volumes associated with elastic snapshot policy\\n*/\\n@get\\n@action(\\\"elasticvolumes\\\")\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_01_preview)\\nlistVolumes is ArmResourceActionSync<\\nElasticSnapshotPolicy,\\nvoid,\\nElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList\\n>;\\n}\\n```\\nHow can we get this to have\\n```\\n\\\"x-ms-pageable\\\": {\\n\\\"nextLinkName\\\": \\\"nextLink\\\"\\n}\\n```\\nIn the operation ?\", \"response\": \"To ensure your ArmResourceActionSync operation emits the `x-ms-pageable` extension with `nextLinkName` set to `nextLink`, you must decorate the operation with the `@list` decorator. This is required by both TypeSpec and Azure API guidelines for pageable operations. The presence of `nextLink` in the response model alone is not sufficient; the operation itself must be explicitly marked as pageable.\\n\\nHere's how you should update your TypeSpec code:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@get\\n@action(\\\"elasticvolumes\\\")\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_01_preview)\\n@list // <-- This is required!\\nlistVolumes is ArmResourceActionSync<\\n  ElasticSnapshotPolicyResource,\\n  void,\\n  ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList\\n>;\\n```\\n\\nWith `@list` applied, the generated OpenAPI will include:\\n```json\\n\\\"x-ms-pageable\\\": {\\n  \\\"nextLinkName\\\": \\\"nextLink\\\"\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis approach follows ARM and Azure REST API guidelines and resolves the `XmsPageableForListCalls` linter finding. Always use the ARM paging templates and decorators for management-plane resource listing operations.\", \"ground_truth\": \"To add the `x-ms-pageable` extension (with `nextLinkName: \\\"nextLink\\\"`) to your TypeSpec operation, you should use the `@list` decorator on your operation. This will ensure that the generated OpenAPI/Swagger includes the correct `x-ms-pageable` extension, as required by Azure ARM and API guidelines.\\nHere's how you should modify your TypeSpec:\\n```\\n@list\\n@get\\n@action(\\\"elasticvolumes\\\")\\nlistVolumes is ArmResourceActionSync<\\nElasticSnapshotPolicy,\\nvoid,\\nElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList\\n>;\\nmodel ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList is Azure.Core.Page<ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolume>;\\n```\\nThe `@list` decorator is what triggers the addition of `x-ms-pageable` in the generated OpenAPI.\\nYour model should use the standard ARM paging model, which is `Azure.Core.Page<T>`. This will ensure you have the required `value` and `nextLink` properties, and that `nextLink` is correctly annotated.\\nAfter adding `@list`, the generated Swagger/OpenAPI will include:\\n```\\n\\\"x-ms-pageable\\\": {\\n\\\"nextLinkName\\\": \\\"nextLink\\\"\\n}\\n```\\nIf you have a custom response model, make sure it uses the `@pageItems` and `@nextLink` decorators:\\n```\\nmodel ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList {\\n@pageItems\\nvalue: ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolume[];\\n@nextLink\\nnextLink?: string;\\n}\\n```\\nSummary:\\nAdd `@list` to your operation.\\nUse the ARM paging model or annotate your custom model with `@pageItems` and `@nextLink`.\\nNo need to manually add the `x-ms-pageable` extension via `@extension`\\u2014the emitter handles this for you when `@list` is present.\\nThis approach is fully compliant with Azure API guidelines and will resolve your `XmsPageableForListCalls` lintDiff finding.\"}"}]

this?\\\\r\\\\n(1.The original put request doesn't have a request body, so I make the put request body optional for backwards compatibility.\\\\r\\\\n2.There is an optional bool flag in the optional request body to turn the feature requires LRO ON.)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n@sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    OptionalRequestBody = true\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      Employee,\\\\r\\\\n      EmployeeProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is pagination\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Support for pagination\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Support for pagination\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi, I have a typespec API which is a list api \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n listResources is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    AutoAction,\\\\r\\\\n    void,\\\\r\\\\n    AutoActionResourceListResponse\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nmodel AutoActionResourceListResponse is Azure.Core.Page\\\\u003cAutoActionResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThis api needs to support pagination. How can I achieve that using Microsoft.TypeSpec.Providerhub.Controller? we use the package to generate our controllers, which doesn't let me add query parameters to our API\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe controller emitter will emit an endpoint for your action, but you will need to add an endpoint manually for the next page endpoint (which is, presumably, a GET).\\\\r\\\\nget is required for paging.  If you are not using GET, then automated paging mechanisms in ARM clients won't work.\\\\r\\\\nIt's possible to use a different paging mechanism, but will require custom code in SDKs\\\\r\\\\ntypespec-providerhub does not provide extra GET endpoints for resource actions that return lists - you would need to add this endpoint.  Since the controllers are partial, this should be fairly straightforward.\\\\r\\\\nThe question of whether RPaaS (providerhub) should support such an endpoint and typespec-providerhub should provide any required extension support for this is a good The link may encode parameters such as query parameters in HTTP. In such cases those parameters must be passed.\\\\r\\\\nFor example, HTTP links are expected to be opaque and contain all the necessary information for the next page URL. This means that query and path parameters are expected to already have been included in the link. On the other hand, any header parameters are expected to be resent in the next request as those cannot be represented in the link.\\\\n\\\\n### Examples\\\\n\\\\n#### Next link pagination in Templates\\\\n\\\\n### Resource Actions (POST)\\\\n\\\\nCustom actions define any operations over resources outside the simple CRUDL (Create\\\\u003c Read, Update,\\\\r\\\\nDelete, List) or lifecycle operations described above. Any operation that returns data that is not\\\\r\\\\nmade up of resources, performs a prescriptive state change on the resource (cycling power,\\\\r\\\\nupgrading, etc.), or any operation that does not fit into the operations described above should be\\\\r\\\\nmodelled as a _resource action_. Examples of resource actions include:\\\\r\\\\n- Operations that manage credentials associated with a resource\\\\r\\\\n- Operations that calculate statistics about resources\\\\r\\\\n- Operations that make specific state changes to resources (power cycle, upgrade, etc.)\\\\r\\\\n#### Actions that take input and output\\\\r\\\\nOperations that manage credentials are a good example fo this category. TypeSpec defines synchronous\\\\r\\\\nand asynchronous templates for actions that consume and produce information.\\\\r\\\\n| Operation                    | TypeSpec                                                                       |\\\\r\\\\n| ---------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |\\\\r\\\\n| Synchronous Resource Action  | `updateCredentials is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cResourceType, Request, Response\\\\u003e`  |\\\\r\\\\n| Asynchronous Resource Action | `updateCredentials is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResourceType, Request, Response\\\\u003e` |\\\\r\\\\nParameters to the template are the ResourceType, the model for the operation Request body, and the\\\\r\\\\nmodel for the operation Response body.\\\\r\\\\n#### Actions that take input but produce no output (state changing actions)\\\\r\\\\nOperations that make state changes will often take some user configuration, and will return a\\\\r\\\\nseccess code or an error code depending on success or failure. TypeSpec defines synchronous and\\\\r\\\\nasynchronous operation templates for state changing actions.\\\\r\\\\n| Operation                     | TypeSpec                                                                              |\\\\r\\\\n| ----------------------------- |\\\\n\\\\nbody.\\\\r\\\\n#### Actions that take input but produce no output (state changing actions)\\\\r\\\\nOperations that make state changes will often take some user configuration, and will return a\\\\r\\\\nseccess code or an error code depending on success or failure. pagination\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Support for pagination\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Support for pagination\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi, I have a typespec API which is a list api \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n listResources is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    AutoAction,\\\\r\\\\n    void,\\\\r\\\\n    AutoActionResourceListResponse\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nmodel AutoActionResourceListResponse is Azure.Core.Page\\\\u003cAutoActionResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThis api needs to support pagination. How can I achieve that using Microsoft.TypeSpec.Providerhub.Controller? we use the package to generate our controllers, which doesn't let me add query parameters to our API\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe controller emitter will emit an endpoint for your action, but you will need to add an endpoint manually for the next page endpoint (which is, presumably, a GET).\\\\r\\\\nget is required for paging.  If you are not using GET, then automated paging mechanisms in ARM clients won't work.\\\\r\\\\nIt's possible to use a different paging mechanism, but will require custom code in SDKs\\\\r\\\\ntypespec-providerhub does not provide extra GET endpoints for resource actions that return lists - you would need to add this endpoint.  Since the controllers are partial, this should be fairly straightforward.\\\\r\\\\nThe question of whether RPaaS (providerhub) should support such an endpoint and typespec-providerhub should provide any required extension support for this is a good one.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"standard-library#built-in-decorators.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Built-in next page.\\\\r\\\\nIt is expected that navigating to the link will return the same set of responses as the operation that returned the current Always use the ARM paging templates and decorators for management-plane resource listing operations.\", \"ground_truth\": \"To add the `x-ms-pageable` extension (with `nextLinkName: \\\"nextLink\\\"`) to your TypeSpec operation, you should use the `@list` decorator on your operation. This will ensure that the generated OpenAPI/Swagger includes the correct `x-ms-pageable` extension, as required by Azure ARM and API guidelines.\\nHere's how you should modify your TypeSpec:\\n```\\n@list\\n@get\\n@action(\\\"elasticvolumes\\\")\\nlistVolumes is ArmResourceActionSync<\\nElasticSnapshotPolicy,\\nvoid,\\nElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList\\n>;\\nmodel ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList is Azure.Core.Page<ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolume>;\\n```\\nThe `@list` decorator is what triggers the addition of `x-ms-pageable` in the generated OpenAPI.\\nYour model should use the standard ARM paging model, which is `Azure.Core.Page<T>`. testcase: Should I add a visibilityFilter to a model

expected.answer:
ou do not need to explicitly add a visibilityFilter or use @withVisibility(Lifecycle.Read) if your model is only used as the return result of an operation. TypeSpec's HTTP library and standard emitters automatically apply Lifecycle.Read visibility to properties when a model is used as a return type. By default, properties are included in the response if they have Lifecycle.Read visibility, and all properties have all visibilities enabled unless you restrict them with @visibility.
Therefore, unless you have properties with more restrictive visibilities, all properties will be included in the response by default. If you want to limit which properties are returned, you should annotate those properties with @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) or other appropriate modifiers, but you do not need to explicitly use a visibilityFilter just because a model is a response type.
If you use the built-in Lifecycle visibility model as intended, the behavior you expect is implicit and handled automatically for response models.

automatically generated by the service, so it cannot be set when the resource is created or updated,\\\\r\\\\n   * but the server will return it when the resource is read.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The name of this resource.\\\\r\\\\n   *\\\\r\\\\n   * The name can be set when the resource is created, but may not be changed.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The description of this resource.\\\\r\\\\n   *\\\\r\\\\n   * By default, properties are visible in all lifecycle phases, so this property\\\\r\\\\n   * is present in all lifecycle phases.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  description: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the above example, each property of the `Example` model has a lifecycle visibility that instructs emitters to include\\\\r\\\\nor exclude the property when creating, updating, or reading the `Example` resource.\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec's HTTP library, OpenAPI emitter, and other standard functionality use the `Lifecycle` visibility to create\\\\r\\\\ndifferent views of the `Example` model based on which lifecycle phase is used in a particular operation.\\\\r\\\\nIn the following example, the type of the input and output of each operation is affected by the lifecycle visibility\\\\r\\\\nof the properties in the `Example` model.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/example\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\ninterface Examples {\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * When an operation uses the POST verb, it uses the `Create` lifecycle visibility to determine which properties\\\\r\\\\n   * are visible.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  @post create(@body example: Example): Created\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e | Error;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * When an operation uses the GET verb, it uses the `Read` lifecycle visibility to determine which properties\\\\r\\\\n   * are visible.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\n\\\\nby the lifecycle visibility\\\\r\\\\nof the properties in the `Example` model.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/example\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\ninterface Examples {\\\\r\\\\n uses the `Update` lifecycle visibility to determine which properties\\\\r\\\\n   * are visible.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  @patch update(@path id: string, @body example: Example): required: true\\\\r\\\\n        content:\\\\r\\\\n          application/json:\\\\r\\\\n            schema:\\\\r\\\\n              $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/ExampleUpdate\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\ncomponents:\\\\r\\\\n  schemas:\\\\r\\\\n    Example:\\\\r\\\\n      type: object\\\\r\\\\n      required:\\\\r\\\\n        - id\\\\r\\\\n type: string\\\\r\\\\n        description:\\\\r\\\\n          type: string\\\\r\\\\n    ExampleUpdate:\\\\r\\\\n      type: object\\\\r\\\\n      properties:\\\\r\\\\n        description:\\\\r\\\\n `ExampleUpdate` schema only includes the `description` property because it is the only property that is visible\\\\r\\\\n  when updating the resource.\\\\r\\\\n- Each of the `paths` reference the correct schema based on the lifecycle phase that the operations use.\\\\r\\\\n- The TypeSpec model is only defined _once_, and any changes in the output schemas are derived from the lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  visibility of the properties in the model.\\\\n\\\\n### Lifecycle modifiers\\\\n\\\\nThe following visibility modifiers are available in the `Lifecycle` visibility class:\\\\r\\\\n- `Create`: The property is visible when the resource is created. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `POST` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Read`: The property is visible when the resource is read. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property is\\\\r\\\\n  returned in an HTTP `GET` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Update`: The property is visible when the resource is updated. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `PATCH` or `PUT` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Delete`: The property is visible when a resource is deleted. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `DELETE` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Query`: The property is visible when a resource is passed as a parameter in a query. This visibility is checked, for\\\\r\\\\n  example, when a property is a parameter in an HTTP `GET` operation (**this should not be confused with an HTTP query\\\\r\\\\n  parameter defined using `@query`**).\\\\n\\\\n### Lifecycle visibility transforms\\\\n\\\\nYou can explicitly compute the shape of a model within a _specific_ lifecycle phase by using the four built-in\\\\r\\\\ntemplates for lifecycle transforms:\\\\r\\\\n- `Create\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Create` lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  phase, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Read\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Read` lifecycle phase,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Update\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Update` lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  phase, with the types of the properties set to `CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have _either_ the `Create` or `Update`\\\\r\\\\n  visibility modifiers enabled, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Delete\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have the `Lifecycle.Delete` modifier enabled,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Query\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have the `Lifecycle.Query` modifier enabled,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Update)\\\\r\\\\n  description: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReadExample is Read\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel CreateExample is Create\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel UpdateExample is Update\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel CreateOrUpdateExample is CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhen you use these templates, the resulting models have no `Lifecycle` visibility modifiers applied, so that any\\\\r\\\\nemitters or libraries that use lifecycle visibility will not alter them {#@withDefaultKeyVisibility}\\\\n# standard-library#built-in-decorators.md\\\\n\\\\n# Built-in Decorators\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n### `@withDefaultKeyVisibility` {#@withDefaultKeyVisibility}\\\\n\\\\nSet the visibility of key properties in a model if not already set.\\\\r\\\\nThis will set the visibility modifiers of all key properties in the model if the visibility is not already _explicitly_ set,\\\\r\\\\nbut will not change the visibility of any properties that have visibility set _explicitly_, even if the visibility\\\\r\\\\nis the same as the default visibility.\\\\r\\\\nVisibility may be set explicitly using any of the following decorators:\\\\r\\\\n- `@visibility`\\\\r\\\\n- `@removeVisibility`\\\\r\\\\n- `@invisible`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@withDefaultKeyVisibility(visibility: valueof EnumMember)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Target\\\\r\\\\n`Model`\\\\r\\\\n#### Parameters\\\\r\\\\n| Name | Type | Description |\\\\r\\\\n|------|------|-------------|\\\\r\\\\n| visibility | `valueof EnumMember` | The desired default visibility value. If a key property already has visibility set, it will not be changed. |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Readonly on model\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Readonly on model\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Readonly on model\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe have such swagger\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  readonly: true,\\\\r\\\\n  properties: {}\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"AnotherModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  properties: {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      $ref: \\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nWhen the type of property \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\" in another model is that \\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\", M4 will give a readonly on that property \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\". I want to confirm if the equivalent TypeSpec should be\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel AnotherModel {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  a: ReadonlyOnModel;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReadonlyOnModel {}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\ncc Alitzel Mendez : Common type replacement relates to this. I remember we have several models in the original common type have readonly on them and you removed these because TypeSpec cannot represent readonly on model. Then if any service refers to this model, those properties might need to be updated.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec can only attach readOnly to properties, not to models or scalars.  Functionally (assuming all references to ReadOnlyModel are through readOnly properties),  these Swagger docs are equivalent, see: [autorest/docs/openapi/howto/$ref-siblings.md at main \\u00b7 Azure/autorest](https://github.com/Azure/autorest/blob/main/docs/openapi/howto/%24ref-siblings.md) from the perspective of both TypeSpec and autorest, these descriptions are equivalent.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"extending-typespec#emitter-metadata-handling.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Managing metadata and visibility in REST API emitters\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/extending-typespec/emitter-metadata-handling\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Managing metadata and visibility in REST API emitters\\\\n## Working with metadata and visibility\\\\n# extending-typespec#emitter-metadata-handling.md\\\\n\\\\n# Managing metadata and visibility in REST API emitters\\\\n\\\\n## Working with metadata and visibility\\\\n\\\\nWhen working with metadata and visibility, it's important to understand how they interact with each other and with the data being transmitted. Here are some key points to consider:\\\\r\\\\n- Metadata is data about the data being transmitted. It can include information like the data's origin, when it was created or last updated, who created or updated it, and so on. Metadata is not usually visible to the end user, but it can be crucial for the system processing the data.\\\\r\\\\n- Visibility determines what data is visible to the end user or the system at any given time. For example, some data might be visible only to the system, some only to the end user, and some to both. Visibility can change depending on the context, such as whether the data is being created, read, updated, or deleted.\\\\r\\\\n- The `getRequestVisibility(HttpVerb): Visibility` API is used to determine the visibility implied for data in the request parameters or body. Note that `Visibility.Read` is always applied for response data, so there is no corresponding API for the response.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo` API is used to create a metadata object for each program, which can then be used to reason about metadata and visibility implications.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.getEffectivePayloadType(Type, Visibility): Type` API is used recursively on every type that is referenced. It recovers the named model when given an anonymous model sourced entirely from a single named model after metadata is moved elsewhere or invisible properties are removed.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isTransformed(Model, Visibility)` API is used to check if a type undergoes any changes in shape due to visibility or metadata. If not, this can allow for simplifications in emit.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isPayloadProperty(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean` API is used to check if a property is transmitted as an object property in the payload and is not invisible or metadata sent elsewhere.\\\\n\\\\nnamed model after metadata is moved elsewhere or invisible properties are removed.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isTransformed(Model, Visibility)` API is used to check if a type undergoes any changes in shape due to visibility or metadata. If not, this can allow for simplifications in emit.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isPayloadProperty(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean` API is used to check if a property is transmitted as an object property in the payload and is not invisible or metadata sent elsewhere.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isOptional(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean` API is used to determine if a property is optional for the given visibility. This will differ from `ModelProperty.isOptional` when the Visibility is Update, in which case the property is always considered optional.\\\\r\\\\n- The `Visibility.Item` flag is added when recursing into an array. This moves all metadata into the payload, which can be useful in scenarios like batching API calls.\\\\r\\\\nBy understanding and correctly using these APIs and concepts, you can ensure that your emitter handles metadata and visibility consistently and effectively.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"standard-library#reference#typekits.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"[API] Typekits\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/reference/typekits\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# [API] Typekits\\\\n## model\\\\n### getEffectiveModel\\\\n# standard-library#reference#typekits.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# [API] Typekits\\\\n\\\\n## model\\\\n\\\\n### getEffectiveModel\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`ts\\\\r\\\\n/**\\\\r\\\\n * If the input is anonymous (or the provided filter removes properties) and there exists a named model with the same set of properties (ignoring filtered properties), then return that named model. Otherwise, return the input unchanged.\\\\r\\\\n *\\\\r\\\\n * This can be used by emitters to find a better name for a set of properties after filtering. For example, given `{  @metadata prop: string} \\\\u0026 SomeName`, and an emitter that wishes to discard properties marked with `@metadata`, the emitter can use this to recover that the best name for the remaining properties is `SomeName`.\\\\r\\\\n *\\\\r\\\\n * @param model - The input model\\\\r\\\\n *\\\\r\\\\n * @param filter - An optional filter to apply to the input model's properties.\\\\r\\\\n */\\\\r\\\\n$(program).model.getEffectiveModel(\\\\r\\\\n  model: Model,\\\\r\\\\n  filter: (property: ModelProperty) =\\\\u003e boolean\\\\r\\\\n): Model;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"standard-library#built-in-data-types.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Built-in Data types\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-data-types\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Built-in Data types\\\\n## TypeSpec\\\\n### `Query` {#Query}\\\\n# standard-library#built-in-data-types.md\\\\n\\\\n# Built-in Data types\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n### `Query` {#Query}\\\\n\\\\nA copy of the input model `T` with only the properties that are visible during the\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"Query\\\\\\\" resource lifecycle phase.\\\\r\\\\nThe \\\\\\\"Query\\\\\\\" lifecycle phase is used for properties passed as parameters to operations\\\\r\\\\nthat read data, like HTTP GET or HEAD operations. This should not be confused for\\\\r\\\\nthe `@query` decorator, which specifies that the property is transmitted in the\\\\r\\\\nquery string of an HTTP request.\\\\r\\\\nThis transformation is recursive, and will include only properties that have the\\\\r\\\\n`Lifecycle.Query` visibility modifier.\\\\r\\\\nIf a `NameTemplate` is provided, the new model will be named according to the template.\\\\r\\\\nThe template uses the same syntax as the `@friendlyName` decorator.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Query\\\\u003cT, NameTemplate\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Template Parameters\\\\r\\\\n| Name | Description |\\\\r\\\\n|------|-------------|\\\\r\\\\n| T | The model to transform. |\\\\r\\\\n| NameTemplate | The name template to use for the new model.\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003e\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003e* |\\\\r\\\\n#### Examples\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  // When getting information for a Dog, you can set this field to true to include\\\\r\\\\n  // some extra information about the Dog's pedigree that is normally not returned.\\\\r\\\\n  // Alternatively, you could just use a separate option parameter to get this\\\\r\\\\n  // information.\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Query)\\\\r\\\\n  includePedigree?: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  // Only included if `includePedigree` is set to true in the request.\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  pedigree?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// This model will have the `includePedigree` and `name` fields, but not `id` or `pedigree`.\\\\r\\\\nmodel QueryDog is Query\\\\u003cDog\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Visibility\\\\n# language-basics#visibility.md\\\\n\\\\n# Visibility\\\\n\\\\n**Visibility** is a language feature that allows you to share a model between multiple operations and define in which contexts\\\\r\\\\nproperties of the model are \\\\\\\"visible.\\\\\\\" Visibility is a very powerful feature that allows you to define different \\\\\\\"views\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nof a model within different operations or contexts.\\\\r\\\\n**Note** \\u26a0\\ufe0f: Enum-based visibility as described in this document _replaces_ visibility strings that you may have used\\\\r\\\\nin the past. The system is backwards-compatible with visibility strings, but you should use enum-based visibility for\\\\r\\\\nnew specifications. String-based visibility (e.g. `@visibility(\\\\\\\"create\\\\\\\")`) may be deprecated and removed in future\\\\r\\\\nversions of TypeSpec.\\\\n\\\\n## Basic concepts\\\\n\\\\n- Visibility applies to _model properties_ only. It is used to determine when an emitter should include or exclude a\\\\r\\\\n  property in a certain context.\\\\r\\\\n- Visibility is defined using a _visibility class_. A visibility class is an `enum` that defines the visibility modifiers\\\\r\\\\n  (or flags) that can be applied to a property. Any `enum` can serve as a visibility class.\\\\r\\\\n- Visibility classes have a _default_ visibility, which is the set of visibility modifiers that are applied _by default_\\\\r\\\\n  to a property if the visibility is not explicitly set.\\\\n\\\\n## Lifecycle visibility\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec provides a built-in visibility called \\\\\\\"resource lifecycle visibility.\\\\\\\" This visibility allows you to declare\\\\r\\\\nwhether properties are visible when passing a resource to or reading a resource from an API endpoint. For example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The unique identifier of this resource.\\\\r\\\\n   *\\\\r\\\\n   * The ID is @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The name of this resource.\\\\r\\\\n   *\\\\r\\\\n   * The name can be set when the resource is created, but may not be changed.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The description of this resource.\\\\r\\\\n   *\\\\r\\\\n   * By default, properties are visible in all lifecycle phases, so this property\\\\r\\\\n   * is present in all lifecycle phases.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  description: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the above example, each property of the `Example` model has a lifecycle visibility that instructs emitters to include\\\\r\\\\nor
