correct schema based on the lifecycle phase that the operations use.\\\\r\\\\n- The TypeSpec model is only defined _once_, and any changes in the output schemas are derived from the lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  visibility of the properties in the model.\\\\n\\\\n### Lifecycle modifiers\\\\n\\\\nThe following visibility modifiers are available in the `Lifecycle` visibility class:\\\\r\\\\n- `Create`: The property is visible when the resource is created. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `POST` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Read`: The property is visible when the resource is read. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property is\\\\r\\\\n  returned in an HTTP `GET` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Update`: The property is visible when the resource is updated. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `PATCH` or `PUT` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Delete`: The property is visible when a resource is deleted. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `DELETE` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Query`: The property is visible when a resource is passed as a parameter in a query. This visibility is checked, for\\\\r\\\\n  example, when a property is a parameter in an HTTP `GET` operation (**this should not be confused with an HTTP query\\\\r\\\\n  parameter defined using `@query`**).\\\\n\\\\n### Lifecycle visibility transforms\\\\n\\\\nYou can explicitly compute the shape of a model within a _specific_ lifecycle phase by using the four built-in\\\\r\\\\ntemplates for lifecycle transforms:\\\\r\\\\n- `Create\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Create` lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  phase, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Read\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Read` lifecycle phase,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Update\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Update` lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  phase, with the types of the properties set to `CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have _either_ the `Create` or `Update`\\\\r\\\\n  visibility modifiers enabled, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Delete\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have the `Lifecycle.Delete` modifier enabled,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Query\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have the `Lifecycle.Query` modifier enabled,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Update)\\\\r\\\\n  description: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReadExample is Read\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel CreateExample is Create\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel UpdateExample is Update\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel CreateOrUpdateExample is CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhen you use these templates, the resulting models have no `Lifecycle` visibility modifiers applied, so that any\\\\r\\\\nemitters or libraries that use lifecycle visibility will not alter them further.\\\\n\\\\n## Visibility modifiers\\\\n\\\\nEach property has its own set of _active visibility modifiers_ for each visibility class. Operations\\\\n## Automatic visibility\\\\n# libraries#http#operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# Operations\\\\n\\\\n## Automatic visibility\\\\n\\\\nThe `@typespec/rest` library understands [Lifecycle Visibility](../../language-basics/visibility.md#lifecycle-visibility) and provides functionality for emitters to apply visibility transforms based on whether a model represents a request or response and on HTTP method usage as detailed in the table below.\\\\r\\\\nSee [handling visibility and metadata](../../extending-typespec/emitter-metadata-handling.md) for details on how to incorporate this information into an emitter implementation.\\\\r\\\\n| Modifier         | Visible in           |\\\\r\\\\n| ---------------- | -------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| Lifecycle.Read   | Any response         |\\\\r\\\\n| Lifecycle.Query  | GET or HEAD request  |\\\\r\\\\n| Lifecycle.Create | POST or PUT request  |\\\\r\\\\n| Lifecycle.Update | PATCH or PUT request |\\\\r\\\\n| Lifecycle.Delete | DELETE request       |\\\\r\\\\nThis allows a single logical TypeSpec model to be used as in the following example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel User {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create) password: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/users\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\ninterface Users {\\\\r\\\\n  @post create(@path id: string, ...User): User;\\\\r\\\\n  @get get(@path id: string): User;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThere is a single logical user entity represented by the single TypeSpec type `User`, but the HTTP payload for this entity varies based on context. When returned in a response, the `id` property is included, but when sent in a request, it is not. Similarly, the `password` property is only included in create requests, but not present in responses.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI v3 emitter will apply these visibilities automatically, without explicit use of `@withVisibility`, and it will generate separate schemas suffixed by visibility when necessary. `@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)` can be expressed in OpenAPI without generating additional schema by specifying `readOnly: true` and the OpenAPI v3 emitter will leverage this a an optimization, but other visibilities will generate additional schemas.\\\\n\\\\nincluded in create requests, but not present in responses.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI v3 emitter will apply these visibilities automatically, without explicit use of `@withVisibility`, and it will generate separate schemas suffixed by visibility when necessary. `@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)` can be expressed in OpenAPI without generating additional schema by specifying `readOnly: true` and the OpenAPI v3 emitter will leverage this a an optimization, but other visibilities will generate additional schemas. For example, `@visibility(Lifecycle.Create)` applied to a model property of a type named Widget will generate a `WidgetCreate` schema.\\\\r\\\\nAnother emitter such as one generating client code can see and preserve a single logical type and deal with these HTTP payload differences by means other than type proliferation.\\\\r\\\\nModeling with logical entities rather than HTTP-specific shapes also keeps the TypeSpec spec decoupled from HTTP and REST and can allow the same spec to be used with multiple protocols.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_08_29.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"How to properly set read-only property?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to properly set read-only property?\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_29.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to properly set read-only property?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nIn our API spec we have a read-only property which will always be set in the response by the server. So we had it set up like this:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"...\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  entityName: string;\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nWe did not set it as nullable since we want to indicate to the user that they can rely on the property to always be set. \\\\r\\\\nHowever, the auto-generated ARM schema seems to be confused by this. This is the warning I'm getting from Intellisense when writing the Bicep file:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThe specified \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\" declaration is missing the following required properties: \\\\\\\"entityName\\\\\\\". If this is a resource type definition inaccuracy, report it using https://aka.ms/bicep-type-issues. bicep(BCP035)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nproperties: DiscoveryRuleProperties\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThe resource-specific properties for this resource.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nView Problem (\\u2325F8) Quick Fix... (\\u2318.) Fix (\\u23181)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nproperties: {\\\\r\\\\n  addRecommendedSignals: 'Enabled'\\\\r\\\\n  authenticationSetting: 'SystemAssigned'\\\\r\\\\n  discoverRelationships: 'Enabled'\\\\r\\\\n  resourceGraphQuery: 'resources | where id startswith \\\\\\\"/subscriptions/00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000\\\\\\\"'\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nOf course, if I add it, I - correctly - get a warning that the property is read-only.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThe property \\\\\\\"entityName\\\\\\\" is read-only. Expressions cannot be assigned to read-only properties. If this is a resource type definition inaccuracy, report it using https://aka.ms/bicep-type-issues. bicep(BCP073)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nentityName: string\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nName of the entity which represents the discovery rule. Note: It might take a few minutes after creating the discovery rule until the entity is created.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nView Problem (\\u2325F8) Quick Fix... (\\u2318.) Fix (\\u23181)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nentityName: 'foo'\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nAny advise is much appreciated!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe property was correctly encoded in TypeSpec using @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) and not marked as nullable, which is appropriate since the property is always set by the service. The ARM template schema is generated automatically from the OpenAPI JSON file in the public API spec repo, and the generated file does mark entityName as readOnly.\\\\r\\\\nThe issue seems to stem from how the schema generator interprets required and readOnly. Specifically, it assumes required applies only to writable views of the resource body, which leads to misleading IntelliSense warnings in Bicep. This is likely due to shared logic in the Bicep and schema generation code.\\\\r\\\\nOptionality in OpenAPI is context-dependent\\u2014relevant to either requests or responses\\u2014while in TypeSpec, optionality for resource types indicates whether a property is part of the resource conceptually. Nullability, on the other hand, means the property accepts null in requests, which is discouraged in Azure.\\\\r\\\\nA proposed fix is already under discussion here: question\\\\n\\\\nI have these lintDiff [errors](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/actions/runs/16303501902): \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n| ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly | provisioningState So, unless you are thinking that a user can actually set the value for any of the changed unions,  that is the recommendation. \\\\r\\\\n`readOnly` requirements in lintdiff are bit over-used,  there is no difference between a response-only property that is marked as 'readOnly'  and a response-only property that is unmarked.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Readonly on model\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Readonly on model\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Readonly on model\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe have such swagger\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  readonly: true,\\\\r\\\\n  properties: {}\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"AnotherModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  properties: {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      $ref: \\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nWhen the type of property \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\" in another model is that \\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\", M4 will give a readonly on that property \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\". I want to confirm if the equivalent TypeSpec should be\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel AnotherModel {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  a: ReadonlyOnModel;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReadonlyOnModel {}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\ncc Alitzel Mendez : Common type replacement relates to this. I remember we have several models in the original common type have readonly on them and you removed these because TypeSpec cannot represent readonly on model. Then if any service refers to this model, those properties might need to be updated.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec can only attach readOnly to properties, not to models or scalars.  Functionally (assuming all references to ReadOnlyModel are through readOnly properties),  these Swagger docs are equivalent, see: [autorest/docs/openapi/howto/$ref-siblings.md at main \\u00b7 Azure/autorest](https://github.com/Azure/autorest/blob/main/docs/openapi/howto/%24ref-siblings.md) from the perspective of both TypeSpec and autorest, these descriptions are equivalent.\\\"}]\"}"}]

response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"You do NOT need to manually add a visibilityFilter or use @withVisibilityFilter/@withVisibility decorators to restrict properties to Read visibility when your TypeSpec model is only used as a return result of an operation. This behavior is implicit in TypeSpec when using the standard HTTP library and emitters. \\n\\nTypeSpec automatically applies Lifecycle visibility based on the context in which the model is used. For response payloads (such as the return type of a GET operation), only properties marked with @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) will be included in the emitted OpenAPI schema, and those properties will be marked as readOnly. Properties without the Read visibility will be excluded from the response schema.\\n\\nYou only need to use visibility decorators (like @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)) on the individual properties that should be read-only. The emitter will handle the rest. Explicit use of @withVisibilityFilter is only necessary if you want to create custom filtered views of a model outside the standard lifecycle phases, or if you need a named model with a specific filtered shape for other purposes.\\n\\nExample:\\n```typespec\\nmodel Result {\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\n  id: string;\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\n  status: string;\\n  // This property will NOT appear in the response\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create)\\n  secret: string;\\n}\\n\\n@route(\\\"/result\\\")\\ninterface Results {\\n  @get getResult(): Result;\\n}\\n```\\nIn this example, only 'id' and 'status' will be present in the response schema, and both will be marked as readOnly in OpenAPI. No additional visibilityFilter is required.\", \"ground_truth\": \"ou do not need to explicitly add a visibilityFilter or use @withVisibility(Lifecycle.Read) if your model is only used as the return result of an operation. TypeSpec's HTTP library and standard emitters automatically apply Lifecycle.Read visibility to properties when a model is used as a return type. By default, properties are included in the response if they have Lifecycle.Read visibility, and all properties have all visibilities enabled unless you restrict them with @visibility.\\nTherefore, unless you have properties with more restrictive visibilities, all properties will be included in the response by default. If you want to limit which properties are returned, you should annotate those properties with @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) or other appropriate modifiers, but you do not need to explicitly use a visibilityFilter just because a model is a response type.\\nIf you use the built-in Lifecycle visibility model as intended, the behavior you expect is implicit and handled automatically for response models.\"}"}]

actual.answer:
1. **Model Validation Error (Additional properties not allowed):**

The error about additional properties (groupIds, privateLinkServiceConnectionState, privateEndpoint, provisioningState) not being allowed typically occurs when the resource model does not correctly inherit from the expected common-types resource. For PrivateEndpointConnection, you should use the Azure Resource Manager template provided in the TypeSpec Azure libraries, specifically `Azure.ResourceManager.PrivateEndpointConnectionResource` or `Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.PrivateEndpointConnection`.

You do **not** need to rename the model when leveraging from common-types. The name of the resource type (e.g., `PrivateEndpointConnection`) does not affect the API contract as long as the model structure matches the expected shape. Some RPs rename for clarity, but it is not required. The reviewer may provide guidance, but using the common-types model directly is the recommended approach.

To resolve the validation error, ensure your TypeSpec model is structured like this:

```typespec
import "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager";

model PrivateEndpointConnection is Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.PrivateEndpointConnectionParameter, Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.PrivateEndpointConnection {}
```
Or, if you need to add parameters:
```typespec
model PrivateEndpointConnection is Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.PrivateEndpointConnection {
  ...Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.PrivateEndpointConnectionParameter;
}
```
This ensures the model includes the required properties and matches the common-types definition, which will resolve the additional properties error.

2. **Avocado Error (API removal):**

Avocado reports errors when an API is removed (e.g., `revokeCertificate` replaced by `revokeCertificates`). If you do not need to support the older preview API, you can remove it entirely. If you must keep the older API for backward compatibility, you should suppress the Avocado error. See the suppression guide: https://aka.ms/ci-fix and https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues.

**Summary:**
- You can retain the same resource name as in common-types; renaming is optional and not required for validation.
- Fix the model validation by ensuring your TypeSpec model correctly extends or composes the common-types resource.
- For Avocado errors due to API removal, either remove the old API if not needed or suppress the error if backward compatibility is required.

If your PR needs special treatment, you can contact the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo | \\\\r\\\\n| I need a review to merge changes to a non-standard branch (e.g. not `main`, `RPSaaSMaster`, etc.) | Contact the owner of that branch. |\\\\r\\\\n| EngSys is behaving badly in my non-standard/release branch | Update the state of the branch to match with `main`. The owner of the release branch is responsible for doing this. See documentation: [Update your branch with changes from main](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish#update-your-branch-with-changes-from-main). |\\\\r\\\\n| I need to set up suppressions for LintDiff violations in my PR | See [Adding Scoped Suppressions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff) | \\\\r\\\\n| I have specific questions about the inner workings of ARM, testing changes to APIs, or rollout/release schedules | Talk to the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo |\\\\r\\\\n| I see an Avocado error `MULTIPLE_API_VERSION` | There is a coordinated effort to fix this. Reach out to the relevant parties. [This PR](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/pull/157) gives more context on why this was upgraded to an error. If relevant parties agree, the PR can be unblocked by adding the `Approved-Avocado` label to the PR. |\\\\r\\\\n| I merged a PR, when does the REST API documentation update on the Learn site? | Docs are published every week on Tuesdays | \\\\r\\\\n| If the specs in the standard branches of `RPSaaSMaster` and `RPSaaSDev` are out of sync, who is responsible for syncing them with main? | The spec owner is responsible for syncing their service\\u2019s spec files from `main` to `RPSaaSMaster/RPSaaSDev` to ensure consistency across branches. |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\\n\\\\n# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nendpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Have observed some RPs have leveraged from commonTypes but renamed as PrivateEndpointConnectionResource in their tsp file.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n2. Avocado error: I have removed an API revokeCertificate and added a new api revokeCertificates which takes an array. \\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nHow do I fix both errors?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n [Added private endpoint connection, bulk revocation and c2pa certificate type by amritas \\u00b7 Pull Requ\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24553)\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nModel validation Error - Additional properties not allowed: groupIds, privateLinkServiceConnectionState,privateEndpoint,provisioningState\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nPEC contract - \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.CodeSigning;\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Private endpoint connection resource.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection\\\\r\\\\n    is ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnectionProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n    ...PrivateEndpointConnectionParameter;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations(PrivateEndpointConnection)\\\\r\\\\ninterface PrivateEndpointConnections {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Get a specific private connection */\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Create a Private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Delete the private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** List private endpoint connections on the given resource */\\\\r\\\\n  list is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\n\\\\nlistPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\r\\\\nThis will then get consumed by teams authoring Azure APIs. As such, they have the Azure linting in place (naming conventions and whatnot).\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe wanted to know whether definitions can also come with suppressions (not inline, as this definition is auto-importer on a regular basis), which would apply ONLY to the definitions we share, not to the rest of the consumer's project?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nThanks!\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nsuppression can only be provided inline for now. Linter rules can be disabled globally but that would apply to the whole project, can't filter by files\\\\n\\\\noperations to any resourc,e see: \\\\r\\\\n[typespec-azure/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-end\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-endpoints.tsp#L69-L94)\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cEmployee, EmployeeProperties\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n deletePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.DeleteAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\n\\\\nI have the below PR [adding shared limit typespec by parthshah2305 \\u00b7 Pull Request #24115 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24115) where some of the LintDiff validations are failing with the exception \\\\r\\\\n``` \\\\r\\\\n  Violation: file:///home/runner/work/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/after/specification/limit/resource-manager/Microsoft.Limit/Limit/stable/2025-08-15/Limit.json:578\\\\r\\\\n    Level: error\\\\r\\\\n    Code: RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel\\\\r\\\\n    Message: Model definition 'SharingDetail' must have the properties 'name', 'id' and 'type' in its hierarchy and these properties must be marked as readonly.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThis particular model is defined as follows - \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel SharingDetail {\\\\r\\\\n  role: SharingRole;\\\\r\\\\n  sharedLimits?: QuotaLimitProperties[];\\\\r\\\\n  guestSubscriptions?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  host?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nIs it possible have a suppression for this validation? If so, how?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nthe link for lintdiff suppressions:\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nyou probably want to fix this in your spec, not suppress the error\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nYou need to fix check \\\\\\\"TypeSpec Validation\\\\\\\" in your PR, before other check results will even be valid.  This is documented in the \\\\\\\"next steps to merge\\\\\\\" comment in your PR.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Model validations are failing although am referring from common-types\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\n1. I have reused the model Private endpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Let me know if the PrivateEndpointConnection should be a customized name or can retain same name as in commonTypes?\\\\r\\\\n Would this be guided by the reviewer?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nLooking at your PR, it seems that the avocado error is the only remaining one - this is just reporting that you have removed an API. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n# Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Table Of Content\\\\n\\\\n### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n\\\\n1. Create a branch in your local repository for your changes.\\\\r\\\\n2. Create or update the TypeSpec files for your service.\\\\r\\\\n3. Add or update 'examples' files for each operation of your OpenAPI file.\\\\r\\\\n   The [oav](https://github.com/Azure/oav) provides two ways to generate OpenAPI examples:\\\\r\\\\n   1. testcase: Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR

expected.answer: Part of the typespec conversion is replacing the existing swagger with a generated swagger.  The generated swagger is still used for some purposes, and Avocado protects the ability to process it. The generated swagger needs to be equivalent, but not necessarily identical.  Generally these issues reflected in the swagger will also show up in breaking change checks, which will have to be resolved (or suppressed if they are false positives)

actual.answer: For TypeSpec conversion PRs, the Avocado 'missing APIs in default tag' check is triggered because the generated Swagger is compared against the previous stable release. Even though your PR only contains TypeSpec conversion and does not update the OpenAPI spec directly, the generated Swagger must be equivalent to the previous version to pass validation. Suppression of this check is not generally supported for TypeSpec conversion PRs. If the missing APIs are a result of false positives (for example, due to renames or moves that Avocado cannot track), you may request a one-time suppression by applying the 'Approved-Avocado' label to your PR, but this is only a temporary workaround until the underlying tooling is fixed. Ultimately, you should ensure that the generated Swagger matches the previous stable release in terms of API surface, or resolve/suppress any breaking changes as needed. Permanent suppression is not allowed for this scenario; you must resolve the issue or request a one-time suppression if justified.

testcase: ArmResourcePatchAsync & discriminator

expected.answer: we generally suggest that PATCH requests over discriminated types should require the discriminator property.  This may result in some lintdiff violations, but that is expected, and those cna be suppressed.  This is especially true if, as most services, your PATCH operation would need the discriminator value on the wire to determine how to apply the PATCH request to the existing reosurce.

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: ArmResourcePatchAsync & discriminator\\n\\nquestion: I was trying to figure out the best way to allow an update for a Host resource. I tried ArmResourcePatchAsync, but the resource has a discriminator. oav fails with OBJECT_MISSING_REQUIRED_PROPERTY_DEFINITION .  [Windows Server AHB for VMware via PATCH by cataggar \\u00b7 Pull Request #25538 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-sp\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/25538)\", \"response\": \"To implement an update (PATCH) operation for a Host resource with a discriminator in TypeSpec, you should use the standard ARM PATCH operation templates, but you must ensure that your resource's update model correctly includes the discriminator property as required. The OBJECT_MISSING_REQUIRED_PROPERTY_DEFINITION error from oav typically means the PATCH request body (the update model) is missing a required property\\u2014often the discriminator itself.\\n\\nIn TypeSpec, discriminators are defined using the @discriminator decorator on a model, and the property (e.g., 'kind' or 'type') must be present and required in all derived models. For PATCH operations, the update model must include the discriminator property so that clients and validation tools (like oav) can correctly identify the type being updated.\\n\\nHere's how you should structure your resource and PATCH operation:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@discriminator(\\\"kind\\\")\\nmodel Host {\\n  kind: HostKind;\\n  // other properties\\n}\\n\\nunion HostKind {\\n  string,\\n  Windows: \\\"windows\\\",\\n  Linux: \\\"linux\\\"\\n}\\n\\nmodel WindowsHost extends Host {\\n  kind: HostKind.Windows;\\n  // windows-specific properties\\n}\\n\\nmodel LinuxHost extends Host {\\n  kind: HostKind.Linux;\\n  // linux-specific properties\\n}\\n\\n// The PATCH update model must include the discriminator\\nmodel HostUpdate {\\n  kind?: HostKind; // Optional for PATCH, but must be present if updating type\\n  // other updatable properties\\n}\\n\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Hosts {\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchAsync<Host, HostUpdate>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nKey points:\\n- Use ArmCustomPatchAsync (or ArmCustomPatchSync for synchronous) and provide a custom update model that includes the discriminator property.\\n- The update model should allow the discriminator property to be present (optional for PATCH, but required if switching types).\\n- Ensure the discriminator property is defined in the update model so oav can validate the PATCH body correctly.\\n\\nIf you use ArmResourcePatchAsync directly with a resource that has a discriminator, the generated update model may not include the discriminator property, causing oav to fail. By explicitly defining a custom update model (as above), you resolve this issue and comply with ARM and TypeSpec best practices.\", \"ground_truth\": \"we generally suggest that PATCH requests over discriminated types should require the discriminator property.  This may result in some lintdiff violations, but that is expected, and those cna be suppressed.  This is especially true if, as most services, your PATCH operation would need the discriminator value on the wire to determine how to apply the PATCH request to the existing reosurce.\"}"}]

groundedness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"To implement an update (PATCH) operation for a Host resource with a discriminator in TypeSpec, you should use the standard ARM PATCH operation templates, but you must ensure that your resource's update model correctly includes the discriminator property as required. The OBJECT_MISSING_REQUIRED_PROPERTY_DEFINITION error from oav typically means the PATCH request body (the update model) is missing a required property\\u2014often the discriminator itself.\\n\\nIn TypeSpec, discriminators are defined using the @discriminator decorator on a model, and the property (e.g., 'kind' or 'type') must be present and required in all derived models. For PATCH operations, the update model must include the discriminator property so that clients and validation tools (like oav) can correctly identify the type being updated.\\n\\nHere's how you should structure your resource and PATCH operation:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@discriminator(\\\"kind\\\")\\nmodel Host {\\n  kind: HostKind;\\n  // other properties\\n}\\n\\nunion HostKind {\\n  string,\\n  Windows: \\\"windows\\\",\\n  Linux: \\\"linux\\\"\\n}\\n\\nmodel WindowsHost extends Host {\\n  kind: HostKind.Windows;\\n  // windows-specific properties\\n}\\n\\nmodel LinuxHost extends Host {\\n  kind: HostKind.Linux;\\n  // linux-specific properties\\n}\\n\\n// The PATCH update model must include the discriminator\\nmodel HostUpdate {\\n  kind?: HostKind; // Optional for PATCH, but must be present if updating type\\n  // other updatable properties\\n}\\n\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Hosts {\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchAsync<Host, HostUpdate>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nKey points:\\n- Use ArmCustomPatchAsync (or ArmCustomPatchSync for synchronous) and provide a custom update model that includes the discriminator property.\\n- The update model should allow the discriminator property to be present (optional for PATCH, but required if switching types).\\n- Ensure the discriminator property is defined in the update model so oav can validate the PATCH body correctly.\\n\\nIf you use ArmResourcePatchAsync directly with a resource that has a discriminator, the generated update model may not include the discriminator property, causing oav to fail. By explicitly defining a custom update model (as above), you resolve this issue and comply with ARM and TypeSpec best practices.\", \"context\": \"[{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n### Converting Synchronous Operations to LROs\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n\\\\n### Converting Synchronous Operations to LROs\\\\n\\\\nYou can generally choose an asynchronous operation template that matches your operation.\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async PUT Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync` is a PUT operation that uses the 'resource' definition in the request body, and returns a `200` response and a `201` response, both of which contain the created/updated resource in the response payload. The 201 response contains a `Location` LRO header.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op createOrUpdate is ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCreateOrUpdateAsync` is a PUT operation that uses the 'resource' definition in the request body, and returns a `200` response and a `201` response, both of which contain the created/updated resource in the response payload. The 201 response contains an `Azure-AsyncOperation` LRO header.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op createOrUpdate is ArmCreateOrUpdateAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async PATCH Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmTagsPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that only allows changing the resource tags (the minimum for Azure Resource Manager).\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmTagsPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourcePatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that uses the visibility settings to select properties for the PATCH request body (any property with no visibility setting, or including visibility \\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\"). It follows the required 202 pattern to resolve the LRO via location, although this can be customized using the `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, ResourceProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCustomPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that allows you to customize the PATCH request body.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, PatchRequestBody\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async POST (Action) Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceActionAsync` is a POST operation that allows you to specify the request and response body for a resource action operation.\\\\n\\\\nthe `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, ResourceProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCustomPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that allows you to customize the PATCH request body.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, PatchRequestBody\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async POST (Action) Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceActionAsync` is a POST operation that allows you to specify the request and response body for a resource action operation. It follows the required 202 pattern to resolve the LRO via location, although this can be customized using the `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuff is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, ActionRequest, ActionResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // With no request body\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuffNoRequest is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, void, ActionResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // With no response body\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuffCommand is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, ActionRequest, void\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async DELETE Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOKAsync` is a DELETE operation that uses no request body, will return a `202` response in the case of an asynchronous delete operation, and a `204` response in case the resource does not exist.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOKAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceDeleteAsync` is a DELETE operation that uses no request body, and returns a `200` response in the case of a successful synchronous delete, a `202` response in the case of an asynchronous delete operation, and a `204` response in case the resource does not exist.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op delete is ArmResourceDeleteAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#resource-operations.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"ARM Resource Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/resource-operations\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# ARM Resource Operations\\\\n## TypeSpec Operation Templates and Interface Templates\\\\n### Resource Update Operations (PATCH)\\\\n# howtos#arm#resource-operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# ARM Resource Operations\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec Operation Templates and Interface Templates\\\\n\\\\n### Resource Update Operations (PATCH)\\\\n\\\\nARM Requires that all `Tracked` resources implement PATCH for ARM tags, which are contained in the\\\\r\\\\nenvelope of every `TrackedResource`. ARM recommends that you also allow PATCH of other envelope\\\\r\\\\nproperties and resource-specific properties. Unless marked with a specific visibility, any property\\\\r\\\\nin your rp-specific properties will be automatically included in the PATCH schema.\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec Provides both Synchronous and Asynchronous PATCH Operations, and allows you to specify a\\\\r\\\\nPATCH for Resource tags only, a PATCH for all updateable properties, or a custom patch. Generally,\\\\r\\\\nyou should choose the patch for all updateable properties, unless you have a very good reason for\\\\r\\\\nchoosing another PATCH operation.\\\\r\\\\n| Operation Description      | TypeSpec                                                                                                                                   |\\\\r\\\\n| -------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |\\\\r\\\\n| Sync TagsOnly PATCH        | `update is ArmTagsPatchSync\\\\u003cResourceType\\\\u003e`                                                                                                 |\\\\r\\\\n| Async TagsOnly PATCH       | `update is ArmTagsPatchAsync\\\\u003cResourceType\\\\u003e`                                                                                                |\\\\r\\\\n| Sync All Properties PATCH  | `update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003cResourceType, Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cResourceType, ResourcePropertiesType\\\\u003e\\\\u003e`  |\\\\r\\\\n| Async All Properties PATCH | `update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResourceType, Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cResourceType, ResourcePropertiesType\\\\u003e\\\\u003e` |\\\\r\\\\nThe ArmResourcePatch\\\\\\\\* templates take the resource type and the resource properties type as\\\\r\\\\nparameters. The ArmTagsPatch\\\\\\\\* templates take the resource type as a parameter. The ArmCustomPatch\\\\\\\\*\\\\n\\\\nArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003cResourceType, Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cResourceType, ResourcePropertiesType\\\\u003e\\\\u003e`  |\\\\r\\\\n| Async All Properties PATCH | `update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResourceType, Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cResourceType, ResourcePropertiesType\\\\u003e\\\\u003e` |\\\\r\\\\nThe ArmResourcePatch\\\\\\\\* templates take the resource type and the resource properties type as\\\\r\\\\nparameters. The ArmTagsPatch\\\\\\\\* templates take the resource type as a parameter. The ArmCustomPatch\\\\\\\\*\\\\r\\\\ntemplates take the resource type and your custom PATCH request type as parameters.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n### Customizing Request Payload Parameter Names\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n\\\\n### Customizing Request Payload Parameter Names\\\\n\\\\nFor operations with request bodies (PUT, POST, PATCH), TypeSpec operation templates provide default names for request parameters. You can use augment decorators to customize these parameter names and other parts of the operation signature.\\\\r\\\\nThe following sections show how to do this for each operation template.\\\\r\\\\n#### CreateOrUpdate (PUT) APIs\\\\r\\\\nGiven a PUT operation, for example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\ninterface Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe name of the request body parameter is `resource`. You can change the name in clients using an augment decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Widgets.createOrUpdate::parameters.resource, \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdesired-request-body-parameter-name\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis works for any PUT operation template.\\\\r\\\\n#### Update (PATCH) APIs\\\\r\\\\nGiven a PATCH operation, for example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\ninterface Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cWidget, WidgetProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe name of the request body parameter is `properties`. You can change the name in clients using an augment decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Widgets.update::parameters.properties, \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdesired-request-body-parameter-name\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis works for any PATCH operation template.\\\\r\\\\n#### Action (POST) APIs\\\\r\\\\nGiven a POST operation, for example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\ninterface Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  mungeWidget is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cWidget, MungeRequest, MungeResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe name of the request body parameter is `body`. You can change the name in clients using an augment decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Widgets.mungeWidget::parameters.body, \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdesired-request-body-parameter-name\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis works for any POST operation template.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"We cannot customize the Type for How could I represent this operation in TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n/** Employee move response */\\\\r\\\\nmodel MoveResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The status of the move */\\\\r\\\\n  movingStatus: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\ninterface Operations extends Azure.ResourceManager.Operations {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      Employee,\\\\r\\\\n      EmployeeProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** long-running get statistics */\\\\r\\\\n  getStatistics is ArmProviderActionAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    void,\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      ...OkResponse;\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n    SubscriptionActionScope\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nBut, in this case, this looks like they are modeling a subscription-level operationResult resource, which should just be modeled as a resource operation get that is not long-running.\\\\n\\\\nlong-running GET is not allowed in ARM, or in Azure at all. Operations\\\\n## JSON Merge-Patch\\\\n### The MergePatch Transform\\\\n# libraries#http#operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# Operations\\\\n\\\\n## JSON Merge-Patch\\\\n\\\\n### The MergePatch Transform\\\\n\\\\nGeneralizing these rules creates a type transform of the resource Model into a Model defining the corresponding Patch request body. The properties of a resource define the allowed properties and their types in a Patch request body for that resource as follows:\\\\r\\\\n- The `type` of a property indicates the allowed type of the corresponding property in a Patch request.\\\\r\\\\n- `Required` properties without a default value are _optional_ in a Patch request, but if present, the value cannot be null.\\\\r\\\\n- `Optional` properties are _optional_ in a Patch request, and, if present, can contain any valid value or null.\\\\r\\\\n- Properties with a default value are _optional_ in a Patch request, but have no default value in the request body. If present, they can contain any valid value or null. A _null_ value will not erase the property, but set it back to its default value.\\\\r\\\\n- `Model` and `Record` typed properties, when present in a Patch request are merged with the existing resource value in accordance with the merge-patch algorithm: this transformation is recursively applied to these values.\\\\r\\\\n- `Array` typed properties, when present in a Patch request replace the existing resource value in accordance with the merge-patch algorithm. This transformation is _not_ recursively applied to these values.\\\\r\\\\n- Properties required to deserialize a request (for example, discriminators) are _required_ in a Patch request body.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_migration_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec-migration-docs-2025-09-12.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"rename duplicated model Additional parameters after the path parameters |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning the LRO headers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI am reaching out to seek advice about versioning the LRO header: \\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Define contract for Batch RuleSet feature by mangoo1 \\u00b7 Pull Request #37879 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-s\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37879)\\\\r\\\\nis about to extend an existing RuleSet PUT endpoint to allow it accepting an optional request body, the feature would be turned on when we specify a bool flag to true and the PUT endpoint would be extend to 201 LRO.  \\\\r\\\\nThis behavior would be available on the new ApiVersion, so I would like to put the Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia annotation to the new ApiVersion, along with LRO/Async headers ArmAsyncOperationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e and ArmLroLocationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e.  But I still won't be able to find a way to put the @added(version) annotations to them.  \\\\r\\\\nCan I version the operation to achieve this?  [Versioning | TypeSpec](https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning/#version-specific-operations) \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the recommended way to do this?\\\\r\\\\n(1.The original put request doesn't have a request body, so I make the put request body optional for backwards compatibility.\\\\r\\\\n2.There is an optional bool flag in the optional request body to turn the feature requires LRO ON.)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n@sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    OptionalRequestBody = true\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      Employee,\\\\r\\\\n      EmployeeProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is Reference\\\\n# v1.0#resource-api-reference.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resource API Reference\\\\n\\\\nThese are the APIs that are implemented by resource providers (a.k.a. RPs) when exposing resource types through Azure Resource Manager (a.k.a ARM). This section is divided into further sub sections for easy reading as follows.\\\\r\\\\n- [Uri format and arguments for CRUD APIs on Resources](./uri-format-and-arguments-for-crud-apis-on-resources.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Put Resource](./put-resource.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Patch Resource](./patch-resource.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Delete Resource](./delete-resource.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Get Resource](./get-resource.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Pagination](./pagination.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Move Resource](./move-resource.md)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003eNOTE: Each of these pages has an `Overview` and a `Rules` section. The `Overview` section provides general information about the topic. The `Rules` section enumerates a list of granular rules that service owners should implement. Each rule has an RPC guideline code, Title, Conformance level, Additional impact and a link to the linter rule if the ruleis automated. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `RPC guideline code` column has values in the format `RPC-{Category}-V1-{serialNumber}`. This code will used for various reporting and tracking purposes.  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Title` column describes the rule.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Conformance level` column has one of the following values - [Required | Recommended | Allowed]. All `Required` rules are enforced using automated linter rules and **must** be adhered to. Violating these rules results in **errors** to be flagged by the automated checks and blocks the OpenAPI spec PRs from getting approved. All `Recommended` rules are strong suggestions, some of which are also automated using linter rules. Violating these rules results in **warnings** to be flagged by the automated checks. All `Allowed` rules simply specify what a service team is allowed to do.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Additional impact` column describes any additional impact the specific rule has on APIs that violate the rule over and above the general impact described for the section.\\\\n\\\\nand blocks the OpenAPI spec PRs from getting approved. All `Recommended` rules are strong suggestions, some of which are also automated using linter rules. Violating these rules results in **warnings** to be flagged by the automated checks. All `Allowed` rules simply specify what a service team is allowed to do.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Additional impact` column describes any additional impact the specific rule has on APIs that violate the rule over and above the general impact described for the section.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Applicabale scope` column describes the scope to which the specific rule applies to. It has one of the following values [ Design | Runtime ]. The value `Design` means that the rule applies to the API design. This means that the rule will be in scope starting from the API design reviews and will most likely also be covered by linter rules. All rules that are in scope for the design phase automatically imply that the runtime will also adhere to it. The value `Runtime` means that the rule applies exclusivley to the runtime implementation of the API. Such a rule cannot be enforced at design time as it refers to something that the actual service runtime is expected to adhere to.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Linter rule` column points to the documentation for the error received when this rule is violated in your OpenAPI specification.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"libraries#azure-resource-manager#reference#interfaces.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Interfaces and Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-resource-manager/reference/interfaces\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Interfaces and Operations\\\\n## Azure.ResourceManager\\\\n### `ArmResourcePatchAsync` {#Azure.ResourceManager.ArmResourcePatchAsync}\\\\n# libraries#azure-resource-manager#reference#interfaces.md\\\\n\\\\n# Interfaces and Operations\\\\n\\\\n## Azure.ResourceManager\\\\n\\\\n### `ArmResourcePatchAsync` {#Azure.ResourceManager.ArmResourcePatchAsync}\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nop Azure.ResourceManager.ArmResourcePatchAsync(provider: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.ThisWillBeReplaced\\\\\\\", properties: Resource): Azure.ResourceManager.ArmResponse\\\\u003cResponseBody\\\\u003e | Azure.ResourceManager.ArmAcceptedLroResponse\\\\u003cDescription, LroHeaders\\\\u003e | Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.ErrorResponse\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Template Parameters\\\\r\\\\n| Name           | Description                                                                   |\\\\r\\\\n| -------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| Resource       | the resource being patched                                                    |\\\\r\\\\n| Properties     | The model type of the resource properties                                     |\\\\r\\\\n| BaseParameters | Optional. files, you should put them under specification/limit/resource-manager/Microsoft.Limit/Limit/ as well as the tspconfig.yaml, you can take the widget specs as an example https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/widget/resource-manager \\\\r\\\\n2.Assuming you are an RPaaS services (because you are a new service and in azure-rest-api-specs-pr repo), you have to have a readme.md under resource-manager folder and which should contains the minimal information which is required from RPaaS to know that your service is a RPaaS services, you can also take a look at widget's example\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nopenapi-type: arm\\\\r\\\\nopenapi-subtype: rpaas\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nYou need to pay attention to the output file If set to `null` it is returned to its default value (`blue`)\\\\r\\\\n- `flavor` may or may not occur in the request, if it does occur, the resource value can be updated to one of the appropriate values. If set to `null` it is returned to its default value (`vanilla`)\\\\r\\\\n- `related` may or may not occur in the request, if it does occur, the resource value can be updated or erased (set to `{}`) by sending null.\\\\r\\\\n  - Since `related` is a keyed type (Object), each key/value pair in the request will be treated as follows:\\\\r\\\\n  - If the key exists in the 'related' field of the resource, the value is merged with the existing value.\\\\r\\\\n  - If the key does not exist in the 'related' field of the resource, the key/value pair is added.\\\\r\\\\n- `tags` may or may not occur in the request, if it does occur, the resource can be replaced by a new array, or erased by sending null.\\\\n\\\\n[RFC 7396](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7396) describes a standard for interpreting\\\\r\\\\na Patch request body using content-type `application/merge-patch+json`to update an existing\\\\r\\\\nresource. The TypeSpec Http library provides Model templates `MergePatchUpdate` and\\\\r\\\\n`MergePatchCreateOrUpdate` for specifying a JSON merge-patch request body. The templates\\\\r\\\\nrecursively apply the merge-patch transformation rules to a TypeSpec resource Model, taking\\\\r\\\\ninto account the structure and characteristics of the resource Model.\\\\r\\\\nFor example, given a resource model like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Resource {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  quantity?: safeint;\\\\r\\\\n  color: \\\\\\\"blue\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"green\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"red\\\\\\\" = \\\\\\\"blue\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  flavor?: \\\\\\\"vanilla\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"chocolate\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"strawberry\\\\\\\" = \\\\\\\"vanilla\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  related?: Record\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  tags?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nA JSON Merge-Patch request updating this resource would have the following behavior:\\\\r\\\\n- `id` may or may not occur in the request, if it does occur, the resource value can be updated to a new string, but cannot be erased by sending null.\\\\r\\\\n- `name` may or may not occur in the request, if it does occur, the resource value can be updated to a new string or erased by sending null.\\\\r\\\\n- `quantity` may or ay not occur in the request, if it does occur, the resource value can be updated to a new integer value or erased by sending null.\\\\r\\\\n- `color` may or may not occur in the request, if it does occur, the resource value can be updated to one of the appropriate values. If set to `null` it is returned to its default value (`blue`)\\\\r\\\\n- `flavor` may or may not occur in the request, if it does occur, the resource value can be updated to one of the appropriate values. If set to `null` it is returned to its default value (`vanilla`)\\\\r\\\\n- `related` may or may not occur in the request, if it does occur, the resource value can be updated or erased (set to `{}`) by sending null.\\\\n\\\\n### The MergePatch Transform\\\\n\\\\nGeneralizing these rules creates a type transform of the resource Model into a Model defining the corresponding Patch request body. The properties of a resource define the allowed properties and their types in a Patch request body for that resource as follows:\\\\r\\\\n- The `type` of a property indicates the allowed type of the corresponding property in a Patch request.\\\\r\\\\n- `Required` properties without a default value are _optional_ in a Patch request, but if present, the value cannot be null.\\\\r\\\\n- `Optional` properties are _optional_ in a Patch request, and, if present, can contain any valid value or null.\\\\r\\\\n- Properties with a default value are _optional_ in a Patch request, but have no default value in the request body. If present, they can contain any valid value or null. A _null_ value will not erase the property, but set it back to its default value.\\\\r\\\\n- `Model` and `Record` typed properties, when present in a Patch request are merged with the existing resource value in accordance with the merge-patch algorithm: this transformation is recursively applied to these values.\\\\r\\\\n- `Array` typed properties, when present in a Patch request replace the existing resource value in accordance with the merge-patch algorithm. This transformation is _not_ recursively applied to these values.\\\\r\\\\n- Properties required to deserialize a request (for example, discriminators) are _required_ in a Patch request body.\\\\n\\\\n### Constraints\\\\n\\\\nBecause JSON merge-patch only describes the request body of an http request, the merge-patch\\\\r\\\\ntransform in TypeSpec does not allow http envelope property metadata like `@query`, `@path`,\\\\r\\\\n`@header`, `@cookie`, and `@statusCode` in http requests.\\\\r\\\\nThe merge-patch templates will **emit an error diagnostic** if a model containing Http metadata\\\\r\\\\nproperties is passed in. For example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel ResourceWithMetadata {\\\\r\\\\n  @path id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @header eTag: string;\\\\r\\\\n  description: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// THIS WILL RESULT IN AN ERROR\\\\r\\\\n@patch op update(...MergePatchUpdate\\\\u003cResourceWithMetadata\\\\u003e): ResourceWithMetadata;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Patch Behavior of Nested Models\\\\n\\\\nModel types may be nested beneath the top level of a resource. The characteristics of the ModelProperty that references a nested Model type determines the valid values for that nested model in the Patch request. Here is how the valid values are determined for each of the model property types that might reference a nested model (also depicted in the following tables):\\\\r\\\\n- The property type is a (simple) Model or an intersection of models\\\\r\\\\n  - if the property is optional, the MergePatch transform applies, and the visibility is `CreateOrUpdate`. This is because, in an update, the property _may or may not_ exist if the resource exists, so might need to be created or updated.\\\\r\\\\n  - if the property is required, the MergePatch transform applies and the visibility matches the input visibility. This is because, in an update, the property _must_ exist if the resource exists, so it can only be updated. In a CreateOrUpdate, it could also be created with the resource.\\\\r\\\\n- The property type is an array (sequence) of model type items\\\\r\\\\n  - For required or optional arrays: The MergePatch transform _does not apply_ and the visibility is `Create`\\\\r\\\\n- The property type is a Record (keyed collection) of model type values\\\\r\\\\n  - For required or optional keyed collections, the MergePatch transform applies, and the visibility is create or update.\\\\r\\\\n- The property type is a union of model type values\\\\r\\\\n  - The MergePatch transform applies to each of the union variants, and because switching between variants is possible, CreateOrUpdate visibility is applied regardless of the optionality of the property. If the union is discriminated, the discriminator remains 'required' so the service can understand which variant the request was intended to apply to.\\\\n\\\\n### Treatment of Nested Keyed Types in response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"To implement an update (PATCH) operation for a Host resource with a discriminator in TypeSpec, you should use the standard ARM PATCH operation templates, but you must ensure that your resource's update model correctly includes the discriminator property as required. The OBJECT_MISSING_REQUIRED_PROPERTY_DEFINITION error from oav typically means the PATCH request body (the update model) is missing a required property\\u2014often the discriminator itself.\\n\\nIn TypeSpec, discriminators are defined using the @discriminator decorator on a model, and the property (e.g., 'kind' or 'type') must be present and required in all derived models. For PATCH operations, the update model must include the discriminator property so that clients and validation tools (like oav) can correctly identify the type being updated.\\n\\nHere's how you should structure your resource and PATCH operation:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@discriminator(\\\"kind\\\")\\nmodel Host {\\n  kind: HostKind;\\n  // other properties\\n}\\n\\nunion HostKind {\\n  string,\\n  Windows: \\\"windows\\\",\\n  Linux: \\\"linux\\\"\\n}\\n\\nmodel WindowsHost extends Host {\\n  kind: HostKind.Windows;\\n  // windows-specific properties\\n}\\n\\nmodel LinuxHost extends Host {\\n  kind: HostKind.Linux;\\n  // linux-specific properties\\n}\\n\\n// The PATCH update model must include the discriminator\\nmodel HostUpdate {\\n  kind?: HostKind; // Optional for PATCH, but must be present if updating type\\n  // other updatable properties\\n}\\n\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Hosts {\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchAsync<Host, HostUpdate>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nKey points:\\n- Use ArmCustomPatchAsync (or ArmCustomPatchSync for synchronous) and provide a custom update model that includes the discriminator property.\\n- The update model should allow the discriminator property to be present (optional for PATCH, but required if switching types).\\n- Ensure the discriminator property is defined in the update model so oav can validate the PATCH body correctly.\\n\\nIf you use ArmResourcePatchAsync directly with a resource that has a discriminator, the generated update model may not include the discriminator property, causing oav to fail. By explicitly defining a custom update model (as above), you resolve this issue and comply with ARM and TypeSpec best practices.\", \"ground_truth\": \"we generally suggest that PATCH requests over discriminated types should require the discriminator property.  This may result in some lintdiff violations, but that is expected, and those cna be suppressed.  This is especially true if, as most services, your PATCH operation would need the discriminator value on the wire to determine how to apply the PATCH request to the existing reosurce.\"}"}]

testcase: CI Failure – Swagger LintDiff

expected.answer: if you are fixing bugs already in main, this is expected.  lintdiff needs to run on your spec both before and after your PR, and if before is crashing, the PR to fix it will still crash.

actual.answer: The error '[Exception] No input files provided.' in the Swagger LintDiff CI check is expected behavior when you are fixing bugs that already exist in the main branch. LintDiff runs on your specification both before and after your PR. If the 'before' state (main branch) is already crashing due to missing or misconfigured input files, then your PR to fix it will still result in a crash for the CI check. This is not a bug in your PR, but rather a limitation of how LintDiff operates: it requires valid input files in both the base and PR branches. To resolve this, ensure that the main branch is fixed first, or coordinate with repo maintainers to unblock your PR. If you are certain your input-file paths are correct and present, this error is not caused by your changes but by the state of the main branch.

Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n# Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Table Of Content\\\\n\\\\n### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n\\\\n1. Create a branch in your local repository for your changes.\\\\r\\\\n2. Create or update the TypeSpec files for your service.\\\\r\\\\n3. Add or update 'examples' files for each operation of your OpenAPI file.\\\\r\\\\n   The [oav](https://github.com/Azure/oav) provides two ways to generate OpenAPI examples:\\\\r\\\\n   1. Generating basic examples and then manually modify the values. It will generate two examples for each operation:\\\\r\\\\n    one contains minimal properties set, the other contains the maximal properties set. Since the auto-generated\\\\r\\\\n     examples consist of random values for most types, you need replace them with meaningful values.\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\n       oav generate-examples openapi.json\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n    Note, latest OAV tool should automatically generate the following. However, if you are generating the examples manually,\\\\r\\\\n     please ensure you have:\\\\r\\\\n    - include `title` field and make sure it is descriptive and unique for each operation.\\\\r\\\\n    - include `operationId`. This is used to match with declared operations in TypeSpec and correctly output in OpenAPI.\\\\r\\\\n4. Add/update the `readme.md` file in the `{service}` folder to specify the version and location of the OpenAPI files. The `readme.md` is needed for both management-plane and data-plane services for REST API Docs generation.\\\\r\\\\n   Example:[sample-readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget/readme.md)\\\\r\\\\n5. Generate OpenAPI files:\\\\r\\\\n   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`git\\\\r\\\\n       git pull upstream \\\\u003ctarget-branch\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the root directory, run `npm install`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.\\\\r\\\\n6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.\\\\r\\\\n7. Send a pull request .\\\\r\\\\n   - commit all your changes.\\\\r\\\\n   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.\\\\n\\\\nOpenAPI files:\\\\r\\\\n   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`git\\\\r\\\\n       git pull upstream \\\\u003ctarget-branch\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the root directory, run `npm install`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.\\\\r\\\\n6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.\\\\r\\\\n7. Send a pull request .\\\\r\\\\n   - commit all your changes.\\\\r\\\\n   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.\\\\r\\\\n   - send a pull request to the original repo from your forked repo.\\\\r\\\\n   See the ARM Wiki for information on the [supported repos and branches for management-plane services](https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/rpaas/swaggeronboarding.html#supported-github-reposbranches).\\\\r\\\\n#### 4.1 Fix the errors of PR reviewing CI checks\\\\r\\\\nThe CI checks result will be commented on the PR. you can refer to the [CI fix Guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/ci-fix.md).\\\\r\\\\nNote:\\\\r\\\\nSince the OpenAPI is generated from TypeSpec, to change the OpenAPI, you must update the TypeSpec file and regenerate the\\\\r\\\\n OpenAPI and avoid updating OpenAPI directly to keep the consistency between OpenAPI and TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\nFor support \\\\u0026 help, you can post a message to [TypeSpec Discussion - teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47).\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_12.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Swagger LintDiff Suppression via TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Swagger LintDiff Suppression via TypeSpec\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_12.md\\\\n\\\\n# Swagger LintDiff Suppression via TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The storage type used for the Operating System disk of Dev Boxes created using this definition.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        },\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"hibernateSupport\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/HibernateSupport\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Indicates whether Dev Boxes created with this definition are capable of hibernation. If scale out/in is not possible for the resource this may be omitted.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        }\\\\r\\\\n      },\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      ]\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"If the service has different generations of hardware, for the same SKU, then that can be captured here.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        },\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"capacity\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"integer\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"format\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"int32\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"If the SKU supports scale out/in then the capacity integer should be included. I can't seem to find any examples of this and would really appreciate any help!\\\\n\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"The SKU for Dev Boxes created using this definition.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  sku?: Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Sku;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The storage type used for the Operating System disk of Dev Boxes created using this definition.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  osStorageType?: string;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"Indicates whether Dev Boxes created with this definition are capable of hibernation.
