These properties can be updated after the resource has been created.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"imageReference\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/ImageReference\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Image reference information.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        },\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"sku\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v4/types.json#/definitions/Sku\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The SKU for Dev Boxes created using this definition.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        },\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"osStorageType\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The storage type used for the Operating System disk of Dev Boxes created using this definition.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        },\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"hibernateSupport\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/HibernateSupport\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Indicates whether Dev Boxes created with this definition are capable of hibernation. Not all images are capable of supporting hibernation. Location: Microsoft.DevCenter/preview/2025-07-01-preview/devcenter.json#L2943\\\\tRPC-Patch-V1-10\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c PatchBodyParametersSchema\\\\tProperties of a PATCH request body must not be required, property:name. Location: Microsoft.DevCenter/preview/2025-07-01-preview/devcenter.json#L8164\\\\tRPC-Patch-V1-10\\\\r\\\\n``` \\\\r\\\\nThis is because a couple of our resource definitions reference the `Sku` definition from ARM common types \\\\r\\\\nThe TypeSpec: [Link](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/82edee201bde3d1de2633221016530141567dd28/specification/devcenter/DevCenter.Management/models.tsp#L1435)\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Properties of a Dev Box definition. These properties can be updated after the resource has been created.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel DevBoxDefinitionUpdateProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"Image reference information.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  imageReference?: ImageReference;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The SKU for Dev Boxes created using this definition.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  sku?: Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Sku;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The storage type used for the Operating System disk of Dev Boxes created using this definition.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  osStorageType?: string;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"Indicates whether Dev Boxes created with this definition are capable of hibernation. Not all images are capable of supporting hibernation. To find out more see https://aka.ms/devbox/hibernate\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  hibernateSupport?: HibernateSupport;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIf you just need to add a suppression for the swagger error in LintDiff, see here: \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions \\\\r\\\\nAlso left a comment here, with a correction to the instructions provided by your ARM reviewer. \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36201#discussion_r2342265620:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nCurrently, LintDiff errors can only be suppressed in readme.md, not *.tsp files or suppressions.yaml or anywhere else.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec Linter errors should be suppressed in the *.tsp themselves.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\nCheck `Swagger LintDiff` may fail for the OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec, even if there are no warnings or errors reported from the TypeSpec compiler.  Causes include bugs in the TypeSpec OpenAPI emitter, bugs in LintDiff rules, incompatibilities between TypeSpec and LintDiff, or checks duplicated in TypeSpec and LintDiff.\\\\r\\\\nWe are working to address the root causes (where possible).  Until then, we recommend you [suppress](https://aka.ms/pr-suppressions) these LintDiff errors, using a \\\\\\\"permanent suppression\\\\\\\" with a descriptive \\\\\\\"reason\\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAdditionalProperties`\\\\n\\\\nThe use of `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e` in TypeSpec is discouraged, and there is a TypeSpec lint rule to enforce this.  If you still need to use `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`, the OpenAPI spec generated will cause many LintDiff errors of types `AvoidAdditionalProperties` and `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`.  You will need to suppress both the TypeSpec violation (in TypeSpec source code) and the LintDiff violations.\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n\\\\n### data-plane\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n\\\\nAs an exception to the previous note, resource-manager specs **may** be able to suppress `AvoidAnonymousTypes`, but only if the error is inside a 202 response from a long-running operation (LRO).  It is known that SDKs do not need to generate type names for such responses.\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousTypes`\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n### `LongRunningResourceAction`\\\\n\\\\nThere is a known issue where `LongRunningResourceAction` in TypeSpec, generates swagger that causes `AvoidAnonymousTypes`.  These errors should be suppressed until the root cause is fixed.  https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure-pr/issues/3349\\\\n\\\\n## `EvenSegmentedPathForPutOperation`\\\\n\\\\nIf `EvenSegmentedPathForPutOperation` is failing for OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec using `@singleton` (OpenAPI path ends with `/default`), we believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/646\\\\n\\\\n## `IntegerTypeMustHaveFormat`\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchBodyParameterSchema`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a bug in typespec-azure:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/383.\\\\r\\\\nPlease see the issue above for the suggested workaround and apply it directly to the spec TypeSpec sources.  The LintDiff error should **not** be ignored or suppressed.\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchPropertiesCorrespondToPutProperties`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/642\\\\n\\\\n## `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`\\\\n\\\\nThe use of `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e` in TypeSpec is discouraged, and there is a TypeSpec lint rule to enforce this.  If you still need to use `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`, the OpenAPI spec generated will cause many LintDiff errors of types `AvoidAdditionalProperties` and `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`.  You will need to suppress both the TypeSpec violation (in TypeSpec source code) and the LintDiff violations.\\\\n\\\\n## `ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a limitation in how `azure-openapi-validator` and `oav` handle `$ref` siblings:\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/637\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/oav/issues/848\\\\r\\\\nThe recommended workaround is to add `use-read-only-status-schema: true` to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\n\\\\n## `RequestBodyMustExistForPutPatch`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/641\\\\n\\\\n## `ResourceNameRestriction`\\\\n\\\\nWhether `ResourceNameRestriction` should be applied to enums is an open question:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/501\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/pull/714\\\\r\\\\nUntil this is resolved, suppress the errors and discuss with your ARM reviewer.\\\\n\\\\n## `XmsEnumValidation`\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec using `OAuth2Auth` may generate the following OpenAPI:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"OAuth2 authentication\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"enum\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"oauth2\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhich causes error `XmsEnumValidation`.  The recommended workaround is to add `omit-unreachable-types: true` to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\n\\\\n## `XmsPageableForListCalls`\\\\n\\\\nIf `XmsPageableForListCalls` are failing for OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec using `@singleton` (OpenAPI path ends with `/default`), we believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/646\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"bad\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# bad\\\\n## Troubleshooting AutoRest suppressions not working\\\\n### For suppression path, use exactly the element the error is pointing to\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# bad\\\\n\\\\n## Troubleshooting AutoRest suppressions not working\\\\n\\\\n### For suppression path, use exactly the element the error is pointing to\\\\n\\\\nThe path in the suppression you add must point to exactly the same element as pointed out by the error.\\\\r\\\\nFor example, if the failure link points [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/30be453a97b9a4d64b1a7a6e45d7364bfbf4d8a2/specification/subscription/resource-manager/Microsoft.Subscription/stable/2021-10-01/subscriptions.json#L137),\\\\r\\\\nthen the path should be:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` xpath\\\\r\\\\n$.paths[\\\\\\\"/providers/Microsoft.Subscription/subscriptionOperations/{operationId}\\\\\\\"].get.responses[\\\\\\\"202\\\\\\\"]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- [Example path for suppressing LintDiff code `GetOperation200`](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/24395/commits/41f8f34937be245a855ff49552ecdeb0213ca525)\\\\r\\\\n  - **IMPORTANT**: This example uses the legacy `directive/suppress` syntax. Do not use it. Use the new syntax instead.\\\\r\\\\n  - [Relevant Teams discussion](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:0351f5f9404446e4b4fd4eaf2c27448d@thread.skype/1688105866973?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47\\\\u0026groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026parentMessageId=1687971321354\\\\u0026teamName=Azure%20SDK\\\\u0026channelName=API%20Spec%20Review\\\\u0026createdTime=1688105866973)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Typespec Validation required check\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Typespec Validation required check\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Typespec Validation required check\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\"github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/{module-name}\\\\\\\" does not match \\\\\\\"github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/{service-dir}/{package-dir}\\\\\\\". Please update the value of \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.module\\\\\\\" to match \\\\\\\"github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/{service-dir}/{package-dir}\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.fix-const-stuttering\\\\\\\". Please add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.fix-const-stuttering\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-samples\\\\\\\". Please add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.head-as-boolean\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans\\\\\\\". Please add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-python.package-dir\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- The value of options.@azure-tools/typespec-csharp.namespace \\\\\\\"Microsoft.Azure.Management.DevTestLabs\\\\\\\" does not match \\\\\\\"{package-dir}\\\\\\\" or the value of \\\\\\\"package-dir\\\\\\\" option or parameter. Please update the value of \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-csharp.namespace\\\\\\\" to match \\\\\\\"{package-dir}\\\\\\\" or the value of \\\\\\\"package-dir\\\\\\\" option or parameter.\\\\r\\\\nPlease see https://aka.ms/azsdk/spec-gen-sdk-config for more info.\\\\r\\\\nFor additional information on TypeSpec validation, please refer to https://aka.ms/azsdk/specs/typespec-validation.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nI have copied the namespace from the autorest readme files that we had before and it was responsible  to generate SDKs. Is it a requirement to update the namespace as suggested given we have already published the SDK before?\\\\n\\\\nPR: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346\\\\r\\\\nThis PR only has typespec conversion change and no API update. It is currently failing for required check - Typespec validation. When I run the npx tsmv command locally then I see the following error.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nExecuting rule: SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\nValidation on option \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-csharp.namespace\\\\\\\" in \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-csharp\\\\\\\" are failed. docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\\n\\\\n# SDK generation configuration\\\\n\\\\nTo generate SDK code based on REST API specifications, you need to configure the corresponding files.\\\\r\\\\n- For TypeSpec, the configuration file is `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n- For OpenAPI, the configuration file is `readme.md`.\\\\n\\\\n## Enable SDK generation\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003e[!IMPORTANT]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e You cannot enable SDK generation for both TypeSpec and OpenAPI simultaneously. Disable one before enabling the other.\\\\n\\\\n### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)\\\\n\\\\nAdd the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:\\\\r\\\\n    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).\\\\r\\\\n    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    namespace: \\\\\\\"Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{output-dir}/{service-dir}/{namespace}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n### [OpenAPI](#tab/openapi)\\\\n\\\\nConfigure the `swagger-to-sdk` section in `readme.md`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code for your OpenAPIs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `azure-sdk-for-net` to the list.\\\\r\\\\n2. Add detailed settings to a separate file `readme.csharp.md` and place it in the same folder as `readme.md`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger to SDK\\\\n\\\\nThis section describes what SDK should be generated by the automatic system.\\\\r\\\\nThis is not used by Autorest itself.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n$(swagger-to-sdk)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nswagger-to-sdk:\\\\r\\\\n  - repo: azure-sdk-for-net\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## CSharp\\\\n\\\\nSee configuration in [readme.csharp.md](./readme.csharp.md)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\nFor more samples on configuring specific `readme.{language}.md`, refer to:\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Management Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles)\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Data Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles-dp)\\\\r\\\\n- [Config SDK Guidelines](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/code-gen)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Configuration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/configuration/configuration\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Configuration\\\\n# handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Configuration\\\\n\\\\nimport { FileTree } from \\\\\\\"@astrojs/starlight/components\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nThe TypeSpec compiler and libraries can be configured either via a configuration-file or command line flags.\\\\n\\\\n## Configuration file\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec configuration can be provided via the `tspconfig.yaml` configuration file.\\\\n\\\\n### Discovery\\\\n\\\\nThe TypeSpec compiler will look for the closest `tspconfig.yaml` file located in the same directory or closest parent directory from the TypeSpec entrypoint.\\\\r\\\\nFor example if running `tsp compile /dev/foo/bar/main.tsp`, the compiler will lookup the file at the folllowing paths (in order):\\\\r\\\\n- `/dev/foo/bar/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `/dev/foo/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `/dev/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\n\\\\n### Schema\\\\n\\\\nThe file is a `yaml` document with the following structure. See the [next section](#typespec-configuration-options) for details on each option.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel TypeSpecProjectSchema {\\\\r\\\\n  extends?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  parameters?: Record\\\\u003c{default: string}\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  `environment-variables`?: Record\\\\u003c{default: string}\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  `warn-as-error`?: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  `output-dir`?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  `trace`?: string | string[];\\\\r\\\\n  imports?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  emit?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  `dry-run`?: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  options?: Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  linter?: LinterConfig;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel LinterConfig {\\\\r\\\\n  extends?: RuleRef[];\\\\r\\\\n  enable?: Record\\\\u003cRuleRef, boolean\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  disable?: Record\\\\u003cRuleRef, string\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Extending Project Files\\\\n\\\\nThere may be instances where you want to build different folders with varying options (such as different emitters), but still want to share some common configurations.\\\\r\\\\nIn such cases, you can use the `extends` property in the configuration file.\\\\r\\\\nFor instance, in `\\\\u003cmy-pkg\\\\u003e/tspconfig.yaml`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    some-option: my-name\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    some-other-option: This is a title\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nin `\\\\u003cmy-pkg\\\\u003e/proj2/tspconfig.yaml`, enable `emitter1` using the options specified in the parent `tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=proj2/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### What gets extended\\\\r\\\\nThe extending logic follows these rules:\\\\r\\\\n- **Root-level properties**: Shallow merge for all properties except `options`\\\\r\\\\n- **Options property**: Deep merge at one level (per emitter)\\\\r\\\\n- **Override behavior**: Properties specified in the extending file will completely override those from the extended file\\\\r\\\\n**Root-level merge behavior:**\\\\r\\\\nWhen extending a configuration, most properties (like `emit`, `imports`, `trace`, etc.) are merged at the root level. If the same property exists in both files, the extending file's value completely replaces the extended file's value.\\\\r\\\\n**Options merge behavior:**\\\\r\\\\nThe `options` property receives special treatment with a one-level deep merge:\\\\r\\\\n- Different emitters from both files are combined\\\\r\\\\n- If the same emitter is configured in both files, the extending file's emitter configuration completely overrides the extended file's configuration for that emitter\\\\r\\\\n- Individual emitter options are not merged - it's all or nothing per emitter\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n// Base config (parent/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    option-a: value-a\\\\r\\\\n    option-b: value-b\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    option-x: value-x\\\\r\\\\n// Extending config (child/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter3  # Completely replaces the emit array\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\n\\\\ncompletely overrides the extended file's configuration for that emitter\\\\r\\\\n- Individual emitter options are not merged - it's all or nothing per emitter\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n// Base config (parent/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    option-a: value-a\\\\r\\\\n    option-b: value-b\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    option-x: value-x\\\\r\\\\n// Extending config (child/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter3  # Completely replaces the emit array\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:   # Completely replaces emitter1 options\\\\r\\\\n    option-c: value-c\\\\r\\\\n  emitter3:   # Added alongside emitter2 from parent\\\\r\\\\n    option-y: value-y\\\\r\\\\n// Resulting merged config:\\\\r\\\\n// emit: [emitter3]  # Only emitter3, emitter1 is gone\\\\r\\\\n// options:\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter1: { option-c: value-c }  # Only option-c, option-a and option-b are gone\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter2: { option-x: value-x }  # Inherited from parent\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter3: { option-y: value-y }  # From extending config\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Variable interpolation\\\\n\\\\nThe TypeSpec project file provides variable interpolation using:\\\\r\\\\n- built-in variables\\\\r\\\\n- environment variables\\\\r\\\\n- config file parameters\\\\r\\\\n- emitter options can reference each other\\\\r\\\\nVariable interpolation is done using an variable expression surrounded by `{` and `}`. (`{\\\\u003cexpression\\\\u003e}`)\\\\r\\\\nExamples:\\\\r\\\\n- `{output-dir}/my-path`\\\\r\\\\n- `{env.SHARED_PATH}/my-path`\\\\n\\\\n### Interpolation of Emitter Path Config\\\\n\\\\nemitter                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name`             | service name             | Name of the service                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name-if-multiple` | service name if multiple | Name of the service if multiple, undefined if one                                    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Project Parameters\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can define certain parameters that can subsequently be specified through the CLI.\\\\r\\\\nParameters can be organized in a nested structure, to access different levels of the structure, use dots (`.`) in the variable expression.\\\\r\\\\nTherefore, parameter names should not contain `.` in their name.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be utilized in the default value of these parameters.\\\\r\\\\nThese parameters can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression.\\\\r\\\\nAll parameters must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nparameters:\\\\r\\\\n  base-dir:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {base-dir}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe parameter can then be specified via `--arg` in this format `--arg \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cparameter-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"` and for nested structures `--arg \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cparameter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003cnested-parameter-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\ntsp compile . --arg \\\\\\\"base-dir=/path/to/base\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Environment variables\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can specify which environment variables it can interpolate.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be used in the default value of these environment variables.\\\\r\\\\nThese environment variables can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression, using the `env.` prefix.\\\\r\\\\nAll environment variables must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nenvironment-variables:\\\\r\\\\n  BASE_DIR:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {env.BASE_DIR}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Emitter Options\\\\n\\\\nCertain emitter configurations can be interpolated using a specific rule designed to collapse a path.\\\\r\\\\nIf a variable is succeeded by a `/` or `.` and the emitter responsible for interpolating the config doesn't supply that variable, the path segment will be omitted.\\\\r\\\\nFor instance, consider the following config value: `{service-name}/output.{version}.json`\\\\r\\\\nHere's what would be produced:\\\\r\\\\n| Service name value | Version value | Result                    |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------ | ------------- | ------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `\\\\\\\"PetStore\\\\\\\"`       | `\\\\\\\"v1\\\\\\\"`        | `PetStore/output.v1.json` |\\\\r\\\\n| `\\\\\\\"PetStore\\\\\\\"`       | `undefined`   | `PetStore/output.json`    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Built-in variables\\\\r\\\\n| Variable name              | Scope                    | Description                                                                          |\\\\r\\\\n| -------------------------- | ------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |\\\\r\\\\n| `cwd`                      | \\\\\\\\*                       | Points to the current working directory                                              |\\\\r\\\\n| `project-root`             | \\\\\\\\*                       | Points to the the tspconfig.yaml file containing folder.                             |\\\\r\\\\n| `output-dir`               | emitter options          | Common `output-dir` See [output-dir](#output-dir---configure-the-default-output-dir) |\\\\r\\\\n| `emitter-name`             | emitter options          | Name of the emitter                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name`             | service name             | Name of the service                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name-if-multiple` | service name if multiple | Name of the service if multiple, undefined if one                                    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Project Parameters\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can define certain parameters that can subsequently be specified through the CLI.\\\\n\\\\nvariables it can interpolate.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be used in the default value of these environment variables.\\\\r\\\\nThese environment variables can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression, using the `env.` prefix.\\\\r\\\\nAll environment variables must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nenvironment-variables:\\\\r\\\\n  BASE_DIR:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {env.BASE_DIR}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Emitter Options\\\\r\\\\nEmitter options can refer to each other by using the other option's name as the variable expression.\\\\r\\\\nInterpolation is only possible among emitter options from the same emitter.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  @typespec/openapi3:\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: {output-dir}/{emitter-sub-folder}\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-sub-folder: bar\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nEmitter options support a nested structure, enabling complex configurations.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter-sub-folder:\\\\r\\\\n    sub-folder: bar\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo set these values via the CLI, use dots to navigate deeper levels in the definition. `--option \\\\\\\"\\\\u003coption-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003cnested-option-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"`\\\\r\\\\nDue to this capability, emitter option names should not contain a `.` in their name.\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec Currently required by TSV.\\\\r\\\\n    azure-resource-provider-folder: \\\\\\\"resource-manager\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    output-file: \\\\\\\"{version-status}/{version}/widget.json\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    arm-types-dir: \\\\\\\"{project-root}/../../../../common-types/resource-management\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n1.because this is the file oav is trying to find https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/blob/d1fd46b8d93ae2cdd50e282768fe5e82e718e893/specification/common-types/resource-management/v5/types.json\\\\r\\\\n2.You also need to have a readme.md under specification/limit/resource-manager/Microsoft.Limit/Limit/ ,  similar like this one https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget/readme.md where you have to have references to all your swagger files with tags and its input-files\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Swagger LintDiff failed\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Swagger LintDiff failed\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Swagger LintDiff failed\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI have many lintDiff failures in this [PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/34318). The interesting thing is, the place I'm violating the rules, its swagger is the same as before. Why these violations are not reported before?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe LintDiff errors in your PR are not necessarily new violations. Many of them already existed in the main branch, but previously, CI failures weren\\u2019t blocking, so these issues were effectively allowed to persist unnoticed.\\\\r\\\\nNow, because your PR is part of a TypeSpec (TSP) migration, the generated Swagger includes many differences\\u2014over 3,000 diffs in total\\u2014due to normalization by the AutoRest emitter. These changes are functionally equivalent but not textually identical, which makes it hard for the LintDiff auto-baselining algorithm to recognize unchanged areas. As a result, you\\u2019re seeing errors flagged as new, even if the same issues existed in main.\\\\r\\\\nGiven the unreliability of the auto-baselining mechanism, we recommend not depending on it. Instead, all LintDiff errors\\u2014regardless of whether they are newly introduced or pre-existing\\u2014should be explicitly suppressed in the `readme.md` file. This is the mitigation approach we advise for all PRs, especially TSP migrations.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Typespec Validation required check\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Typespec Validation required check\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Typespec Validation required check\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\"github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/{module-name}\\\\\\\" does not match \\\\\\\"github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/{service-dir}/{package-dir}\\\\\\\". Please update the value of \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-csharp.namespace\\\\\\\" to match \\\\\\\"{package-dir}\\\\\\\" or the value of \\\\\\\"package-dir\\\\\\\" option or parameter.\\\\r\\\\nPlease see https://aka.ms/azsdk/spec-gen-sdk-config for more info.\\\\r\\\\nFor additional information on TypeSpec validation, please refer to https://aka.ms/azsdk/specs/typespec-validation.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nI have copied the namespace from the autorest readme files that we had before and it was responsible  to generate SDKs. Please update the value of \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-java.namespace\\\\\\\" to match \\\\\\\"/^com\\\\\\\\.azure\\\\\\\\.resourcemanager\\\\\\\\.[^\\\\\\\\.]+$/\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\\\\\\". Please add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.fix-const-stuttering\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-samples\\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\ntypeSpec validation is failing, but not for that reason.  The configuration for c-sharp emitter is a warning only.  The current failure is caused by diffs between the generated swagger included in your PR and the generated swagger when the ci compiles your spec. \\\\r\\\\nUsually this indicates that your local dependencies are out of date, and you need to pull the latest into your local branch and re-install at thetop level: \\\\r\\\\ngit fetch upstream main\\\\r\\\\ngit pull upstream main\\\\r\\\\nnpm ci\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation#running-locally:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nRunning Locally\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nTo ensure you see the same results from TypeSpecValidation in your PR check and tsv on your local machine:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1.Merge latest from parent (e.g. main or RPSaaSMaster) to your PR branch\\\\r\\\\n2.Run locally\\\\r\\\\ngit clean -xdf (may revert any local changes)\\\\r\\\\ngit pull\\\\r\\\\nnpm ci\\\\r\\\\nnpx tsv specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management\\\\r\\\\ngit status\\\\r\\\\nIf any changes, git add, git commit, git push to update your PR.\\\\r\\\\n3.If you are still having problems, try cloning your branch to a new folder, or try on another machine.\\\\r\\\\n4.If the problem can be reproduced on a clean machine, request assistance from the TypeSpec Discussion teams channel.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Need help with PR checks\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Need help with PR checks\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\\n\\\\n# Need help with PR checks\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi, need help with some failures I'm getting when running a PR against `azure-api-specs-pr`. This is the PR: [Microsoft Planetary Computer Pro - AI Workflows by emiliodangelo \\u00b7 Pull Request #23267 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/23267) and I'm getting the following errors when running the PR checks:\\\\r\\\\n`private.rest-api-specs-pr`: Failing with the message `the branch is protected`, [Microsoft Planetary Computer Pro - AI Workflows by emiliodangelo \\u00b7 Pull Request #23267 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/23267/checks?check_run_id=44598442126). I assume this is expected since the PR is against the main branch of the private repo.\\\\r\\\\n`private.rest-api-specs-pr (BranchProtectionForPrivateRepo)`: Same error as above.\\\\r\\\\n`Swagger ModelValidation`: Fails with error `unacceptable kind of an object to dump [object Error]`, [Microsoft Planetary Computer Pro - AI Workflows by emiliodangelo \\u00b7 Pull Request #23267 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/23267/checks?check_run_id=44598262948).\\\\r\\\\n`Swagger SemanticValidation`: Failing with `INTERNAL_ERROR`, part of the message is `Must have text between two parameters, missing text after \\\\\\\"2x\\\\\\\" at safePattern`, [Microsoft Planetary Computer Pro - AI Workflows by emiliodangelo \\u00b7 Pull Request #23267 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/23267/checks?check_run_id=44598263149).\\\\r\\\\n`Swagger LintDiff`: Fails with `AvoidAnonymousTypes`, [Microsoft Planetary Computer Pro - AI Workflows by emiliodangelo \\u00b7 Pull Request #23267 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/23267/checks?check_run_id=44598262474).\\\\r\\\\nThe `Swagger LintDiff` seems to be related with this question: [Emilio D'Angelo: Asynchronous resource delete | Azure SDK \\\\u003e TypeSpec Discussion |\\\\n\\\\n`Swagger LintDiff`: Fails with `AvoidAnonymousTypes`, [Microsoft Planetary Computer Pro - AI Workflows by emiliodangelo \\u00b7 Pull Request #23267 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/23267/checks?check_run_id=44598262474).\\\\r\\\\nThe `Swagger LintDiff` seems to be related with this question: [Emilio D'Angelo: Asynchronous resource delete | Azure SDK \\\\u003e TypeSpec Discussion | Microsoft Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf@thread.skype/1750334021292?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47\\\\u0026groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026parentMessageId=1750334021292\\\\u0026teamName=Azure%20SDK\\\\u0026channelName=TypeSpec%20Discussion\\\\u0026createdTime=1750334021292).\\\\r\\\\nThe error appears when using this pattern:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@resource(\\\\\\\"operations\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_30_Preview)\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"An AI Workflow delete operation.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel AiWorkflowOperationStatus is Foundations.OperationStatus\\\\u003cnever\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@tag(\\\\\\\"AI Workflows\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"ai\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_30_Preview)\\\\r\\\\ninterface AiWorkflowOperations {\\\\r\\\\n  get is StandardOperations.ResourceRead\\\\u003cAiWorkflowOperationStatus\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@tag(\\\\\\\"AI Workflows\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"ai\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_30_Preview)\\\\r\\\\ninterface AiWorkflows {\\\\r\\\\n  ...\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @pollingOperation(AiWorkflowOperations.get)\\\\r\\\\n  delete is StandardOperations.LongRunningResourceDelete\\\\u003cAiWorkflow\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  ...\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe issue you're encountering is caused by a regression in the path-to-regexp dependency used by oav. Specifically, patterns like {width}x{height} or {x}/{y}@{scale}x in your API paths are now breaking validation due to stricter parsing rules introduced in path-to-regexp@6.2.1.\\\\r\\\\nPreviously, your spec passed validation because older versions of path-to-regexp were more lenient. The recent update introduced security fixes that inadvertently caused this break.\\\\r\\\\nTo unblock your PR, we\\u2019ve deployed a temporary fix that pins path-to-regexp to an older version. This means your Swagger checks should no longer crash. Meanwhile, we\\u2019re working on a permanent solution that doesn\\u2019t rely on pinning old code.\\\\r\\\\nIf you still need to validate locally, you can manually install the older version and run oav like this:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cinstall node 20\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\nmkdir testdirectory\\\\r\\\\ncd testdirectory\\\\r\\\\nnpm i oav path-to-regexp@6.2.2\\\\r\\\\nnpx oav validate-example /path/to/your/openapi.json\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nAlternatively, you can use validate-spec instead of validate-example if you're checking the spec directly. This workaround has been confirmed to pass for your PR.\\\\r\\\\nWe\\u2019ve also applied the approved-modelvalidation and approved-semanticvalidation labels to your PR to unblock progress. Just note that if other issues surface later due to this regression, you may need to address them in a follow-up PR.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_31.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Looking for examples on running TypeSpec in ADO Pipelines\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Looking for examples on running TypeSpec in ADO Pipelines\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_31.md\\\\n\\\\n# Looking for examples on running TypeSpec in ADO Pipelines\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe're looking to work in ADO internally before promoting swagger to github - is there any examples of teams using the TypeSpec method for swagger internally vai ADO pipelines?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nhttps://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/rest-api-publish/buildpipelines/#_top\\\\r\\\\nbut this is only about typespec itself. If you plan to merge in the spec repo later there is many additional validations that will not be verified this way\\\\r\\\\nA large set of them are available to install and run locally: [azure-rest-api-specs/documentation/SwaggerValidationTools.md at master \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/master/documentation/SwaggerValidationTools.md):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThere are some tools that can help you make sure your specifications conform to the accepted guidelines. Better upfront validation before the final pull request is sent will result in quicker turnaround time.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nValidation tools available locally\\\\r\\\\nThe various tools mentioned above are also available for local download.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nInstall Node.js (7.10.0 or greater)\\\\r\\\\nLinter Validator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n - `npm install -g autorest`\\\\r\\\\n -  `autoRest \\\\u003cpath to readme.md\\\\u003e --azure-validator=true`\\\\r\\\\nStatic Validator (Semantic):\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n - `npm install -g oav`\\\\r\\\\n - `bash-3.2$ oav validate-spec \\\\u003cspec-path\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\nStatic Validator (Model):\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n - `npm install -g oav`\\\\r\\\\n - `bash-3.2$ oav validate-example \\\\u003cspec-path\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\nSwagger diff tool\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n - `npm install -g oad@0.1.7`\\\\r\\\\n - `bash-3.2$ oad compare \\\\u003cold-spec\\\\u003e \\\\u003cnew-spec\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThe TypeSpec validation tool (tsv) is also available locally, but for now it's only available in the azure-rest-api-specs repo and the package is not published. You can clone the repo and run it from there, though it assumes everything is run from within that repo, so it may have issues elsewhere.\\\\r\\\\nThe current focus for engineering system improvements is the azure-rest-api-specs repo itself. You can use draft PRs to validate work in progress, and some of the checks can be run locally\\u2014with varying levels of usability.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_31.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec Validation error\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec Validation error\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_31.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec Validation error\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nFiles have been changed after `tsp compile`. response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"The error '[Exception] No input files provided.' in the Swagger LintDiff CI check is expected behavior when you are fixing bugs that already exist in the main branch. LintDiff runs on your specification both before and after your PR. If the 'before' state (main branch) is already crashing due to missing or misconfigured input files, then your PR to fix it will still result in a crash for the CI check. This is not a bug in your PR, but rather a limitation of how LintDiff operates: it requires valid input files in both the base and PR branches. To resolve this, ensure that the main branch is fixed first, or coordinate with repo maintainers to unblock your PR. If you are certain your input-file paths are correct and present, this error is not caused by your changes but by the state of the main branch.\", \"ground_truth\": \"if you are fixing bugs already in main, this is expected.  lintdiff needs to run on your spec both before and after your PR, and if before is crashing, the PR to fix it will still crash.\"}"}]

expected.answer:

Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing
SDK Validation steps are failing with not much helpful logs
Suppress validation failures on a PR

actual.answer:
This issue is most likely caused by a permissions problem with the PR author. For the required pipelines (SDK Validation Status and Swagger PrettierCheck) to start and report status, the PR author must have their Azure organization membership set to public (not private) and must also be a member of the Azure SDK Partners group. If these requirements are not met, the pipelines will remain queued and never start, blocking the PR from merging. 

To resolve this:
1. Make sure the PR author sets their Azure organization membership to public.
2. Join the Azure SDK Partners group by following the instructions at https://aka.ms/azsdk/access.

Once these steps are completed, the pipelines should start and report status as expected, allowing you to proceed with merging the PR.

knowledge_match_missing_refs.title: Azure REST API Specification Directory Structure

testcase: RPaaSMaster branch requirement for Ring 0 services

expected.answer: Based on the available knowledge context, syncing API specs between the public 'main' branch and the private 'RPaaSMaster' branch is the responsibility of the spec owner. There is no strict requirement in the referenced documentation that all resource providers (including ring 0 services like Microsoft.Compute) must have their specs present in RPaaSMaster if they have received an explicit exemption from RPaaS onboarding. The documentation and FAQ state that if your service is not onboarded to RPaaS (and has an exception), you do not need to merge your specs into RPaaSMaster. The presence or absence of Microsoft.Compute in RPaaSMaster does not dictate requirements for other RPs; each spec owner is responsible for their own onboarding and branch sync according to their onboarding status and exemptions. If your ring 0 service has an approved exception, you can continue to manage your specs in 'main' and do not need to merge into RPaaSMaster unless instructed otherwise by the ARM or EngSys team.

actual.answer: If your service is a ring 0 resource provider and has been granted an explicit exception from onboarding to RPaaS, you are not required to merge your API specification into the RPaaSMaster branch before merging into the main branch of the public repository. The RPaaSMaster branch is used for RPaaS-managed resource providers, and exceptions (such as for Microsoft.Compute) are handled on a case-by-case basis. For ring 0 services with an approved exception, you can proceed with merging your spec directly to the main branch in the public repo, following the standard review and validation process. Always ensure your exception is documented and communicated to the ARM review team to avoid process confusion.

testcase: Looking for someone to suppress CI failures https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36221

expected.answer:
Based on the information provided and the knowledge context, the Avocado CI failure in your PR (https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36221) is expected because the Compute service currently has multiple API versions in its default tag, which violates the Uniform Versioning Principle. The Avocado check (MULTIPLE_API_VERSION) was recently made a blocking error to enforce this policy.
To temporarily suppress this failure and unblock your PR, you can add the Approved-Avocado label to your PR. However, this is only a one-time suppression and should be done if:
There is an ongoing discussion and plan to resolve the uniform versioning issue for Compute.
You or your team are aware that this is a temporary measure and are working towards compliance.
Important: Regular use of this suppression is discouraged. The long-term solution is to restructure your API versions so all components under Compute adopt a uniform versioning scheme, or split into independent services as outlined in the Uniform Versioning Violation Guide.
If you are not aware of any ongoing discussion or plan for resolution, you should reach out to azversioning@service.microsoft.com for guidance.

Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing

actual.answer:
Your PR is currently targeting a feature branch, so CI checks are not strictly required at this stage. However, when you attempt to merge to the main branch, the Avocado check failure due to multiple API versions will become a blocker. The MULTIPLE_API_VERSION rule was upgraded to an error as of 7/1/2025 and is now a mandatory requirement for TypeSpec conversion across Azure services.

To resolve this, you should:
1. Review the guidance at https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#multiple_api_version and the Uniform Versioning Violation Guide.
2. If you believe your service qualifies for a one-time suppression, contact azversioning@service.microsoft.com for approval.
3. Do NOT rely on suppression as a long-term solution; you should work to resolve the underlying versioning issue to comply with Azure API guidelines and enable successful TypeSpec conversion.

Suppression is only possible with explicit approval and should be used sparingly. Permanent resolution is preferred.

https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/32694\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n\\\\nHear directly from teams who have successfully transitioned to TypeSpec Azure and learn about their experiences:\\\\n\\\\n### Azure Batch\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EUkgwSc69lpPsBjQBfLfMEgB0WCTBe9x7ozU8VNK2s8mAw?e=1MIXZi)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"There's definitions in Swagger, but \\u2026 TypeSpec has much more flexibility when it comes to doing things like mix or not mixing in traits and defining core things that you export.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I want to highlight the tooling improvements, like not having to figure out how to install things locally [like Swagger tooling], having it all in the same tool set that includes the emitters and things like that is really nice. The VS code integration right out of the box is something I've really liked.\\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n### MS Learn\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EXjQ3t7i-z9BpxVUgZVcS6QBxjLYdRLUquX2y8xczNxfbA?e=nesl3Q)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\u201cOne of the highlights [of using TypeSpec] was our ability to author API specs in a very simple and intuitive language. This meant that even [our PMs] who are not engineers were able to understand these API specifications. They could review them, make comments, and participate in designing those APIs.\\u201d\\\\n\\\\n### Azure AI Content Safety\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EdlE2PYtZ9BKoXQ-R0h-O10B9RidePBT4mwB1JgIqRC01A?e=JRneI2)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I find TypeSpec to be much simpler to learn and write compared to Swagger. In my experience, Swagger often encounters many conflicts due to its JSON format. TypeSpec proves to be a much better alternative as it allows everyone to work independently on their own sections, making it more user-friendly. Furthermore, TypeSpec allows for the separate definition of models and routes. So, from my perspective, it's a superior choice at present.\\\\\\\"\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"API-Spec-Review-FAQ.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/API-Spec-Review-FAQ\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"ARM team right now | PRs are generally reviewed in order of the ARM queue.  If your PR needs special treatment, you can contact the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo | \\\\r\\\\n| I need a review to merge changes to a non-standard branch (e.g. not `main`, `RPSaaSMaster`, etc.) | Contact the owner of that branch. |\\\\r\\\\n| EngSys is behaving badly in my non-standard/release branch | Update the state of the branch to match with `main`. The owner of the release branch is responsible for doing this. See documentation: [Update your branch with changes from main](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish#update-your-branch-with-changes-from-main). |\\\\r\\\\n| I need to set up suppressions for LintDiff violations in my PR | See [Adding Scoped Suppressions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff) | \\\\r\\\\n| I have specific questions about the inner workings of ARM, testing changes to APIs, or rollout/release schedules | Talk to the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo |\\\\r\\\\n| I see an Avocado error `MULTIPLE_API_VERSION` | There is a coordinated effort to fix this. Reach out to the relevant parties. [This PR](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/pull/157) gives more context on why this was upgraded to an error. If relevant parties agree, the PR can be unblocked by adding the `Approved-Avocado` label to the PR. |\\\\r\\\\n| I merged a PR, when does the REST API documentation update on the Learn site? | Docs are published every week on Tuesdays | \\\\r\\\\n| If the specs in the standard branches of `RPSaaSMaster` and `RPSaaSDev` are out of sync, who is responsible for syncing them with main? | The spec owner is responsible for syncing their service\\u2019s spec files from `main` to `RPSaaSMaster/RPSaaSDev` to ensure consistency across branches. |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\\n\\\\n# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nendpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Have observed some RPs have leveraged from commonTypes but renamed as PrivateEndpointConnectionResource in their tsp file.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n2. Avocado error: I have removed an API revokeCertificate and added a new api revokeCertificates which takes an array. \\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nHow do I fix both errors?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n [Added private endpoint connection, bulk revocation and c2pa certificate type by amritas \\u00b7 Pull Requ\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24553)\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nModel validation Error - Additional properties not allowed: groupIds, privateLinkServiceConnectionState,privateEndpoint,provisioningState\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nPEC contract - \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.CodeSigning;\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Private endpoint connection resource.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection\\\\r\\\\n    is ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnectionProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n    ...PrivateEndpointConnectionParameter;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations(PrivateEndpointConnection)\\\\r\\\\ninterface PrivateEndpointConnections {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Get a specific private connection */\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Create a Private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Delete the private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** List private endpoint connections on the given resource */\\\\r\\\\n  list is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\n\\\\nlistPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\r\\\\nThis will then get consumed by teams authoring Azure APIs. As such, they have the Azure linting in place (naming conventions and whatnot).\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe wanted to know whether definitions can also come with suppressions (not inline, as this definition is auto-importer on a regular basis), which would apply ONLY to the definitions we share, not to the rest of the consumer's project?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nThanks!\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nsuppression can only be provided inline for now. Linter rules can be disabled globally but that would apply to the whole project, can't filter by files\\\\n\\\\noperations to any resourc,e see: \\\\r\\\\n[typespec-azure/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-end\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-endpoints.tsp#L69-L94)\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointConnectionResource;\\\\r\\\\nalias PrivateEndpointOperations = PrivateEndpoints\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cEmployee, EmployeeProperties\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  getPrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.Read\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdatePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.CreateOrUpdateAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  updatePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.CustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  deletePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.DeleteAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\n\\\\nI have the below PR [adding shared limit typespec by parthshah2305 \\u00b7 Pull Request #24115 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24115) where some of the LintDiff validations are failing with the exception \\\\r\\\\n``` \\\\r\\\\n  Violation: file:///home/runner/work/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/after/specification/limit/resource-manager/Microsoft.Limit/Limit/stable/2025-08-15/Limit.json:578\\\\r\\\\n    Level: error\\\\r\\\\n    Code: RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel\\\\r\\\\n    Message: Model definition 'SharingDetail' must have the properties 'name', 'id' and 'type' in its hierarchy and these properties must be marked as readonly.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThis particular model is defined as follows - \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel SharingDetail {\\\\r\\\\n  role: SharingRole;\\\\r\\\\n  sharedLimits?: QuotaLimitProperties[];\\\\r\\\\n  guestSubscriptions?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  host?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nIs it possible have a suppression for this validation? If so, how?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nthe link for lintdiff suppressions:\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nyou probably want to fix this in your spec, not suppress the error\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nYou need to fix check \\\\\\\"TypeSpec Validation\\\\\\\" in your PR, before other check results will even be valid.  This is documented in the \\\\\\\"next steps to merge\\\\\\\" comment in your PR.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Model validations are failing although am referring from common-types\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\n1. I have reused the model Private endpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Have observed some RPs have leveraged from commonTypes but renamed as PrivateEndpointConnectionResource in their tsp file.\\\\n\\\\nis ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Create a Private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Delete the private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** List private endpoint connections on the given resource */\\\\r\\\\n  list is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateLink is ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateLinkResourceProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...PrivateLinkResourceParameter;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n updated the operationId and it worked. Let me know if the PrivateEndpointConnection should be a customized name or can retain same name as in commonTypes?\\\\r\\\\n Would this be guided by the reviewer?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nLooking at your PR, it seems that the avocado error is the only remaining one - this is just reporting that you have removed an API.  If you do not need to continue supporting the older preview, you might consider removing it,  otherwise, this is an error you can safely suppress (https://aka.ms/ci-fix is a great link to remember, as it has links to all kinds of useful info about ci errors, including a link to the suppression guides).\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nFor PrivateEndpointConnections, RPs have done both, as the name of the private endpoint connection type doesn't really matter to the API, however, there is a new template that greatly simplifies adding private endpoint connection operations to any resourc,e see: \\\\r\\\\n[typespec-azure/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-end\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-endpoints.tsp#L69-L94)\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointConnectionResource;\\\\r\\\\nalias PrivateEndpointOperations = PrivateEndpoints\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Avocado error after @renamedFrom on custom action route\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Avocado error after @renamedFrom on custom action route\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\\n\\\\n# Avocado error after @renamedFrom on custom action route\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nFor PR [Add Microsoft.Mission version 2025-05-01-preview - Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22581) I was asked to consider renaming routes for some custom actions to meet naming conventions. For example, I now have this in my routes:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Community Endpoint Interface\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface CommunityEndpoints {\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"Callback that triggers on approval state change.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @armResourceAction(CommunityEndpointResource)\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2024_12_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(\\\\r\\\\n    Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2025_05_01_preview,\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"approvalCallback\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  )\\\\r\\\\n  notifyOnApprovalCreation is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    CommunityEndpointResource,\\\\r\\\\n    ApprovalCallbackRequest,\\\\r\\\\n    ApprovalActionResponse\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThis unfortunately now produces Avocado errors for [MISSING_APIS_IN_DEFAULT_TAG](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/blob/master/README.md#MISSING_APIS_IN_DEFAULT_TAG) , \\\\r\\\\nThe default tag should contain all APIs. The API path \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/subscriptions/{}/resourcegroups/{}/providers/microsoft.mission/virtualenclaves/{}/enclaveendpoints/{}/approvalcallback\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nis not in the default tag. Please make sure the missing API swaggers are in the default tag.\\\\r\\\\nreadme: [specification/mission/resource-manager/readme.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/blob/589a07c8dcfe05714c746dcaf2052da06ae6ad74/specification/mission/resource-manager/readme.md)\\\\r\\\\njson: [Microsoft.Mission/preview/2024-12-01-preview/openapi.json](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/blob/589a07c8dcfe05714c746dcaf2052da06ae6ad74/specification/mission/resource-manager/Microsoft.Mission/preview/2024-12-01-preview/openapi.json)\\\\r\\\\nIs there something that I need to do differently to define this route renaming? \\\\r\\\\nLink to [Avocado check](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22581/checks?check_run_id=45066798540). Thanks!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nAvocado doesn't handle moves/renames.  You can suppress by adding label `Approved-Avocado`.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"API-Spec-Review-FAQ.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/API-Spec-Review-FAQ\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"Answers to frequently asked questions in the [Api Spec Review](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A0351f5f9404446e4b4fd4eaf2c27448d%40thread.skype/API%20Spec%20Review?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47). Within that channel, EngSys should be answering questions about validation pipelines and tools that run in those pipelines. Specific questions about typespec, the API Review process, etc. should be answered by others who specialize in those topics. \\\\r\\\\n| If the question is about | The answer should be | \\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- | \\\\r\\\\n| Authoring typespec | Send to [TypeSpec Discussions](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47) | \\\\r\\\\n| My PR is ready to review, will someone review it? | See the \\\\\\\"Next steps to merge\\\\\\\" comment in your PR and follow directions to ensure you're in the review queue. No need to post here. | \\\\r\\\\n| API Doc Preview is broken | If the error message linked doesn't make sense, follow instructions at [Troubleshooting REST API documentation](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-docs-troubleshooting). API Doc Preview is not a required check so you can ignore the failure if it's not relevant to your documentation needs. |\\\\r\\\\n| My PR needs to be reviewed by the ARM team right now | PRs are generally reviewed in order of the ARM queue. testcase: is sdk generation required for private preview?

expected.answer:
API approval for private preview does NOT always require SDK generation or SDK configuration in your tspconfig.yaml. For private preview ARM APIs, it is acceptable to onboard and validate your API contract without including SDK emitter settings (such as for Go, Python, Java, etc.).

However, the Azure TypeSpec validation tooling (tsv) is configured to expect certain SDK emitter options in tspconfig.yaml by default, even for private preview, which is why you see SdkTspConfigValidation failures if you remove them.

The correct and supported approach is:
- Remove SDK emitter configs you do NOT want in your tspconfig.yaml.
- Add a suppressions.yaml file in the same directory as tspconfig.yaml to explicitly suppress the SdkTspConfigValidation rule (or specific sub-rules for missing SDK configs).

Here is a sample suppressions.yaml to suppress all SdkTspConfigValidation checks (recommended for your scenario):

```yaml
- tool: TypeSpecValidation
  paths:
    - tspconfig.yaml
  rules:
    - SdkTspConfigValidation
  reason: 'SDK generation is not in scope for private preview onboarding.'
```

Place this suppressions.yaml alongside your tspconfig.yaml. This will allow CI and local validation to succeed without requiring SDK settings, letting you focus on API review and onboarding. When you later want to add SDK support, you can remove the suppression and add the required SDK emitter configuration.

In summary: No, API approval for private preview does not require SDK generation. Use suppressions.yaml to bypass SDK validation in tspconfig.yaml until you are ready to onboard SDKs.

Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing

actual.answer:
SDK generation is NOT required for private preview approval of an ARM (management-plane) API. For private preview, you are not required to onboard SDK emitters or provide SDK configuration in your tspconfig.yaml. The Azure guidelines explicitly state that private preview versions do not have corresponding SDK package versions, and there are no SDK support requirements for private preview.

However, the TypeSpec validation system (TSV) may expect certain SDK emitter options in tspconfig.yaml by default, which can cause validation failures if you remove them. To resolve this, you should add a suppressions.yaml file in your service folder and suppress the specific validation rules related to missing SDK configuration. This is the recommended approach for private preview scenarios where SDK generation is not in scope.

Example suppressions.yaml for disabling Go SDK validation (similar approach for other SDKs):

```yaml
- tool: TypeSpecValidation
  paths:
    - tspconfig.yaml
  rules:
    - SdkTspConfigValidation
  sub-rules:
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir
  reason: 'SDK generation is not required for private preview.'
```

You can suppress other SDK emitter options in the same way if you encounter validation errors for them. This allows your TypeSpec to validate and pass CI without requiring SDK configuration until you are ready to onboard SDKs for public preview or GA.

Summary:
- Private preview does NOT require SDK generation or SDK config in tspconfig.yaml.
- Suppress SDK validation rules in suppressions.yaml to pass TypeSpec validation.
- You can onboard SDKs later when moving to public preview or GA.
