This allows your TypeSpec to validate and pass CI without requiring SDK configuration until you are ready to onboard SDKs for public preview or GA.\\n\\nSummary:\\n- Private preview does NOT require SDK generation or SDK config in tspconfig.yaml.\\n- Suppress SDK validation rules in suppressions.yaml to pass TypeSpec validation.\\n- You can onboard SDKs later when moving to public preview or GA.\", \"context\": \"[{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\\n## Positive Consequences of the Azure Service Definition\\\\n# Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\\n\\\\n## Positive Consequences of the Azure Service Definition\\\\n\\\\nFrom the above definition, many processes and assets naturally flow, providing both Azure engineering teams and customers with great experiences:\\\\r\\\\n- Each service version is documented separately allowing a customer to reference the specific version of the service they are targeting.\\\\r\\\\n- Each service version gets its own SDK package version allowing a customer to import the SDK package version corresponding to the service version they wish to target.\\\\r\\\\n    - GA versions of a service get a stable SDK package and preview versions of a service get a beta SDK package. Each SDK package version must clearly document which service version it targets .\\\\r\\\\n    - When any preview or GA version of a service is retired, the corresponding SDK package version is deprecated (without affecting any other SDK packages). Note that Azure retires preview service versions regularly; GA service versions are retired when breaking changes are introduced or on other rare occasions. See [Azure SDK lifecycle and support policy](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_support.html#azure-sdk-lifecycle-and-support-policy).\\\\r\\\\n    - When a service is retired in its entirety, all SDK packages for this service are deprecated (without affecting any other services\\u2019 SDK packages).\\\\r\\\\n    - A service version introducing a breaking change will likely break that service\\u2019s SDK package in the next version causing the new SDK package version to increment its major number as per semantic versioning. This also causes old preview and GA service versions and their corresponding SDK package versions to be retired/deprecated.\\\\r\\\\n- The above service and SDK package versioning rules simplify the usage and ongoing maintenance of downstream consumers such as the Azure Portal, Azure CLI/PowerShell, Azure Developer CLI, ARM templates, Bicep, 3rd party libraries that wrap our Azure REST APIs and SDK packages (such as Terraform/Pulumi), etc.\\\\n\\\\nto increment its major number as per semantic versioning. This also causes old preview and GA service versions and their corresponding SDK package versions to be retired/deprecated.\\\\r\\\\n- The above service and SDK package versioning rules simplify the usage and ongoing maintenance of downstream consumers such as the Azure Portal, Azure CLI/PowerShell, Azure Developer CLI, ARM templates, Bicep, 3rd party libraries that wrap our Azure REST APIs and SDK packages (such as Terraform/Pulumi), etc.  \\\\r\\\\nThe following diagram summarizes how Azure internal teams and customers should think about Azure service abstractions and their relationship to each other. \\\\r\\\\n- The RP namespace identifies the Resource Provider that customers must use to manage some Azure resource(s). The namespace itself has no code and therefore never versions. \\\\r\\\\n- Within an RP namespace is 1+ control plane services and 0+ data-plane services which version uniformly over time. \\\\r\\\\n    - Private preview versions don\\u2019t have corresponding SDK package versions\\\\r\\\\n    - Public preview versions do have corresponding beta SDK package versions\\\\r\\\\n    - GA versions do have corresponding stable SDK package versions. Beta SDK package versions may also exist if the SDK package has rich functionality requiring customer testing/feedback before releasing the stable SDK package version. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cimg width=\\\\\\\"600\\\\\\\" height=\\\\\\\"400\\\\\\\" alt=\\\\\\\"image\\\\\\\" src=\\\\\\\"https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7b079665-2328-4524-8784-476e52e57343\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Can required fields have default values?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Can required fields have default values?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\\n\\\\n# Can required fields have default values?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nDoes typespec allow default value for required field? I ask as mandatory field states that users send a value but we want to be able to assign a default for them. The field is below. \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel StorageDiscoveryWorkspaceProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The storage discovery sku.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(ApiVersion.v2025_03_01_preview, \\\\\\\"tier\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @madeRequired(ApiVersion.v2025_06_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  sku: StorageDiscoverySku;\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nCan required fields have default values in TypeSpec?\\\\r\\\\nUnfortunately, TypeSpec does not currently support versioned default values for required fields. If you want to assign a default value to a required field, you\\u2019ll need to use the \\u201cremove/rename dance\\u201d workaround, as shown in the referenced playground. This means you\\u2019ll have to remove the old field and reintroduce it with a default value, which is not ideal but currently the only way.\\\\r\\\\nCan we delete unused preview versions and only keep the latest one?\\\\r\\\\nYes, absolutely. That is what we recommend. Azure services are moving toward maintaining only one active preview version per spec (except for ARM retention requirements, which typically apply only to public previews). Since you\\u2019re still in private preview and none of your previous versions are being used, you can safely remove them and keep only the latest one.\\\\r\\\\nDeprecation only matters if you have customers using those versions. For private previews, there are no SDK support requirements. You can simply remove the older versions from your TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\nWhat\\u2019s the process for moving to public preview?\\\\r\\\\nYou should open a PR against the public repo\\u2019s main branch before the public preview announcement. You can start preparing Microsoft Learn documentation using the versions merged in the RPSaaSMaster branch. The review process for public preview is slightly easier if you\\u2019ve already been reviewed privately, but it does include required SDK checks.\\\\r\\\\nYou should only bring over the latest preview version to the public repo. It\\u2019s fine to omit .tsp files in the public repo if they\\u2019re not needed.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Deprecating-Preview-APIs.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Process\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Deprecating-Preview-APIs\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"## Process\\\\n1. Open a PR deleting one (or more) previews.  All of:\\\\r\\\\n   1. TypeSpec sources (`*.tsp`)\\\\r\\\\n   2. Example sources (examples closest to `*.tsp` files)\\\\r\\\\n   3. Generated swaggers and examples (`preview/YYYY-MM-DD-preview/**`)\\\\r\\\\n   4. readme.md (remove tags)\\\\r\\\\n2. PR should fail check `Swagger BreakingChange`, but pass all other checks.\\\\r\\\\n3. Request approval following the normal process for breaking changes\\\\r\\\\n   - https://aka.ms/brch\\\\r\\\\n   - azbreakchangereview@microsoft.com\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Oav generate-examples failed\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Oav generate-examples failed\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Oav generate-examples failed\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nSteps to reproduce:\\\\r\\\\n1. clone https://github.com/minhng22/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/nguyenmin/targetk8sversionchannel\\\\r\\\\n2. Run \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\noav generate-examples specification/containerservice/resource-manager/Microsoft.ContainerService/fleet/preview/2025-07-01-preview/fleets.json\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nError \\\\r\\\\n(node:53300) [DEP0040] DeprecationWarning: The `punycode` module is deprecated. Please use a userland alternative instead.\\\\r\\\\n(Use `node --trace-deprecation ...` to show where the warning was created)\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  message: 'array details item is null, it may be caused by circular reference',\\\\r\\\\n  level: '\\\\\\\\x1B[33mwarn\\\\\\\\x1B[39m'\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  message: 'fatal error: Maximum call stack size exceeded, {}',\\\\r\\\\n  level: '\\\\\\\\x1B[31merror\\\\\\\\x1B[39m'\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nfatal error: Maximum call stack size exceeded, {}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nDoes any one know why this error happens TypeSpec Discussion?\\\\r\\\\nThis branch is based on branch `dev-aks-fleet-2025-07-01-preview` . For diff, pls see https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/34812\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nFirst thing to understand there are two copies of all examples when you're using TSP \\\\r\\\\nSwagger copy: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/33737ff460f78153f4cc21ef5d2d4586fcbae107/specification/containerservice/resource-manager/Microsoft.ContainerService/fleet/preview/2025-07-01-preview/examples \\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec copy: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/33737ff460f78153f4cc21ef5d2d4586fcbae107/specification/containerservice/Fleet.Management/examples/2025-07-01-preview \\\\r\\\\nProcess is you update examples in TypeSpec copy, then run \\\\\\\"tsp compile\\\\\\\" which copies them to swagger folder \\\\r\\\\nYour TSV may have been failing, if you changed one copy but not the other \\\\r\\\\nSecond, you can generate examples manually or using `oav` , whatever you prefer, is more efficient for your workflow, etc \\\\r\\\\nIf you think you're hitting a bug in `oav`, you can open an issue here, or discuss in any of our teams channels. \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/oav/issues\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#checklists#migrate-arm-tips.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Migrate ARM spec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/checklists/migrate-arm-tips\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Migrate ARM spec\\\\n## Initial pass through checklist\\\\n# migrate-swagger#checklists#migrate-arm-tips.md\\\\n\\\\n# Migrate ARM spec\\\\n\\\\n## Initial pass through checklist\\\\n\\\\nAzure extensible enums. See: [Defining enums for Azure services][no-enum]. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** The color of a widget. */\\\\r\\\\nunion WidgetColor {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** Red Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Red: \\\\\\\"Red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Green Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Green: \\\\\\\"Green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Blue Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Blue: \\\\\\\"Blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use templates `xxx.Private` namespaces\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` in files other than `client.tsp` or `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** reference `client.tsp` in `main.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** reference `back-compat.tsp` in `main.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations for ARM APIs in `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations that impact only generated client SDKs in `client.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations that impact both generated client SDKs and generated OpenAPI specs in `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** run `tsp compile .` on your specification and address all warnings\\\\n\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** name your ARM spec folder with `.Management` suffix.\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** configure your tspconfig.yaml. See: [example tspconfig.yaml][tspconfig]\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** extend the `@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/resource-manager` linter rule set in your tspconfig.yaml if not already there. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nlinter:\\\\r\\\\n  extends:\\\\r\\\\n    - \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/resource-manager\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your `@service` and `@server` definitions are correct in main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure `interface Operations extends Azure.ResourceManager.Operations {}` is in main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your versions enum is up to date. For an initial migration we recommend migrating your latest stable API version (and the latest preview API version the service may support after the stable API version)\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure you have correct ARM common type version select with each service version. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  ...\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)  \\\\u003c---\\\\r\\\\n  v2021_10_01_preview: \\\\\\\"2021-10-01-preview\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** review all enum definitions and add documentation over each value. See: [Documentation in TypeSpec][docs]\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** suppress documentation warnings\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use the [standard Typespec Azure.ResourceManager and Azure.Core operation templates and data-types][standard-templates] wherever possible. Standard operation templates should be used as much as possible\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use `union` instead of `enum` to define Azure extensible enums. See: [Defining enums for Azure services][no-enum]. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** The color of a widget. */\\\\r\\\\nunion WidgetColor {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** Red Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Red: \\\\\\\"Red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Green Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Green: \\\\\\\"Green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Blue Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Blue: \\\\\\\"Blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use templates `xxx.Private` namespaces\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` in files other than `client.tsp` or `back-compat.tsp`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_17.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"having trouble with examples not matching @pattern rules in github actions\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# having trouble with examples not matching @pattern rules in github actions\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_17.md\\\\n\\\\n# having trouble with examples not matching @pattern rules in github actions\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI think I'm doing something wrong when I generate my examples... what should i be doing? \\\\r\\\\nfor example this tsp:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel AcStorConfiguration is ExtensionResource\\\\u003cAcStorConfigurationProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    AcStorConfiguration,\\\\r\\\\n    NamePattern = \\\\\\\"^acstor-configuration$\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nthen:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\noav generate-examples ./specification/arccontainerstorage/resource-manager/Microsoft.ArcContainerStorage/preview/2024-10-01-preview/arccontainerstorage.json\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nand i run \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nnpx prettier --write specification/arccontainerstorage/resource-manager/Microsoft.ArcContainerStorage/preview/2024-10-01-preview/examples/*  \\\\r\\\\n npx tsv specification/arccontainerstorage/ArcContainerStorage.Management    \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nexample github action failure:https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/23604/checks?check_run_id=46129519720\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nI think you need to manually update the auto-generated strings to satisfy the regexes.  \\\\r\\\\nmost of the errors, the example itself tells you to update the string: \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nGitHub Actions / [TEST-IGNORE] Swagger ModelValidation\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nPATTERN: String does not match pattern ^acstor-configuration$: Replace this value with a string matching RegExp ^acstor-configuration$\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThis one is a little unusual, but I think just update the string to something that works, unless your spec is doing something unusual with this id property.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nGitHub Actions / [TEST-IGNORE] Swagger ModelValidation\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nINVALID_FORMAT: Object didn't pass validation for format arm-id: gkbwmag\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nExamples generation was written to produce a structure that you can update, but there is more work necessary to fully generate the placholders. It's just not been prioritized work unfortunately.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec-conversion.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec-conversion\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\\n## Conversion process\\\\n### Identify the OpenAPI spec version to convert\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec-conversion.md\\\\n\\\\n# Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Conversion process\\\\n\\\\n### Identify the OpenAPI spec version to convert\\\\n\\\\nIt must be newest version for which SDKs have been generated, regardless of whether it was a stable or preview version.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## Service Versioning Workflow\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## Service Versioning Workflow\\\\n\\\\n**Current GA**  \\\\r\\\\n`api-version: 2019-12-01`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2193\\\\r\\\\n**Preview (Private/Public)**  \\\\r\\\\n`api-version: 2020-01-01-preview`\\\\r\\\\n- Each new preview requires a later YYYY-MM-DD\\\\r\\\\n  - Avoids breaking customers using old preview\\\\r\\\\n- When new preview releases, notify customers that previous preview retires in 90+ days\\\\r\\\\n- The preview period must not be \\\\u003e1 year\\\\r\\\\n\\u2193\\\\r\\\\n**New GA**  \\\\r\\\\n`api-version: 2020-05-01`\\\\r\\\\n- GA requires a later YYYY-MM-DD\\\\r\\\\n- When GA releases, notify customers that last preview retires in 90+ days\\\\r\\\\n- New GA should be compatible with previous GA\\\\r\\\\n  - If impossible, retire previous GA in 3+ years\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"bad\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# bad\\\\n## Implementation details\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# bad\\\\n\\\\n## Implementation details\\\\n\\\\nThe contents of this article is primarily derived from the following source code:\\\\r\\\\n- [`openapi-alps` repo] / `azure-rest-api-specs.yml` configs\\\\r\\\\n- [`openapi-alps` repo] / `requiredLabelRules.ts`\\\\r\\\\nAs such, if you find a discrepancy:\\\\r\\\\n1. The source code takes precedence.\\\\r\\\\n2. [Let us know](xref:support)!\\\\r\\\\n[#6509]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/issues/6509\\\\r\\\\n[`openapi-alps` repo]: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_git/openapi-alps/\\\\r\\\\n[step 3 in the diagram]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/control_plane_template.md#pr-review-workflow-diagram\\\\r\\\\n[Breaking Change Board]: mailto:azbreakchangereview@microsoft.com\\\\r\\\\n[aka.ms/ci-fix]: https://aka.ms/ci-fix\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"emitters#clients#introduction.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Client Emitters\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/clients/introduction\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Client Emitters\\\\n## How to Use Emitters to Generate HTTP Clients from TypeSpec\\\\n### Introduction\\\\n# emitters#clients#introduction.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Client Emitters\\\\n\\\\n## How to Use Emitters to Generate HTTP Clients from TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n### Introduction\\\\n\\\\nThis guide will walk you through the process of using different client emitters (JavaScript, Python, Java, C#) to generate HTTP clients from TypeSpec. Please note that all client emitters are currently in **preview** and are subject to changes in future versions.\\\\r\\\\nBy following this guide, you will learn:\\\\r\\\\n1. How to set up client emitters in `package.json`.\\\\r\\\\n2. Update the client emitter configurations in `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n3. How to generate HTTP clients for each specific programming language.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"SDK generation configuration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-spec-gen-sdk-config\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# SDK generation configuration\\\\n## Swagger to SDK\\\\n# docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\\n\\\\n# SDK generation configuration\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger to SDK\\\\n\\\\nThis section describes what SDK should be generated by the automatic system.\\\\r\\\\nThis is not used by Autorest itself.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n$(swagger-to-sdk)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nswagger-to-sdk:\\\\r\\\\n  - repo: azure-sdk-for-net\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#checklists#migrate-dp-tips.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Migrate data-plane specs\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/checklists/migrate-dp-tips\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Migrate data-plane specs\\\\n## Initial pass through checklist\\\\n# migrate-swagger#checklists#migrate-dp-tips.md\\\\n\\\\n# Migrate data-plane specs\\\\n\\\\n## Initial pass through checklist\\\\n\\\\nwherever possible. Standard operation templates should be used as much as possible\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** review model definitions and add the `@resource` decorator over models that represent resources in your service and the `@key` decorator for the resource identifier property on the model. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** A widget. */\\\\r\\\\n@resource(\\\\\\\"widgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget name. */\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"widgetName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget color. */\\\\r\\\\n  color: WidgetColor;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The ID of the widget's manufacturer. */\\\\r\\\\n  manufacturerId: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use `union` instead of `enum` to define Azure enums. See: [Defining enums for Azure services][no-enum]. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** The color of a widget. */\\\\r\\\\nunion WidgetColor {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** Red Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Red: \\\\\\\"Red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Green Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Green: \\\\\\\"Green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Blue Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Blue: \\\\\\\"Blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use templates from the `@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager` library in a data-plane specification\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** make client customizations in a `client.tsp` file\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` in other files aside from client.tsp.\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** run `tsp compile .` on your specification and address all warnings\\\\n\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** configure your tspconfig.yaml. See: [example tspconfig.yaml][tspconfig]\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** extend the `@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/data-plane` linter rule set in your tspconfig.yaml. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nlinter:\\\\r\\\\n  extends:\\\\r\\\\n    - \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/data-plane\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your `@service` and `@server` definitions are correct in main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use the built-in [url][url-type] for endpoint specification. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"{endpoint}/widget\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"Contoso Widget APIs\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    /**\\\\r\\\\n      * Supported Widget Services endpoints (protocol and hostname, for example:\\\\r\\\\n      * https://westus.api.widget.contoso.com).\\\\r\\\\n      */\\\\r\\\\n    endpoint: url,\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure that you have a security definition (`@useAuth`) specified for your service. See: [Security definitions in TypeSpec][security-definitions]\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure you have versioning (`@versioned`) enabled over your service definition. See: [Versioning][versioning]\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your versions enum is up to date. For an initial migration we recommend migrating your latest stable API version (and the latest preview API version the service may support after the stable API version)\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** review all enum definitions and add documentation over each value. See: [Documentation in TypeSpec][docs]\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** suppress documentation warnings\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use the [standard Typespec Azure operation templates and data-types][standard-templates] wherever possible. Standard operation templates should be used as much as possible\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** review model definitions and add the `@resource` decorator over models that represent resources in your service and the `@key` decorator for the resource identifier property on the model. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** A widget. */\\\\r\\\\n@resource(\\\\\\\"widgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget name. */\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"widgetName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget color. */\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\\n# Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors.md\\\\n\\\\n# After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\\n\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n     \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-autorest\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n       emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{project-root}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n       output-file: \\\\\\\"{version-status}/{version}/DynamicSessions.json\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n3. **Common-types references** - Update relative paths in JSON files:\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n   // Before (in ContainerApps.json)\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v3/types.json#/parameters/SubscriptionIdParameter\\\\\\\"   \\\\r\\\\n   // After  \\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v3/types.json#/parameters/SubscriptionIdParameter\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   Fpr mgmt plane TypeSpec, we also need to specify the `arm-common-types` in tspconfig options of `@azure-tools/typespec-autorest`.\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n   options:\\\\r\\\\n     \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-autorest\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n       arm-types-dir: \\\\\\\"{project-root}/../../../../common-types/resource-management\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n4. **Suppressions.yaml** - Update paths in suppressions:\\\\r\\\\nAs GitHub recognize this refactor change as to add new API versions in the OpenAPI folder, in order to make sure the TypeSpec requirement check pass. we need to have a suppressions.yaml under serviceName folder \\\\r\\\\nand add suppression one by one like this \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecRequirement\\\\r\\\\n  path: ./preview/2022-01-01-preview/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Brownfield service not ready to migrate\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecRequirement\\\\r\\\\n  path: ./stable/2025-01-01/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Brownfield service not ready to migrate\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## The impact to ongoing PRs\\\\n\\\\n1. If the ongoing PRs are targeting to a release-* or dev-* branch which are not created or syncing from the latest main, we recommend to merge these PRs first.\\\\r\\\\n1. If the ongoing PRs are targeting to public main branch, Here's the suggestion to resolve the conflict. \\\\r\\\\n      1. Merge latest main \\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n          git checkout main\\\\r\\\\n          git pull origin main // origin points to Azure rest api specs repo.\\\\r\\\\n          git merge main \\\\u003cyour-pr-branch\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n      2. Resolve conflicts  \\\\r\\\\n        - For most of the conflicts, accept the incoming changes.  \\\\r\\\\n        - If it's unclear, please accept both and then update based on your judgement with the folder structure changes above.  \\\\r\\\\n      3. Make sure the new change is aligned with folder structure v2  \\\\r\\\\n         There are some cases where the PR is adding a new version in the original location, but the file diffs don't show as conflict. we should move them into the correct place so that it doesn't break the folder structure v2 as instructions in **Understanding Folder Migration sections** \\\\r\\\\n      4. clean up the previous folder if exists.  \\\\r\\\\n**Important**: It's strongly recommended to understand what's really changed in the folder refactor. Always ensure the new PR doesn't include any things that breaks the folder structure.\\\\n\\\\n### After Resolution\\\\n\\\\nMake sure to compile the TypeSpec project so that the TypeSpec Validation could pass.\\\\r\\\\n1. **Comprehensive validation**:\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#generate-with-tsp-client#intro_tsp_client.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Usage\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-with-tsp-client/intro_tsp_client\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Usage\\\\n## Prerequisites\\\\n# howtos#generate-with-tsp-client#intro_tsp_client.md\\\\n\\\\n# Usage\\\\n\\\\n## Prerequisites\\\\n\\\\nUsers working with a repository that already accepts this tool can continue to the [Usage](#usage) section.\\\\r\\\\nRepo owners should follow the steps in the [tsp-client repo setup](./repo_setup.md) doc.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"SDK generation configuration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-spec-gen-sdk-config\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# SDK generation configuration\\\\n# docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\\n\\\\n# SDK generation configuration\\\\n\\\\nTo generate SDK code based on REST API specifications, you need to configure the corresponding files.\\\\r\\\\n- For TypeSpec, the configuration file is `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n- For OpenAPI, the configuration file is `readme.md`.\\\\n\\\\n## Enable SDK generation\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003e[!IMPORTANT]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e You cannot enable SDK generation for both TypeSpec and OpenAPI simultaneously. Disable one before enabling the other.\\\\n\\\\n### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)\\\\n\\\\nAdd the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:\\\\r\\\\n    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).\\\\r\\\\n    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    namespace: \\\\\\\"Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{output-dir}/{service-dir}/{namespace}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n### [OpenAPI](#tab/openapi)\\\\n\\\\nConfigure the `swagger-to-sdk` section in `readme.md`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code for your OpenAPIs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `azure-sdk-for-net` to the list.\\\\r\\\\n2. Add detailed settings to a separate file `readme.csharp.md` and place it in the same folder as `readme.md`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger to SDK\\\\n\\\\nThis section describes what SDK should be generated by the automatic system.\\\\r\\\\nThis is not used by Autorest itself.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n$(swagger-to-sdk)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nswagger-to-sdk:\\\\r\\\\n  - repo: azure-sdk-for-net\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## CSharp\\\\n\\\\nSee configuration in [readme.csharp.md](./readme.csharp.md)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\nFor more samples on configuring specific `readme.{language}.md`, refer to:\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Management Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles)\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Data Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles-dp)\\\\r\\\\n- [Config SDK Guidelines](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/code-gen)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\\n## An Azure Resource Provider and its 1+ Azure Services\\\\n# Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\\n\\\\n## An Azure Resource Provider and its 1+ Azure Services\\\\n\\\\nIf 2+ services want to \\u201cshare\\u201d some TypeSpec/OpenAPI files, these files must be explicitly copied into a consuming service\\u2019s folder on its desired timeline. We do not allow multiple services to reference a single copy of a service contract because it is too dangerous to allow one service to change a shared contract, forcing other services to pick up this shared contract instantly, especially if the shared contract introduces breaking changes. Each service must be in control of its own destiny.\\\\r\\\\n4.\\\\tThe ServiceName folder must have examples, preview and stable subfolders. Additional subfolders are allowed to help organize *.tsp files. The rules should ensure that only the tspconfig.yaml  and *.tsp files are in the ServiceName folder.  \\\\r\\\\n5.\\\\tThe examples folder should only have a subfolder for each api-version and each api-version folder can contain only example *.json files for this api-version.\\\\r\\\\n6.\\\\tThe preview and stable folders must only have subfolders whose name match this format: YYYY-MM-DD-preview in the preview folder and YYYY-MM-DD in the stable folder. All the files in the YYYY-MM-DD(-preview) folders must be json (OpenAPI) files.\\\\r\\\\n7.\\\\tEach YYYY-MM-DD(-preview) folder must have an examples folder containing only example *.json files for this api-version.\\\\r\\\\n8.\\\\tIt is illegal for a preview and GA version to share the same date. For example, if there is a 2024-04-01-preview, then there can never be a 2024-04-01 GA.\\\\r\\\\n9. Each new control plane api-version should be unique across all the control plane service folders for an RP Namespace. \\\\r\\\\n10.\\\\tEach service name folder must duplicate the special \\\\\\\"list operations\\\\\\\" API. \\\\r\\\\n    - While this RP (not service) operation requires an api-version query parameter, the response data is not specific to this api-version; the response is api-version neutral. In addition, the response is always the same regardless of tenant/subscription.\\\\n\\\\nA single Azure Resource Provider (RP) has an RP namespace. This RP namespace can contain 1+ control-plane services and 0+ data-plane service; each service versions as described above. Today, we want the GitHub specs repo to be structured as follows for control-plane \\\\u0026 data-plane contracts:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nspecification/\\\\r\\\\n\\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003corgName1\\\\u003e/\\\\r\\\\n    \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 cspell.yaml\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 resource-manager/\\\\r\\\\n        \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 readme.md\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df NOTE: For ARM schema validation; see bullet #2 below\\\\r\\\\n        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cRPNamespace\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df NOTE: Control-plane only (not data-plane) \\\\r\\\\n            \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName1\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\u00df Customer-facing service name; each version gets Documentation \\\\u0026 SDK package\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 tspconfig.yaml\\\\t\\u00df TypeSpec files\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 models.tsp\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 readme.md\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df autorest readme with YAML blocks\\\\r\\\\n                \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 examples/\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df TypeSpec example folder\\\\r\\\\n                    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\u00df One folder per service version described in TypeSpec\\\\r\\\\n                        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cexample .json files\\\\u003e \\\\r\\\\n                \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 preview/ and stable/\\\\r\\\\n                    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\u00df One folder per service version described in OpenAPI. These folders are created and populated by compiling the TypeSpec folder for the service.\\\\r\\\\n                        \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cOpenAPI .json files\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n                        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 examples/\\\\t\\u00df OpenAPI example folder\\\\r\\\\n                            \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cexample .json files\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n            \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName2\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 data-plane/\\\\r\\\\n        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName3\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this structure, Azure services are presented as an RPNamespace that is used to manage services (both with customer-facing names). Each service has versions (some preview and some GA) and each version has its own API contract, documentation, and (beta/stable) SDK package(s).\\\\n\\\\nthere can never be a 2024-04-01 GA.\\\\r\\\\n9. Each new control plane api-version should be unique across all the control plane service folders for an RP Namespace. \\\\r\\\\n10.\\\\tEach service name folder must duplicate the special \\\\\\\"list operations\\\\\\\" API. \\\\r\\\\n    - While this RP (not service) operation requires an api-version query parameter, the response data is not specific to this api-version; the response is api-version neutral. In addition, the response is always the same regardless of tenant/subscription. Whenever any other service in the RP gets a new api-version, the TypeSpec/OpenAPI for the operations service must also be updated to match this new api-version.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003cServiceName2\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 data-plane/\\\\r\\\\n        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName3\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this structure, Azure services are presented as an RPNamespace that is used to manage services (both with customer-facing names). Each service has versions (some preview and some GA) and each version has its own API contract, documentation, and (beta/stable) SDK package(s).   \\\\r\\\\nTo enforce these rules, here are some notes about the repo structure:\\\\r\\\\n1.\\\\tIn the resource-manager folder, if it's a RPaaS service, there must be just 1 readme.md file, and 1+ service name folders under resource-manager/RPnamespace folder, but the resource types within each service folder must not duplicate except for operations, locations, checkNameAvailability etc. Which is required by RPaaS for HTTP request schema validation.\\\\r\\\\n2.\\\\tIn the data-plane folder there must be no files and at least 1 service name folder.\\\\r\\\\n3.\\\\tThe ServiceName folder must have only readme.*, tspconfig.yaml and *.tsp files in it. \\\\r\\\\n    - In the readme.md file, the latest package tag value (which represents a service version) must refer to OpenAPI files that are all in the exact same folder. Also, if the tag value is suffixed with \\u201c-preview\\u201d then all the OpenAPI paths must refer to files in the preview subfolder; else all OpenAPI paths must refer to files in the stable subfolder.\\\\r\\\\n    - If 2+ services want to \\u201cshare\\u201d some TypeSpec/OpenAPI files, these files must be explicitly copied into a consuming service\\u2019s folder on its desired timeline. We do not allow multiple services to reference a single copy of a service contract because it is too dangerous to allow one service to change a shared contract, forcing other services to pick up this shared contract instantly, especially if the shared contract introduces breaking changes. Each service must be in control of its own destiny.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"good\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# good\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# good\\\\n\\\\n- path: data-plane/Azure.Contoso.WidgetManager/preview/2022-11-01-preview/**/*.json\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n\\\\nAs an exception to the previous note, resource-manager specs **may** be able to suppress `AvoidAnonymousTypes`, but only if the error is inside a 202 response from a long-running operation (LRO).  It is known that SDKs do not need to generate type names for such responses.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#code-generation-javascript.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Getting started with TypeSpec server code generation for JavaScript\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/code-generation-javascript\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Getting started with TypeSpec server code generation for JavaScript\\\\n## Prerequisites\\\\n# getting-started#code-generation-javascript.md\\\\n\\\\n# Getting started with TypeSpec server code generation for JavaScript\\\\n\\\\n## Prerequisites\\\\n\\\\n- Node.js and NPM (required for both TypeSpec and JavaScript server code generation)\\\\r\\\\n- Basic familiarity with TypeSpec\\\\r\\\\n- Basic knowledge of JavaScript/TypeScript and Express.js\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec-conversion.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec-conversion\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\\n## Conversion scope\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec-conversion.md\\\\n\\\\n# Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Conversion scope\\\\n\\\\n- Horizontal conversion: Converting existing Azure OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec should not introduce any changes to the API.\\\\r\\\\n- No version revving: No version revving will occur during this process. The focus is solely on converting the existing\\\\r\\\\nspecifications to TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n- SDKs generated for validation only: The SDKs generated from the converted TypeSpec files will be used for validation\\\\r\\\\npurposes only. They are not intended for production release.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"SDK-Validation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Table of Contents\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/SDK-Validation\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Table of Contents\\\\n## Common Error Fix Guidance\\\\n### Import Resolution Errors\\\\n# SDK-Validation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Table of Contents\\\\n\\\\n## Common Error Fix Guidance\\\\n\\\\n### Import Resolution Errors\\\\n\\\\n#### Error Pattern: `import-not-found`\\\\r\\\\n**Error Message Pattern**: `error import-not-found: Couldn't resolve import '[.*].tsp'`\\\\r\\\\n**Root Cause**: The folder containing the imported TypeSpec files is not specified in the `tspconfig.yaml` file's `additionalDirectories` setting.\\\\r\\\\n**Solution Steps**:\\\\r\\\\n1. Locate the `tspconfig.yaml` file in your TypeSpec project root\\\\r\\\\n2. Find the `additionalDirectories` array in the configuration\\\\r\\\\n3. Add the path to the folder containing the imported `.tsp` files\\\\r\\\\n4. Ensure the path is relative to the `tspconfig.yaml` file location\\\\r\\\\n**Reference**: [Sample tspconfig.yaml](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/tspconfig.yaml#L52)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec\\\\n## Table Of Content\\\\n### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n# Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Table Of Content\\\\n\\\\n### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n\\\\n1. Create a branch in your local repository for your changes.\\\\r\\\\n2. Create or update the TypeSpec files for your service.\\\\r\\\\n3. Add or update 'examples' files for each operation of your OpenAPI file.\\\\r\\\\n   The [oav](https://github.com/Azure/oav) provides two ways to generate OpenAPI examples:\\\\r\\\\n   1. Generating basic examples and then manually modify the values. It will generate two examples for each operation:\\\\r\\\\n    one contains minimal properties set, the other contains the maximal properties set. Since the auto-generated\\\\r\\\\n     examples consist of random values for most types, you need replace them with meaningful values.\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\n       oav generate-examples openapi.json\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n    Note, latest OAV tool should automatically generate the following. However, if you are generating the examples manually,\\\\r\\\\n     please ensure you have:\\\\r\\\\n    - include `title` field and make sure it is descriptive and unique for each operation.\\\\r\\\\n    - include `operationId`. This is used to match with declared operations in TypeSpec and correctly output in OpenAPI.\\\\r\\\\n4. Add/update the `readme.md` file in the `{service}` folder to specify the version and location of the OpenAPI files. The `readme.md` is needed for both management-plane and data-plane services for REST API Docs generation.\\\\r\\\\n   Example:[sample-readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget/readme.md)\\\\r\\\\n5. Generate OpenAPI files:\\\\r\\\\n   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`git\\\\r\\\\n       git pull upstream \\\\u003ctarget-branch\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the root directory, run `npm install`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.\\\\r\\\\n6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.\\\\r\\\\n7. Send a pull request .\\\\r\\\\n   - commit all your changes.\\\\r\\\\n   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.\\\\n\\\\nOpenAPI files:\\\\r\\\\n   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`git\\\\r\\\\n       git pull upstream \\\\u003ctarget-branch\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the root directory, run `npm install`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.\\\\r\\\\n6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.\\\\r\\\\n7. Send a pull request .\\\\r\\\\n   - commit all your changes.\\\\r\\\\n   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.\\\\r\\\\n   - send a pull request to the original repo from your forked repo.\\\\r\\\\n   See the ARM Wiki for information on the [supported repos and branches for management-plane services](https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/rpaas/swaggeronboarding.html#supported-github-reposbranches).\\\\r\\\\n#### 4.1 Fix the errors of PR reviewing CI checks\\\\r\\\\nThe CI checks result will be commented on the PR. you can refer to the [CI fix Guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/ci-fix.md).\\\\r\\\\nNote:\\\\r\\\\nSince the OpenAPI is generated from TypeSpec, to change the OpenAPI, you must update the TypeSpec file and regenerate the\\\\r\\\\n OpenAPI and avoid updating OpenAPI directly to keep the consistency between OpenAPI and TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\nFor support \\\\u0026 help, you can post a message to [TypeSpec Discussion - teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47).\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Generating readme and examples files\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Generating readme and examples files\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\\n\\\\n# Generating readme and examples files\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion\\\\r\\\\nI have this PR [adding shared limit typespec by parthshah2305 \\u00b7 Pull Request #24115 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24115) to add a new resource provider's typespec.\\\\r\\\\nTwo of the validations that are failing are due to missing readme and example files.\\\\r\\\\nCould anyone point me to some documentation around generating readme files?\\\\r\\\\nI also tried generating the example files locally, but it throws the below exception . I am not sure where this path to common-types is specified to change it to point it correctly.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\noav generate-examples .\\\\\\\\resource-manager\\\\\\\\Microsoft.Limit\\\\\\\\Limit\\\\\\\\stable\\\\\\\\2025-08-15\\\\\\\\Limit.json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  message: `fatal error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open 'D:\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\repos\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\azure-rest-api-specs-pr\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\common-types\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\resource-management\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\v5\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\types.json', response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"SDK generation is NOT required for private preview approval of an ARM (management-plane) API. For private preview, you are not required to onboard SDK emitters or provide SDK configuration in your tspconfig.yaml. The Azure guidelines explicitly state that private preview versions do not have corresponding SDK package versions, and there are no SDK support requirements for private preview.\\n\\nHowever, the TypeSpec validation system (TSV) may expect certain SDK emitter options in tspconfig.yaml by default, which can cause validation failures if you remove them. To resolve this, you should add a suppressions.yaml file in your service folder and suppress the specific validation rules related to missing SDK configuration. This is the recommended approach for private preview scenarios where SDK generation is not in scope.\\n\\nExample suppressions.yaml for disabling Go SDK validation (similar approach for other SDKs):\\n\\n```yaml\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\n  paths:\\n    - tspconfig.yaml\\n  rules:\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\n  sub-rules:\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\n  reason: 'SDK generation is not required for private preview.'\\n```\\n\\nYou can suppress other SDK emitter options in the same way if you encounter validation errors for them. This allows your TypeSpec to validate and pass CI without requiring SDK configuration until you are ready to onboard SDKs for public preview or GA.\\n\\nSummary:\\n- Private preview does NOT require SDK generation or SDK config in tspconfig.yaml.\\n- Suppress SDK validation rules in suppressions.yaml to pass TypeSpec validation.\\n- You can onboard SDKs later when moving to public preview or GA.\", \"ground_truth\": \"API approval for private preview does NOT always require SDK generation or SDK configuration in your tspconfig.yaml. For private preview ARM APIs, it is acceptable to onboard and validate your API contract without including SDK emitter settings (such as for Go, Python, Java, etc.).\\n\\nHowever, the Azure TypeSpec validation tooling (tsv) is configured to expect certain SDK emitter options in tspconfig.yaml by default, even for private preview, which is why you see SdkTspConfigValidation failures if you remove them.\\n\\nThe correct and supported approach is:\\n- Remove SDK emitter configs you do NOT want in your tspconfig.yaml.\\n- Add a suppressions.yaml file in the same directory as tspconfig.yaml to explicitly suppress the SdkTspConfigValidation rule (or specific sub-rules for missing SDK configs).\\n\\nHere is a sample suppressions.yaml to suppress all SdkTspConfigValidation checks (recommended for your scenario):\\n\\n```yaml\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\n  paths:\\n    - tspconfig.yaml\\n  rules:\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\n  reason: 'SDK generation is not in scope for private preview onboarding.'\\n```\\n\\nPlace this suppressions.yaml alongside your tspconfig.yaml. This will allow CI and local validation to succeed without requiring SDK settings, letting you focus on API review and onboarding. When you later want to add SDK support, you can remove the suppression and add the required SDK emitter configuration.\\n\\nIn summary: No, API approval for private preview does not require SDK generation. Use suppressions.yaml to bypass SDK validation in tspconfig.yaml until you are ready to onboard SDKs.\"}"}]

actual.answer:
Your TypeSpec validation is failing because the CI system is enforcing the presence of Go SDK emitter configuration options in your tspconfig.yaml, even though your service does not require a Go SDK. This is due to the SdkTspConfigValidation rule, which checks for required emitter options for all supported SDKs.

Since your service does not support or plan to support a Go SDK, you should suppress these specific validation checks. The recommended approach is to add a suppressions.yaml file in the root directory of your service specification (where tspconfig.yaml is located) and explicitly suppress the missing Go emitter options for TypeSpecValidation.

Here is an example suppression file that will resolve your issue:

```yaml
- tool: TypeSpecValidation
  paths:
    - tspconfig.yaml
  rules:
    - SdkTspConfigValidation
  sub-rules:
    # Suppress validation for Go emitter options
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir
  reason: 'Service does not support a Go SDK currently'
```

Add this suppressions.yaml file to your repo, commit, and push. This will allow the CI validation to pass without requiring unnecessary Go SDK configuration. This approach is fully supported and documented in the Azure REST API specs wiki.

If you later decide to support a Go SDK, you should remove the suppression and add the required configuration options to tspconfig.yaml.

testcase: Conflicting @azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi and missing-x-ms-identifiers errors

expected.answer:
You should NOT use @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", #[]) in your Azure Resource Manager TypeSpec code. The no-openapi rule is strict: ARM specs must NOT use decorators from @typespec/openapi or @azure-tools/typespec-autorest, including $extension, because these are only processed by OpenAPI emitters and will break other emitters (like client SDKs).
For array properties, the correct approach is to use the @identifiers decorator from @azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager. This decorator is the ARM-compliant way to specify identifying properties for array items and will ensure that x-ms-identifiers is emitted in the generated OpenAPI as needed, without violating the no-openapi rule. If there are no identifying properties, you can use @identifiers([]) to indicate this.
Example:
```
@identifiers([])
myArrayField: MyItemType[];
```
If you use @identifiers, the ARM linter will recognize the array is correctly specified and will not require you to use the OpenAPI extension directly.
You should only suppress the error if you have a legitimate, ARM-approved reason (for example, for backwards compatibility or an explicit reviewer exemption). But for new fields and normal scenarios, always use the ARM-compliant decorators, NOT OpenAPI extensions.
Summary:
DO NOT use @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", #[]) in ARM specs.
DO use @identifiers([]) or @identifiers(["propertyName"]) as appropriate for array items.
Suppression should only be used in rare, reviewer-approved cases, not as a general workaround.
This approach ensures your spec is future-proof, passes all ARM validation, and is compliant with Azure API guidelines.

testcase: Need help with what appear like False Positives in ARM PR

expected.answer:
You should NOT manually edit the autogenerated hardware.json file to work around TypeSpec or linter errors. Instead, you must address these issues at the TypeSpec source level and via configuration, following Azure TypeSpec best practices.
1.ProvisioningState Must Be ReadOnly: The LintDiff check for `ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly` is triggered because the validation expects the type schema referenced by `provisioningState` to be `readOnly`, not just the property instance. The recommended (and officially supported) solution is to update your `tspconfig.yaml` to set:
```
options:
"@azure-tools/typespec-autorest":
use-read-only-status-schema: true
```
This ensures all `ProvisioningState` schemas are emitted as `readOnly`, resolving the LintDiff error at the TypeSpec emission layer and removing the need to edit the generated Swagger.
2.Missing Examples for Subscription-level APIs: The OpenAPI validation (ModelValidation) requires an example for each operation, including subscription-level (preview) APIs. If auto-generation tools like OAV are not generating examples for these, you must:
Manually add a valid example JSON file in the `examples/<api-version>/` folder of your TypeSpec project, ensuring the `operationId` matches your operation.
There is currently NO supported way to suppress example requirements in TypeSpec or Swagger for missing examples. Suppression can sometimes be done via labels (like `Approved-ModelValidation`) to unblock a PR, but the recommended approach is to provide at least one example per operation.
General Best Practices:
Do NOT edit the emitted Swagger (`hardware.json`). Always make changes at the TypeSpec or configuration level.
If you encounter TypeSpec validation failures, refer to the TypeSpec source, emitter options, or required supporting files (such as examples or suppressions.yaml for certain rule types). For LintDiff, suppressions must be done in `readme.md` or `suppressions.yaml` (for TypeSpecRequirement errors only, not LintDiff or example requirements).
Summary:
Set `use-read-only-status-schema: true` in `tspconfig.yaml` to resolve the `ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly` error.
Add missing example files for all operations, including subscription-level ones, as there is no suppression for missing examples.
Never edit the generated OpenAPI files to workaround linter errors.
Let me know if you need guidance on creating an example file or configuring the emitter options.

actual.answer:
You should not manually edit the autogenerated OpenAPI (hardware.json) to work around linter or validation errors. All changes to the OpenAPI must originate from the TypeSpec source files to ensure consistency and compliance with Azure API guidelines. 

For the `provisioningState` readOnly issue: The LintDiff check expects the `provisioningState` property to be marked as readOnly in the OpenAPI. However, due to legacy validation logic, it sometimes expects the entire type schema to be readOnly, not just the property. The correct way to resolve this in TypeSpec is to configure the TypeSpec emitter to always output `provisioningState` as readOnly. You can do this by adding the following to your `tspconfig.yaml`:

```yaml
emit:
  - "@azure-tools/typespec-autorest"
options:
  "@azure-tools/typespec-autorest":
    use-read-only-status-schema: true
```

If you use the ARM scaffolding template, this option is enabled by default. This will ensure the generated OpenAPI marks `provisioningState` as readOnly and resolves the LintDiff violation without manual edits.

For missing examples on subscription-level preview APIs: Examples must be provided for every operation, including subscription-level APIs. The recommended workflow is:
1. Design your API in TypeSpec.
2. Generate OpenAPI via `tsp compile`.
3. Use the `oav` tool to auto-generate example files for each operation (including subscription-level APIs). If `oav` does not generate examples for certain operations, you must manually create example JSON files in the appropriate `examples/<api-version>/` folder and ensure each example includes a unique `title` and the correct `operationId` matching the operation in TypeSpec/OpenAPI.

Do not suppress TypeSpec validation errors unless you have a valid reason approved by ARM reviewers (such as a false positive or a rule that does not apply to your service). Suppression for time constraints or technical debt is not allowed. If you believe a validation error is a false positive, document it and request suppression via `suppressions.yaml` with a clear reason, but this is rarely approved for TypeSpec Validation failures.

In summary:
- Do not manually edit OpenAPI files; fix issues in TypeSpec and emitter config.
- Use `use-read-only-status-schema: true` for provisioningState.
- Generate or manually add examples for all operations, including subscription-level APIs, in the examples folder.
- Only request suppression for TypeSpec validation if you have a valid, approved reason.

If you continue to see validation failures after following these steps, ensure your local environment is up to date (`git pull`, `npm ci`) and recompile your TypeSpec files. If the issue persists, reach out to the TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel for further assistance.

testcase: Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models

expected.answer:
You should not suppress this LintDiff validation error. The error `RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel` indicates that your `SharingDetail` model is being interpreted as a resource model, but it does not contain the required ARM resource properties: `name`, `id`, and `type` (all marked as readOnly). According to Azure API and TypeSpec guidelines, all resource models must include these properties to be compliant.
Suppressing this error is not the correct approach—instead, you must fix your TypeSpec definition. Ensure that resource models either extend the appropriate common-types resource base model (such as `Resource`, `ProxyResource`, or `ExtensionResource`) or, if `SharingDetail` is not a resource, ensure it is not referenced in a way that causes it to be treated as one.
For suppressing LintDiff errors in general, you can add scoped suppressions in your `readme.md` following the guidance here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions. However, for this particular error, you are expected to fix your TypeSpec spec to meet the ARM requirements—not suppress it.
To resolve this:
If `SharingDetail` is a resource, extend from the correct base model and add `id`, `name`, `type` (all readOnly).
If it is not a resource, check where it is referenced in your operations or model hierarchy to ensure it is not being treated as a resource by the code generator.

actual.answer:
Yes, it is possible to suppress the Swagger LintDiff validation error 'RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel' for your 'SharingDetail' model, but it must be done in the readme.md file of your specification, not in the TypeSpec source itself. LintDiff suppressions are scoped to the OpenAPI/Swagger output and are applied via directives in readme.md. You cannot suppress LintDiff errors directly in TypeSpec files or via suppressions.yaml.

To suppress this error, follow the guidance in the Azure REST API Specs Wiki:

1. Identify the exact path in the generated Swagger/OpenAPI where the error occurs (as shown in your error message).
2. In your readme.md, add a suppression directive under the `directive` section, targeting the specific path and error code. For example:

```yaml
directive:
  - where:
      - $.definitions.SharingDetail
    suppress:
      - RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel
```

Make sure the path matches the element referenced in the error message. For more details and examples, see the official suppression documentation linked below.

Note: While suppression is possible, it is generally recommended to fix the underlying model to comply with ARM guidelines (i.e., include 'name', 'id', and 'type' as readonly properties for resource models). Suppression should only be used when you have a valid justification and after consulting with your ARM reviewer.

testcase: How to make an interface internal ?

expected.answer: We do not support hiding an entire operation group directly. The recommended approach is to redefine your client in client.tsp to control which operations appear on the public client. When you do this properly, the default service clients and their Operations classes should not be emitted—as long as you remove all previously generated SDK output before regenerating. Or you can use _patch.py to customize the code.

references.title: How to remove certain classes for Python SDK only

knowledges.title: How to remove certain classes for Python SDK only
Usages for Test for internal decorator.
Usages for Test for internal decorator.
How to remove certain classes for Python SDK only
How to remove certain classes for Python SDK only

actual.answer:
To make an interface internal so that it does not appear in the public interface of the generated Python SDK, you should use the `@access(Access.internal, "python")` decorator on the interface. However, this approach only works if none of the operations or models under the interface are referenced by public operations elsewhere. If any operation or model is referenced by a public operation, it will still be emitted as public in the SDK.

In practice, for Python SDK generation, marking all operations under the interface as internal and applying `@access(Access.internal, "python")` to the interface should work, but only if the interface and its operations are not referenced by any public API surface. If you find that the interface still appears in the public client, it is likely because of such references or because the Python emitter does not fully honor the internal access setting for interfaces.

There is currently no supported way in TypeSpec to generate an interface for internal use only in Python SDK if it is referenced by public operations or models. The `@removed` decorator will remove the interface from all SDKs, which is not what you want. Also, Python SDK does not support removing exported classes using patch customization.

**Recommended approach:**
- Ensure that the interface and its operations are not referenced by any public operation or model.
- Apply `@access(Access.internal, "python")` to the interface and all its operations.
- If the interface is still emitted publicly, this is a limitation of the current TypeSpec tooling for Python, and there is no workaround that targets only Python.

If you need to remove the interface only for Python, but keep it for other SDKs, this is not currently supported. You may need to revisit your API design to avoid exposing the interface publicly, or accept that it will be present in the Python SDK until the tooling supports more granular suppression.

Also, Python SDK does not support removing exported classes using patch customization.\\n\\n**Recommended approach:**\\n- Ensure that the interface and its operations are not referenced by any public operation or model.\\n- Apply `@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")` to the interface and all its operations.\\n- If the interface is still emitted publicly, this is a limitation of the current TypeSpec tooling for Python, and there is no workaround that targets only Python.\\n\\nIf you need to remove the interface only for Python, but keep it for other SDKs, this is not currently supported. Is there a way to do conditional imports based off of version in main?\\nThank you in advance!\", \"response\": \"No, TypeSpec does not support conditional imports based on API versions in main.tsp or anywhere else. All imports in TypeSpec are static and apply to the entire compilation unit, regardless of version. The correct way to exclude a resource type or model from a specific API version is to use the @removed decorator from the @typespec/versioning library on the types, models, or operations you want to remove for that version. For example:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmodel MyResource {\\n  // ... properties ...\\n  @removed(Versions.v2024_12_01)\\n  propertyToRemove: string;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis ensures that the resource or property is excluded from the generated OpenAPI spec for the specified version and all subsequent versions. If you are in preview, Azure policy is to only have a single active preview version, so you may also simply delete the resource type file if it is no longer needed. But for versioned retention, always use @removed and @added decorators to control visibility per version.\\n\\nConditional imports are not supported, and you should not attempt to work around this by manipulating imports. Use versioning decorators for all version-specific changes.\", \"ground_truth\": \"no, you have to mark the models/types and everything that you want to remove with the @removed decorator using the versioning library\\nif you are in preview version I think also the policy is to only have a single preview version in the spec repo at the timme now so you could also just delete it\"}"}]

TypeSpec: How can I change only descriptions/comments between versions while keeping models identical?

actual.answer:
The best practice is to update your documentation (model descriptions) in all API versions, not just the latest. Documentation-only changes—such as improving descriptions or comments—are not considered breaking changes according to Azure and TypeSpec guidelines. These updates should be propagated to all versions, making your specs more accurate and helpful for all consumers. 

You should NOT change the output path in tspconfig.yaml to exclude older versions just to avoid validation failures. This would break the reproducibility and versioning guarantees of TypeSpec and Azure API specs. Instead, update the descriptions in all relevant TypeSpec files so that the generated specs for all versions reflect the improved documentation. 

If your CI or validation flags documentation-only changes as breaking, these should be easily approved, as they do not affect the wire shape or SDK generation. There is no need for versioned documentation changes—TypeSpec does not support versioning of descriptions/comments, and the best practice is to keep documentation up-to-date across all versions.

actual.answer:
You cannot selectively apply a pattern restriction to the resource name parameter (e.g., 'storageMoverName') for only a specific API version in TypeSpec. Decorators like @pattern are not versioned—if you add a pattern to the ResourceNameParameter, it will apply to all API versions, and this is considered a breaking change for older versions if the pattern is more restrictive than before.

The recommended approach is:
- If your service enforces the same validation for resource names across all API versions, update the pattern restriction for all versions. This ensures the spec accurately reflects service behavior and avoids inconsistencies. This is not a breaking change if the service always enforced the pattern, even if it was missing from the spec.
- If your service actually validates differently across versions (which is rare), you would need to create separate models for each version, but this leads to duplication and is not recommended unless absolutely necessary.

You should NOT manually edit the generated JSON from 'tsp compile' to add the pattern. All changes must be made in TypeSpec source files so that the spec remains the source of truth and is maintainable.

In summary: Unless your service truly validates names differently between versions, update the pattern for all versions in TypeSpec. If this is a bug fix (the pattern was always enforced but missing from the spec), apply it everywhere. If it is a new restriction, you must go through the breaking change review process. Manual edits to the generated JSON are not allowed.
